job_title: ENTERPRISE INSIDE SALES ACCOUNT REPRESENTATIVE in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good way to get your foot into the door if you're interested in getting into a sales position with UPS.  Veteran inside sales employees are a vital asset to the office environment when it comes to training and mentoring new employees.
cons: Many managers and supervisors have been in their roles for years so stagnant and recycled ideas on employee pay and job expectations don't allow for organizational growth. Typical American corporate environment where office politics and favoritism run rampant, and employee advancement opportunities are impacted.  Too many young, 20 something employees have created more of an immature, college like environment at the site.  Certain members of the management and supervisor team are unprofessional in their treatment of their employees, and are guilty of excessive micro-managing.  Extremely high turnover rate there, mainly due to poor employee treatment and inconsistent compensation plans.

review_title: OK Job..... used to be great!
job_title: Senior Systems Programming Analyst in Louisville, KY
pros: Biggest pro was the flexibility with work schedule. I was almost always able to take care of personal matters around my work schedule. There are an abundant number of extremely talented IT professionals based in the Louisville Offices. Recent (2016) emphasis has been placed on employee training. As an IT organization, that's about where the Pros stop.
cons: Extremely top heavy management structure with long-time employees holding key positions. There may be many opportunities for advancement in the near future, as a large number of managers are approaching retirement age. But for now, there is an attitude that seems more interested in self preservation, and less interested in providing innovative solutions. IT at UPS is very mature, but in my opinion it has gone way beyond the point of where processes and procedures are a good thing. The processes are usually more cumbersome than the actual work that needs to be performed.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Omaha, NE
pros: Great co-workers,  good pay, don't need to have a gym membership. If you are a hard worker and don't have a family or are attending school then this is a good place to work.
cons: 10+ hr work day with only ONE ten minute break that you do not get to choose when to take, and yes that is the only break, there is no lunch break. Food is not provided every day but it is some days. They do not inform you about the break policy in the interview. They also lied to me in the interview about the hours saying 12am was the earliest I'd come in and I would leave at 9am Tues-Sat during peak season. A week later the new schedule came out saying I needed to go in at 10pm, we end up staying till 10am usually later, Tues-Sun.  I go to school full time and explained that in the interview and was told that it wouldn't be an issue with the hours discussed. So I asked management to accommodate for my school schedule  and they told me I needed to either work the hours or leave. It is far from student friendly and the information provided in the interview is wrong and misleading.

job_title: Hub Loader/Unloader in San Bernardino, CA
pros: Great benefits package if you are able to keep work for a year until you can become a member of the union.
cons:
Very disorganized and major communication issues between employees and supervisors (including HR). 
I was told that my position was permanent and that i could advance within the company and right before Christmas on Dec. 23 50 percent of the employees hired around the time i was at the facility were told that they wouldnt be needing us at that location. In Addition it was also mentioned that day that nobody was getting fired, however, they have not placed me anywhere and i have not received an email or a telephone call from anyone at UPS. Most importantly, I found openings at another location and since I was already an employee I figured I could get placed in one of those openings (since we were told that they would place us as needed). Needless to say, that never happened and I wonder if the position was in fact permanent or was is temp all along. Afterall, my last day worked conveniently came before I would have has to be paid for the holiday. hmmm.

review_title: A good, stable, somewhat boring union job.
pros: The pay,  health care benefits, the pension and the stability of the company are hard to match. I am a full time inside hourly worker.  I have a college degree and would be hard pressed to find a white collar job with  comparable pay and benefits for the amount of time, effort, and stress that is required of me.
cons: The job tends to be boring as you are doing the exact same thing day after day.  The tension between management and the teamsters is a source of frustration as they are often in petty disputes which disrupt the workplace.  Individuals whether management or hourly are treated as a cost or liability rather than a potential asset.  Management  worries more about manipulating production numbers instead of actually trying to run the business better.

pros: Advancement within the company is probably one of the biggest pros for working at UPS. If you work hard and have completed your education requirements you will get promoted. It might take a while but you will get where you deserve to be at.
cons:
HOURS!!! Upper management does not care about your personal life. I was told to either chose school or job with UPS even though I was only a part-time supervisor. If you are on salary, you are expected to work unlimited amount of hours constantly, especially during the peak season (October to January). 

Next would be equipment. If you are working at Indianapolis Hub, you will have outdated equipment which will  frustrate your employees and you at the same time, but there is nothing you can do about it. 

The other thing that I disliked a lot was the appreciation of the work that you do. Nobody really cares about you working your behind off. I had the best running area for 8 months in a row but did not even get a good bonus at all.

pros: Flexible hours, to an extent. Fast-paced environment makes the time go fast and the employees were very easy going. Management would constantly walk around and be involved with all the processes. You can also cancel your gym membership since this job will be the new workout. The tuition assistance and schedule flexibility is the main reason I stayed so long.
cons: Summers were absolutely brutal! At the end of the night, my shirt would be completely drenched in sweat. Pretty much the equivalent of jumping in a pool. The job is also quite physically demanding and requires a little persistence to make it past the first few months. Peak season (Thanksgiving-Christmas) is also very very heavy and allows for a little bit of overtime, but it's not always worth the amount of work that you do.

review_title: UPS Part Time Supervisor in Jacksonville, FL.
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Jacksonville, FL
pros:
- Pay is acceptable
- Decent benefits
cons:
- No respect for employee's time and non-work commitments.
- Expect you to commit to a part time job as much as you do a full time one.
- HR is deceptive with information they provide during hiring process.  particularity the hours you work.
- A complete lack of integrity when communicating or relaying information.
- Very high turnover rate.
- Work environment is dangerous, loud, and very dirty.
- Upper management, without any room to misinterpret, very clearly stated they are about quantity and not quality.
- SUPER slow career advancement.
- A lack of a progressive or innovative management mentality.
- No interest in increasing efficiency by investing in technology.  A lot of administrative tasks still done with pen and paper and archaic filing.
- Absolutely no system to collect suggestions or input from lower level employees.  Strictly top-down management.
- Lower level management do a lot more mindless manual labor than manage, train, or lead.

review_title: UPS really makes you work hard to earn the great benefits/compensation.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Raleigh, NC
pros:
-100% free health insurance. Including dental, vision, prescriptions. Amazing plan too: low copays, very low prescription costs.
-With no education, this is one of the highest-paying jobs you could get. (You get a raise every 6 months too!)
-If you're in school, UPS pays you $1000 per semester to help cover tuition costs.  Its like getting a $1000 bonus check for completing each semester!
-You'll work hard almost every night. This should cause you to go home each night with a great sense of pride and accomplishment at a job well done. It's a very good feeling that you just can't get from working at, say, a grocery store.
-If you like Tetris, then loading trucks is for you!
cons:
-It gets very hot in the summer.  And you're working in a warehouse. Industrial fans and water jugs become your best friends.
-Likewise, it gets very cold in the winter.  And very, VERY busy around the holidays (Christmas).
-It is hard, heavy, fast-paced work and there's no "easy way out".  This job is not for slackers.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Hollywood, FL
pros: Nothing good about it it
cons: They are horrible for a billion dollar company. They sell you these dreams of 10.20$ and hour pay that you get every week and that you will get hours as a seasonal driver helper which is a lie. These are the most unorganized corporation EVER MADE. The managers clearly don’t speak to each other because I spoke to three different managers and each of them said something different. One manager told me to come in at 1 in the morning for me to get send home on spot because they was “FULLY” staffed but they didn’t even call me they just waited for me to show up. The job is on call so you have to long into a website just to show that you are able to work which is stupid because if I am getting hired for a job and you asking me oh do you have full day  availability  and I tell you yes why are you wasting time. Some locations don’t even need helpers they need loaders who comes in at 1 in the morning to 9. I would never refer this job to anyone it was a waste of gas and time. This is the Hollywood location in Florida. Lucky I had a second job

review_title: Once a great company, recently no work-culture
pros:
1.  Good HR policies
2.  very good for freshers as they will get the brand name for the starting of their career.
3. OT money is there, so you can earn little bit extra monthly.
4. PF is there.
5. You do not have to worry about your salary as you get it perfectly "on time" (mostly by 27th of the month before 7 PM)
6. Good HR time.
7. Nicely executed "Employee Appreciation Night" once in a year,
cons:
1. Not good enough for experienced/ tenure people. 
2. Less salary
3. Do not have  flexible timings. Forces people/ women (included pregnant women) work for graveyard shifts.
4. No work life balance (NO FAMILY TIME, NO FESTIVAL, you have to do OT for maximum processes)
5. Partial & rude management team (especially newly joined managers & supervisor)
 6. Pathetic travel desk admins.
7. Divide & rule policy, so that team unity is rare.
8. Work- Politics & Grapevines are very common.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Canton, OH
pros:
Decent Compensation
Good Benefits
Good Exercise
Five Words
cons:
Unfriendly co-workers
Uncaring management
Back Breaking Work

pros:
Hours work for those who are in school.
Work load was as expected for working for a large company.
Has a lot of benefits (can not name)
cons:
Although this is a good company to work for, the major down side is this, you cannot leave (no matter the reason) transfer until after you have worked for the company for at least a year. Working seasonal does not count as a part of your year unless they keep you on. If you leave for before that time you will not be able to come back and work for them again. AT ALL!!

Communication with managers is very hard.

review_title: Luck of the draw. Don't expect consistency!
job_title: Package Handler in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Can be great pay if you're able to advance to driver position.  ( Not as easy as it seems though.)
cons: Entry level part time package handler jobs keep you working  paycheck to paycheck for a long time before advancement opportunities come up.

pros:
- Gain some very useful management skills, such as communication and time management.
- You get out what you put in, it is your leadership that will lead to success or lack thereof.
- Room for growth, although it is a competitive talent pool.
- Safety culture is stressed.
- Amazing benefits, including tuition reimbursement and tuition discounts for certain colleges.
cons:
- You might end up putting in 75% of the total work and get little to no recognition.
- If one part of the warehouse suffers, the rest can crash and burn if there is no team work between areas.
- Management can and will ask you to do things you don't want to do, such as work off the clock.
- Safety is stressed, but then when something "goes wrong" or it is really busy, safety is probably the last thing management cares about. 
- You will work with Type A personalities: lots of swearing and a lack of respect.

pros: Compensation and benefits are good if you can get the hours
cons: Seniority if according to each department and time with company, allowing for company cuts on hours.  Full time employees do not get their full 40 hours per week and sometimes only work one or two days per week, while the company is still hiring for the same positions.  A family or individual cannot survive on these hours.    One cannot transfer to a different company location without loosing seniority, which means starting all over again.  Managers are rude, and do not give proper direction/instruction.  Managers tell you to just do it.  If compensativing work for unavailable hours is available, managers need to inform and instruct employees on what they need to do for it, where to go and how to do it.

review_title: Be prepared to stay ACTIVE - no 'slugs' tolerated
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Baltimore, MD
pros: As seasonal the pay is fair.  Treat the job like they are paying you to workout at the gym and your mindset will be in the proper place.  It IS active, quick paced walking, package carrying work so you DO get a workout during the hours you are helping the driver.
cons: NOT a job suggested for an inactive person or one with mobility problems. The work may be tough since it involves LOTS of quick paced walking, carrying packages for delivery to homes up driveways, hills, steps, etc. There MAY be ice or snow, since it IS a winter seasonal job. Job is TEMPORARY and seasonal - does NOT lead to advancement within company.

review_title: Good busy work with good benefits.
pros: The part time work sorting packages at UPS was satisfying and rarely challenging. You got great benefits for being part time.
cons:
As a part time employee the union does not really care about you. Their dues for the first few months are outrageous but worth it afterwords for the benefits. After the healthcare exchanges go up, their benefits package will probably stink in comparison to using the exchanges.
Management at UPS is horrible.They will purposely deceive you just to get exactly what they want. I ended up leaving because I do not appreciate being lied to and manipulated.
Also, as a part time sort employee I would get bumped from work occasionally. I once worked 2 days in February. When I told them I was going to seek a part time job that may run into an hour of work IF i happened to work in February, they told me that if I was not available they would fire me. Even when you are not working, they own that time.

pros: Benefits for UPS under the Union are great for what is required to work at the company. Over the course of my time being here I have developed great relations with my coworkers and associates that have helped me greatly in my own life. We all bleed brown and as long as you work hard and show your commitment to doing your job to the best of your ability there really is no reason to complain.
cons: Summer months are slow and season near the end of the year can be intense with a second job. If you want to be a driver there is a wait time since positions are based on the Unions seniority. However, if you decided to leave the union and work in management options for working at UPS open up significantly.

pros: Loved working here during my college days. Great benefits. Took care of me. I loved the work. Using your hands. I was a small 5'5" 18 year old kid about 125 pounds. But I promise you I can outwork anybody 2-3x my size and I loved it. I worked 2x as fast as the next guy. When I left, 2 of the managers told me they don't know how they are gonna get the trailers unloaded on time now.
cons: Cons kinda goes with the pros. The union allowed us to have great benefits but created lazy guys. You can't just fire a guy cuz the Union wouldn't allow it. I remember a couple guys telling me to slow down. Said it made them look bad for one and also it didn't matter if I worked harder cuz I would just get paid the same as them anyways. I hated that laziness.

job_title: Delivery Driver Helper in Nampa, ID
pros: Simple duties, “easy money” if you don’t mind physical exercise.  Good way to stay in shape. Pay isn’t bad. It was a quick hiring process, and they seem to take any help they can get.
cons: Long hours, Can become redundant, exposure to the elements. At my center in Nampa, ID they didn’t start deliveries until 10am or later on most days, causing shifts to stretch well into the 6’o clock hour, would’ve been nice if trucks were loaded and deliveries started an hour earlier. On top of that it seemed almost every day after we made all of our deliveries, we had to go and help other drivers out which was frustrating because after about 7 I was ready for home but often found myself getting home between 8:30-10pm.

review_title: Not for tall and skinny dudes
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Dallas, TX
pros:
Good pay for a first job, easy to get hired. No interview involved, everyone who shows up is hired.

Job is very straight-forward, and you are always busy.

UPS is good about promoting from within. If you stomach this job long enough and kick butt you can become a delivery driver.
cons:
Once you get out of the cushy training, you work in the middle of the night (they always have a shortage for this shift). Management is a bunch of monkeys, which is expected at a job like this. Employees are a bunch of monkeys too. Make sure you exercise regularly before working here.

I am 6ft 150lb dude. I used to buss tables and I was fast. At this job, I couldn't keep the same pace without hurting my back. I would pop painkillers prior to working, and that would help a lot. While working here a few months my legs would be in a constant state of extreme bruising from the pace they want you to work, so I couldn't wear shorts without looking like a case of domestic violence.

review_title: Not for me but a good overall company
pros:
I worked here briefly over the summer  as a loder/unloader. If you keep at your work and meet the demands, theirs a lot of oppurtunity after probation to elevate yourself into a higher position, a former coworker was able to be a manager within a couple of months.

All of the seniors that I personally worked with were very nice people, something about doing mundane work really binds people together.
cons:
More personal for myself, but you will be working like a dog
May have to work overtime without componsation
You will more than likely do unloading as it is much harder for them to keep people in that field
If your a big guy, they will put you in air containers to unload, even if their are shorter people who can actually fit.
Theirs a bit of sexism in terms of workload, men get more laborious tasks, pretty woman get placed onto scanners/sorting.
Management can be jerks, salary paid = wanting to get out as soon as possible.

review_title: Hard work, but good pay + benefits
pros:
- good work out for the body
- good pay
- good benefits 
- $5000 financial assistance for students annually
-supervisors were nice, work environment is very friendly. People are very willing to help you if you need it.
- lots of opportunity to move up if you want it and are aggressive about it
cons:
-  It is a very physical job, which can be both a plus and a negative.  You have to make sure you are staying healthy and eating right or you're going to have a really hard time. 

- It is very stressful when boxes stack up in a truck faster than you can load them. The packages will just keep coming and start overflowing off of the sides of the conveyer. This is an inevitability that comes with the job. It was my least favorite part of working as a package handler despite liking most everything else about the job. If you are not someone who can easily handle this kind of stress you might want to take that in to consideration before working here.

job_title: Human Resources Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros: There are many advancement opportunities, mostly all in operations. You have to work hard, achieve results, and have a positive attitude. UPS is a company that promotes from within, most people start off as package handlers others through an internship. Union benefits are great! Non union benefits are good. UPS has matching 401k, great time off options.
cons: A lot of UPSers  in management work 12-16 hour days. Sets a bad precedent for the new generation. If we only work 8-10 it’s not enough. There has to be a balance between work and life and in order to have that the 12-16 hour work days needs to be minimized. Other cons are management trying to keep their strong performing  employees in their specific area because they don’t want to lose them to something else. It is very important that we think of UPS as a whole and getting strong performers into different roles if that is what will be best for company and not holding them back because they’re good at what they do.

review_title: The only company who's ever treated me like a human being
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Orlando, FL
pros:
Great work culture. Everyone is accepted socially no matter their race, religion, sex, ect and I truly feel equal as a woman here. The supervisors really care and listen to us and treat us with respect. My hard work and dedication is always noticed and rewarded, and I honestly have never felt so at home at any workplace. There's always an opportunity to move up and I've never felt "stuck".

14 dollars an hour is a lot when you're used to minimum wage, cut hours and terrible bosses, and it saved me when I really needed money. Without UPS, I . don't know where I'd be right now. 

They also offer amazing benefits after 9 months, which I'm looking forward to.
cons: Parking can be a bit difficult to find. Management is way too hard on supervisors and I think they deserve a bit more pay (even though this isn't my position as of now)

review_title: Seasonal Helper Easy to Join, Easy to Stay? Depends on You
pros: The work is consistent, 10 hours a day, 5 days a week,  with overtime.
cons:
Exposure to the elements, so just prepare yourself well. Work can be hard if you're not properly prepared for it. Because it was a seasonal job, and the amount of packages skyrockets at that time of year, there is constant pressure to deliver fast, despite how new you are, which is perfectly understandable. However, you are not given any training during the orientation, which will be a source of stress, when you are in a hurry to deliver.


Also the job does not pay very well considering the amount of work that you will do, which outside of driving and some deliveries, is the same work that the driver does. It was $8.00/hr when I was a helper, but I heard that it was raised to $10.00/hr this year, which is better, but I think it can still be better.

review_title: Love the holiday season? Working here may turn you into a Scrooge.
pros: Fast-paced environment (never bored). Job security. Advancement from within. Challenging, rewarding work. Good, committed people. Pride in knowing that you work for a fortune 50 company, and help play an essential part in daily world commerce. Non-traditional work environment (ie no cubicle).
cons: Very demanding work, physically and mentally. 24 hour operation equals lots of long days and nights (avg workday at least 12 hours). No guarantee of advancement through the years (limited openings).  Decent salary, but when I do the math to find out hourly rate, I cringe. Vacations are not very flexible. Holiday peak season-you might as well just live at the office for the month of December.

pros: Stable company with continued strong future earnings potential. Large corporate office offers a multitude of opportunities for ambitious employees.
cons: Work/life balance is a distant memory. 'Do more with less' has reached the breaking point for my team of talented, dedicated employees. I am aware of several long-term management employees looking elsewhere. This is not insubordination or lack of work ethic - it is actually just the opposite. These are people who take tremendous pride in their work and welcome new challenges. With streamlined staffing and ever-increasing workloads, it is impossible to sustain the necessary hours to stay afloat with any quality output.

Micro managing is EXTREMELY high and they treat Associates like high school teens. review_title: Decent pay but managment is out of touch with reality
job_title: Small Package Sorting/Bagging/Debagging in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The pay and benefits are decent and even as part time you get benefits which is very rare.
cons: Management doesn't really care about the well being of employees, does not matter how fast you work it should always be faster, management has unrealistic expectations sometimes, monotonous work that will be replaced by robots and would have already if it was not unionized, takes a toll on your body, especially in AZ where I am with the heat, every year people there people that get sick of in the hospital because they didn't listen to their body and usually didn't drink enough water.

review_title: Good Company to Work For but Low Potential
job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros: The people are amazing here and you'll establish a great network quickly. The benefits are good as well if you negotiated correctly.
cons: Still a very traditional company, they are trying to become more of a startup but there is a very slow adoption rate to this new methodology.  In addition, the older members are hindering change and there is not much growth for those that want to stay, hence they leave.

pros: Clearly, the pay. And that's about it!
cons: HR is seemingly the most incompetent, inexperienced, lazy, unprofessional, personnel with absolutely no knowledge or even a clue. No one knows anything, cares about anything, or care to know. I am so disappointed, as I thought ups would be a great company to work for. Due to their sheer size, you'd THINK they're organized. I do NOT know how they're even functioning, much less, profitable. The warehouse workers are treated like slaves. Just bottom barrel. They work in VERY DANGEROUS environments. The drivers are the next step up from warehouse. So, they're not treated much better. The workload is barely manageable. You work in an oven. No air in the warehouse or trucks. No heat in the warehouse and maybe a bit of heat in the trucks. The upper echelon of the company looks down and urinate on non corporate workers. They move you around as if you're nothing. With no regards to your personal life. There is no work-life balance. Ugh. I can go on and on. My heart is simply broken.

pros: Easy job to get when in need
cons: very hard work, will hurt

pros: Your supposed to get paid every Thursday but the checks are usually late.
cons: If you get stationed at a shopping mall for the holiday season so you will be dropping off carts of heavy 50 lb boxes in the storage rooms of the big dept. stores. and stacking them until your arms feel like they are about to fall off. You will be sore all over your body after a 4 hour shift then a week later you will find out that you got docked a few hours because of clerical or driver error logging in your shift.  My first check was 2 weeks late then I got docked 2 hours on my 2nd check. They charge $22 per month for union dues even for temporary employees. The drivers are mean and aggressive and will embarrass you in public to hurry up despite doing your best nothing is ever good enough. You will always get told off about something. They also have no patience and will walk over people that get in the way of their path of delivery.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: Good work/life balance, lots of time off earned, relatively easy job, 8-5 M-F and never overtime, paid vacation, pays weekly
cons: Lots, if you get a bad sales territory you won’t get promoted, they have preferential treatment, it’s luck of the draw what team you end up on, they promote within but it’s based on numbers(which you’re selling a service, not a tangible product, you can’t force people to ship more), all territories have the same goals but aren’t the same(imagine Florida has lots of exports and Amish country has the same expectations). If you get put in a promotion patch you’ll get out, if not you’ll spend years here. They don’t promote on experience but on numbers(which aren’t controllable). Then if put on an action plan you can’t apply for promotions for 6 months. Also, plan to relocate to get a promotion. Basically look for another job unless you really love UPS. Oh the moral sucks.

review_title: Learn a lot and feel ahead of my peers, but slow-moving
pros: I started at UPS when I first got out out of school. In retrospect, I’m really happy it was my first job. You learn a lot and have the opportunity for exposure. The salary is decent and the benefits are nice.
cons: UPS is working on their work-life balance, but it’s a massive corporation so it’s taking time. It also just depends on what group you are in. The worst part about UPS is the “peak ready team.” They did not do one to my knowledge for 2018, but in 2017 I (and many others from the corporate office) was sent to work in a hub for about 5 weeks between thanksgiving and Christmas, and all I got was a mug. This is also not necessarily a “fun” place to work. Most employee events have an awkward vibe, because again, it is so big. That being said it is what you make it!

review_title: Excited to start - more excited to leave
pros:
Stability
Benefits of working for a Fortune 100 company (respect)
Benefits package (costs increasing as I left)
Ability to understand both a corporate environment and a post-military regime
cons:
Compensation
Ability to grow within a position
Ability to advance within the company
Ability to compete within transportation industry as well as in attracting/retaining talented employees
Long term strategies

review_title: MICRO-MANAGERS!  Politically motivated managers just trying to cover their own a**!
pros: Great brand, great reputation for servicing their customers.  Benefits are good too but changes are starting to effect that view.  Rising insurance costs and new rules for getting stock options, etc.
cons: AEs are drowning in reports, paperwork, meetings, and "strategy meetings".  Instead of selling, they are spending endless nights, mornings, days reporting on everything and anything that has happened!  How about letting them sell instead of talking it to death?  They cause many tenured employees to quit because they get tired of all the BS paperwork!  If you complain, you get  targeted and they find a way to get rid of you.

pros: I worked as a sorter and got two raises in less than 6 months. I worked in a main hub which is a huge building that gets packages from alot of states around the world. You get paid great for a good work out! I worked 3rd shift so i worked at night while my children slept. I left around 9 and was home by 2. You can advance quickly if you are smart and can pass a test with about 100 questions. Pay starts above min wage and after 90 days goes up then if you take your sort test another dollar than a dollar raise every year.
cons: It is very fast paced! If you are working at a main hub like i was with over 400 people a shift you will work fast and hard. Be prepared to sweat and go home with wet clothes. But the job is easy overall if you have a good memory and can remember zip codes and colors. Rule is your hand should be on a new box every 3 seconds!

review_title: Poor communication and management is bad!!!
job_title: UPS Preload and Peak Driver in Longwood, FL
pros: After you work for a year then you get good medical/dental insurance and other benefits.
cons: I was hired for peak driver, but when I showed up I was informed it was for a part time preload position and after October 15 I would start driving. Began driving at the beginning of December, only till the 24th not January 15 as previously stated. Management don't care about their personnel. You show up to work at 4:15am and they send you home. Waste of time, gas, etc. when you work is non stop for 3 hrs then a quick 10min break and that's it. For $11:00/hr you are breaking your back. I joined because I wanted to work but, an hour a week doesn't pay the bills. They give you a nice picture of what the job will be, but once you get in its different and disappointing.

job_title: Auto Fleet Supervisor in New York, NY
pros:
Career opportunities
Decent pay even though the  MTA pays more for the work we do.  
Schedule can be very flexible if you need time off it's allowed so long as it's not abused.
You can make it a career and it takes a serious egregious act to get fired. So job security is  great. Keep it honest in everything your do in and you'll be employed until you retire
cons:
Disorganization- A lot of internal systems  that are a part of the job function  don't work  correctly and   upper management always wants to blame it on human error rather then correct the issues with the tools they provide  to accomplish the job.

Confusing Promotion process- individuals  with  10 years plus  get passed up by others with  less years  or promotion

Disconnect between corporate and  field- Seems that corporate come s up with ideas and directives but doesn't seem to  connect with the individuals working in the field.

review_title: STAY AWAY FROM ENTRY LEVEL POSITIONS - (full/part-time) !! RUN AWAY
pros:
tuition reimbursement
daily over-time compensation rate
cons: The harder you work the harder they work you. Hours are terrible. Twilight (3 am - 10 am) evening (5 pm - 11 pm). They say you only have to fulfill 4hrs and 30 mins a day, but they won't let you go until much later. You do get overtime after you complete your first 4 to 5 hrs (daily overtime), every hour after is time and a half.  Twilight shift gets paid about $11/hr and evening shift gets paid $10/hr.  Must work for a full year to qualify for health coverage and other useful benefits. Union has too much power,  you have useless workers walking around the warehouse all day doing nothing or hiding in the break room from other employees to get away from work. Work performance means nothing to them so put in the minimum amount of effort. Tell them everything is very hard to do so they do not take advantage of you (which they will).

pros: Currently the overall compenstion package is decent.  UPS rarely terminates employees so job security is a plus.  In this eceonomy I have valued this.
cons: Management is a very "good ol' boys" with promotions and information.  You can be the top performer and get minimal recognition - the job is thankless.  The sales team works 70+ hours a week as support resources have been all but eliminated.  Attainability of sales compensation in my area is only 18% due to the creative pay structure which is inentionally mastered to reduce payout.  This is discouraging.  Management style is shame based.

review_title: Good job for college but not much further.
pros:
Benefits that now take a year to get. (I got them in 7 weeks)
Tuition reimbursement
cons:
Managers yell for you to work faster but after you get in the union you can ignore them since they can't really do anything to you.
General working environment seems extremely moody and short-tempered, not management for the most part but sorters and some fellow unloaders are always yelling and can be a pain to deal with.
Cheap as hell. The safety BBQ that is held quarterly at best, consist of a can of pop, bag of chips, and two burgers grilled out back. It probably costs $2-3 a person and anytime anything else is proposed it costs too much even though it's 4 times a year at best and usually or once or twice.
Also, they are so cheap that they don't supply pens to supervisors that have to do paperwork.

pros:
-Medical and dental benefits are awesome (low copays)
-Pension
-Overtime after 5 hour for part-timers
-Tuition reimbursement
-Union 
-Vacation time
-Variety of jobs
-Weekends off 
-Paid holidays
-Work is done at the end of shift unlike other jobs when work can drag on for weeks or months. Every day is a new beginning.
cons:
-Extreme temperatures, no a/c or heat
-Very physical work (I was told when I was hired to get a feel for the job I should pick up a box of paper and move it across the room and then repeat for 3 hours.)
-Hard to get full time work, especially if you don’t want to drive. I been bidding for 10 years and not full time yet.

review_title: NO Work-Life balance!  Great company benefits but NO LIFE!!!!
job_title: Senior Account Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: This company still has better benefits than most small organizations.
cons: All management in all departments micro-manage their groups and overburden employees with too many reports, recaps, reviews, meetings and anything else that doesn't help win the business!!  It is only used to CYA the managers!  If you mention it or disagree with their reasoning, you are targeted and removed as a disgruntled employee, regardless of your meeting goals!  Early mornings to late nights...doing reports!!!!  STRESS!!!!  It is just NOT worth it?

review_title: Place is going downhill, shows no signs of changing.   Can't keep consolidating management positions and expect results
pros: Strong company, not going anywhere anytime soon.   Locations are in every city for the most part.
cons: Upper management is completely out of touch with reality.  Hey let's add a new board or directors position making millions, but cut the lower grunt positions who do all the hard work so some clown can reap the benefits.   Expectations haven't adjusted to the current market place.   Unable to retain talent due to awful working conditions as a package handler.  Company is increasingly hiring managers externally and these people don't understand what goes on in the front line management positions.

review_title: This is how we have always done it
pros: Benefits, worked with some good people get rid of management could be a great place
cons: Managers to long in same spot, resist change, nepotism , silos ,do not start entry level you will be lied to and will not be able to move up . Higher management does not care ..likes things status quo lots of high priced people watching videos...managers can be nasty treat you like idiots.no where to go stay in your little silo job. job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Work at your own pace. You are able to work on your own about 90 percent of the time. The position allows you to prospect and hunt customers using your own style or use common practices. Base pay is great and co workers are helpful and understand the products. Room for growth is very abundant.
cons:
Not all Supervisors and Managers in the office follow the same rules and guidelines. One may work with reps on issues like tardiness and attendance, the other may not. Culture of the company is very conservative, no beards and business or business casual are required. Most sales coaches and supervisors do not have much sale experience which is hard to get help on a sales strategy from them.

Systems are very old and are very unhelpful when trying to find sales. There is only one internal system that gives leads which come from drivers and other sources.

pros: - The benefits, especially for a part-time role, are really hard to beat. That goes for both union and management positions.
cons: - The culture is terrible. UPS is an old company that retains an atmosphere of management that feels like it is a generation behind. Combining that with grueling physical labor, a large amount of pressure to hit production goals, and management personalities that lack soft skills can make for a pretty miserable work environment.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Pensacola, FL
pros: You work with people that share your hatred for the job.
cons: The hours kinda suck (anywhere from midnight to 9:30a up to 3:30-9:30a) they rope you in by saying you get $14/hr and you get paid weekly, which is awesome if you work more than 20 hours a week (which doesn’t happen unless you’re seasonal) they tell you that you can move up within a year to a full time driver (that’s false because there are no driver positions available and you get put on a list of seniority. I was personally told that it would be at least 2-3 years before I could become a driver because of the waiting list) they offer you “driver assistant” jobs to help the drivers in the bulk of the seasons, which is awesome because you get more pay, but they don’t tell you that it resets you in the seniority list to become a full time driver. Drivers make $30/hr and then every hour they work overtime, they get paid time and a half, package handlers don’t get paid anything overtime except normal pay then supervisors yell at you if you work past 9:30.

review_title: I wake up everyday and wonder how did I end up allowing myself to be treated like this.
pros: Getting paid at the end of the month. If you been with the company forever you have seniority and get several weeks of vacation.
cons: Hostile environment. As a salary employee they abuse your time. No work life balance. Don’t expect a break or have time to eat. I can’t even use the restroom without my phone being blown up of hostile questions. Upper management use intimidation. Money isn’t worth the stress you are put through. If you’re new you have 2 weeks of vacation out of the year until you hit 5 years. Long hours a day to only have 2 weeks. It seems the better you are the more they put on your plate extending your day and stress. I’ve witnessed a lot of prejudice and discrimination. But you are bullied into “what is said here, stays here”.  I’ve had my job threatened numerous times inappropriately in front of an audience. I’m cussed out daily. Oh, and if you’re a woman be prepared to be sexually harassed daily. Upper management does not care about your well being. All they care about is a number. And if you can’t produce the number, you are garbage.

review_title: UPS - Good pay but they own you!
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Money!  Where else can you earn 50K plus a year without a college degree?  Package drivers earn a good wage but work their tails off for it!  Part time employees...forget it!  The pay is horrible along with (or without) bennies which I will discuss later.  Management makes a good wage but works long hours and is on call 24-7.  Benefits are good for full time.  The company is financially stable!  It's a very structured company so you won't get freedom to explore.
cons: You belong to Big Brown when you work there.  Management / hourly relationships are not very good.   You work hard as a driver and the demands are high.  The part time warehouse people work hard for little pay.  You don't receive bennies until after 1 year.  Senior management is always trying to find a way to squeeze more from employees.

weekends off
paid vacations and paid holidays after one year.

pros: The only pros to this job are the benefits and the overtime (after 5 hours in a shift you get time and a half)

Coworkers - Scum of the earth

review_title: Poor place to work in IT
job_title: Junior Software Developer in Carrollton, TX
pros: Nice facility.  Good workspaces as far as cubicles go.  Management was easy to communicate with.

review_title: A great place to get a career started but difficult not to become a disgruntled employee over the long term.
pros: The benefit of working at UPS is simply that, the benefits.  A great overall package consisting of medical, dental, 401k match and an employee stock purchase plan were the main offerings.  The work environment is great for a recent college graduate that can dedicate a good deal of time to their career.  Those who can put in the hours are generally given a preference and the opportunity to develop.
cons: If you're an hourly employee at UPS you can pretty much expect to work a standard 40 hour work week, but if you are a salaried employee watch out, you'll be working the extra hours to complete things the hourly employees couldn't get done.  Very difficult to advance in departments outside of the core operations due the number of people competing for the position and the length of time between an available opening.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler Loader in Cerritos, CA
pros: Supposedly if you work for more than one year you get benefits like medical,dental, etc. Pay it 10.10/hr. Not much good things to say. If you can avoid working here do it.
cons: Were do I start. UPS works you like a dog, they don't care about your well being even tho they train you to be safe and employees wellness is paramount its all bull. I started in the worst time possible peak season November-December. I worked up to 12 hours in one shift and this is part time. lol My body has bruises up and down and elbows are about to give out. This is not worth it to mess up your body with any injury for 10.10/hr. After UPS works you like a dog they short your wages, Managers short your wages because they look better or receive more bonus if they get the job done with less hours and they only have a certain amount of hours they can give out. Its all bull.

job_title: Enterprise Sales Agent in Richmond, CA
pros: Great co-workers and overall team mentality.  The company does have talent within its ranks.  Seen everything needed to coordinate at the national level and its truly astonishing.
cons: Good ole boy mentality.  I am firmly against the notion that tenure equals ability.  Just because you've been at a job for X amount of time mean your qualified to lead a team of individuals.  Some metrics are not clearly explained and seem to consistently change.  Since my employment date, I've seen the pay change every year.  Its discouraging to those who would like to purchase a home, car, etc.

review_title: If you like hard work and great benifits
job_title: Package Handler/Seasonal Driver Helper/Seasonal Plant Engineer Helper in Commerce City, CO
pros: Job Security, Benefits (hands down the best I have ever seen), you get paid to work out, they cover College Tuition, great people to work with. I was able to get a much higher paying engineering job because of some of the industrial maintenance experience I was able to receive.
cons: Have to keep track of your hours, ecspessaly around peak season, there have been many cases where hours were forgotten or missing.

job_title: Seasonal Package Handler in Portland, OR
pros: It really does sound like if you plan to be long term with UPS you will do well and move up to some great positions.
cons: Seasonal: you’ll do an over the internet interview and may get the wrong info about when and where to show up for the first day. (This happened to me and a number of others.) Be advised that while they SAY you will get paid for that orientation the first day, you will not be on the clock until 45 minutes after it’s started. Also know you must join the union at that time and agree to a $175 initiation fee taken from your weekly paycheck incrementally.  As a 15-20 hour/week seasonal, that may not pencil out.  It was a waste of my time and a bit of a bait and switch for people hoping to earn a solid seasonal check.  Anytime an HR person sounds like a salesman, you should feel red flags going up.  This job is right for some, but it gives less than advertised.

job_title: Drivers Assistant in South Portland, ME

ups hired me when other employers were looking at resumes
very streamlined straight forward hiring process, all you need is a pulse and no skeletons in your closet.
surprisingly consistant monday thru friday hours.
no problem with overtime
good exercise, you will be great shape for first runs of ski season.

get the dirt on folks in your neighborhood.
nice customers will give you cookies, and nicer ones will give you rum brownies.

review_title: Delivery Driver Seasonal Helper Austin Texas
job_title: Delivery Driver Seasonal Helper in Austin, TX
pros: The staff are nice people however there is lack of direction and the scheduled is disorganized. Mnay times I have had to call in to see if I am working I am told "Yes" then I receive a call back saying "No".
cons: During the 2014 Christmas seasonal  hiring seminar we attended, the director of human resources said that the seasonal helpers for delivery driver helper  were hired in at $8.50 and hour while warehouse workers were being paid. $10.50. We were assured that a "commitment bonus" would be on our paychecks of $75.00 per week which would bring our hourly rate up to what warehouse season help was getting. We had to make a commitment of working through January 17th. And we had to be available to work the day before and day after of Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Years. The first paycheck came around so did the 2, 3,  and we were told that they were not going to honor what human resources told us. I celebrated Christmas without ever seeing a bonus.  Do not work for UPS as a seasonal delivery driver helper if you need more that $8.50 an hour. Apply for a warehouse position.

pros: UPS promotes from within. Great healthcare. The management team is generally pretty good; a lot of emphasis on management training.
cons: The pay can be low for certain jobs relative to industry standards. For instance, the Finance and Accounting jobs are at a lower pay rate than similar jobs at other companies. Emphasis is placed on higher education, i.e. MBA, for management jobs, but the company does not pay anything for anything beyond a Bachelor's degree. It can also be difficult to take a vacation longer than a week even if you have the time.

review_title: Best sales in District 2 out 3 years, Passed over twice.  Once you get your 3 years of experience, find a better offer.
job_title: Account Manager in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: UPS spares no expense in training supervisor and management level employees.   It is a great place to begin a carrier right out of college.
cons: UPS does not promote based on performance but on the amount of ass you kiss.  If you are not willing to kiss some major ass and go out for drinks with your boss this is not the place for you.

review_title: I am very happy for the opportunities and experiences that I have received from my employment at UPS.
pros: UPS has great benefits from the day you start working with the company even as a part-time  worker you receive good heath and insurance benefits.
cons: The only downside that I can see is the amount of overtime that I receive.  Sometimes I want to make it to different functions but I can't really plan anything because the day to day delivery is never the same and you never know what other factors may come into play in the course of a regular work day.

pros: Great work experience because you'll face many different scenarios that you won't get from other company's. You'll definitely know what it's like to be "thrown in the fire." Employee discounts are pretty good.
cons: Raises are a joke unless you're liked, or kill the numbers. Production goals used in the Quality Performance Review are too high in some areas so most p/t sups won't hit their target goals for an average. This is one of the ways that they keep raises down. Unfortunately all the centers have the same goals even though it's a lot easier to make your numbers in certain centers than others. And if you happen to beat your numbers for this year you have to beat those numbers next year and so on... Management move around a lot so there's always a new "flavor of the day" on what they want...no uniformity.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative to Account Executive in Greenville, SC
pros: This is a sales environment, and the do an excellent job of selling you on a dream
cons: Everything, they lie, they lie, they lie

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Greeley, CO
pros: The elements of a potentially great workplace are all there. You can move up if you put in the time.
cons:
The business revolves around hiring new people, because so many employees quit. Management DOES NOT CARE how often you show up for work, how hard you work, how good a job you do, etc. It sounds crazy but this is the business model they've fallen into. They would rather hire a new employee than pay an above average employee to stay there. They will abuse your work ethic and hire someone to take your place the second you decide it's no longer worth being mistreated.
The worst of it is that this job will destroy your body. Corporate places a lot of emphasis on safety, yet in the facility employees are STRONGLY encouraged to sacrifice safety for the sake of speed. It's very sad, but on the days corporate inspects the facility, employees are instructed by management to adhere to all safety rules. Safety rules which they have never heard of before or are normally instructed to disregard for the sake of quicker production.

pros:
Tuition Assistance Program

everyone quits because they don't know what work is until they work for it so that means you have to pick up their shifts. (Good/Bad)

they knew they were letting out me go but didn't say anything til the day before.I got a call that i was out of a job. I worked seasonal for 2 1/2 yrs AND was never hired on. Even tho I was told several times that I was going to be by management. I was an auditor. Which winter spring summer or fall u open trailers and verify if its a load or not. I work 5hrs walking non stop around the truck yard. Was on time and rarely missed work and they still did not hire me.
 And because they didn't have any positions avalialbe they let all of the temps go.Management are idoits and control freaks about everything. Exspecially with the drivers. The drivers make sooo money but they cry and complain nonstop. Which was really annoying.

pros: Great pay for full time employees before last contract.  New full time employees will only get about 3/4 of the pay that full time drivers were  before last contract.
cons: It is nothing but a numbers game at UPS now that they are a publicly held company.  If you do not make the productivity numbers that they set for your route you are besieged by management until you can or they will micromanage you and find any and all reasons to "write you up" so they can bully you into resignation.  They treat all employees like "pack mules" and do not allow a healthy work- life balance.  If you get hurt on the job, even if you were following company safe work procedures, they will send you to a company Dr for evaluation.  The Dr's are hired by UPS and are biased in all decisions concerning your health,  the company only want you back at work ASAP, with little concern for your physical health.

pros: Great campus, fitness center, cafeteria, fitness trails, cubicles are well planned generally.  Hard Walled offices are distributed by rank and are not for the rank and file.  Good medical and dental benefits.  401k match available.
cons: You will hear a lot about values and our corporate responsibility to the community which is supported by leadership.  Get the comp you want when you come in. Raises are very modest and tied to your performance review.  A fabulous employee will be eligible for a 2% raise.  This is a top down organization and it is not unusual for someone to have an issue with you but never discuss it with you, they will go to your boss instead who may discuss it with you or just put it on your review at the end of the year.  This is typical human behavior. If you can let it roll off your back then this culture is a good fit for you.

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Ontario, CA
pros: great benefits and one heck of a learning experience if you've never been involved in anything business related before in your life.
cons: It's a stressful job but then again what job out there isn't. You might feel sometimes like you wanna quit just because of one or two bad days but it's so important that you don't. Go home, let your frustration out, and come back the next morning ready to seize the day.

review_title: Count the days until I can finally plot my escape route
job_title: UPS Part Time Package Handler in Middleburg Heights, OH
pros: weekly paycheck, most holidays off (thank goodness!)
cons: They are always critical of your performance along with many of your coworkers.  New people to different departments get treated really bad by some coworkers that have a lot of years at a particular dept. Most of them would be in for a rude awakening having to go out and get another job that's not a union shop and not make what they make at UPS.  If this place ever started losing money and started having layoffs or eliminating certain jobs many of the long time full time and part time workers would be in for one big shock.   You feel like telling these people everyone has to start somewhere and nobody new to any particular job does it 100% right away it takes time.

review_title: Good if you put in the time
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great benefits, Guaranteed raises every year, co-workers are what make the job, and you'll most likely get along with all of them you talk to. Management will let you come in late if you have another job. No drug testing.. not even if you're driving.
cons:
PLEASE LISTEN CAREFULLY!! If you are hired here, and wish to advance, you can't if you work hard.  It's all about seniority and bidding jobs based on seniority to advance.  My first couple years loading at UPS I broke records, I was the one every supervisor wanted.  I always thought my hard work would pay off.. IT DOESN'T!! Don't kill yourself. 
Management will abuse you if they find out you can work hard.  You will have extremely lazy co-workers around you, who do half your work in twice the time, and they get treated better than you.

pros:
if you are in the union then you can guarantee a long and successful career in UPS because you will always have the support of union. if you are in management - then good luck to you because you will be blamed for everything that goes wrong. you will not be supported by management when exceptions are not directly related to you.. and HR will side with upper management every single time. Best of luck 
if you accept a position in management then join a good gym and work out regularly to deal with stress... statistics show UPS management turn to alcohol to deal with stress.
cons:
Moral is often very LOW 
in some stations (Management) shows no appreciation to those employees who literally bleed brown. 
Employees are unhappy but are afraid to voice this because they will let go. 
Management finds ways around corporate policy to let go of employees who pose a threat to their position. 
expectations are set too High to ensure that year end reviews are automatically low and no significant raises are awarded .. tactic in place to save company revenue and keep quarter end profits high.

review_title: DO NOT WORK HERE- HIGH TURNOVER- 60 CALLS per day on the phone..
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: It's inside with AC and some good benefits but other than that this location/ position is horrible. There is only 1 manager there that is good and she has not been there to long to get jaded.
cons: Even if you get the job, if you do not passing training they will fire you and even if you get sick and the DR. said you have to stay home. You will get written up. Management is horrible and they are very abusive with the authority and the ridiculous calls you have to make a day to stay on track is unreasonable. Then you also have to fight with the Outside Rep to prove that you won a deal. For the pay it is not worth moving or working there.  Maybe other places in UPS are good but this is not,  unless you want to come in and apply for outside rep asap and you need a 4 year degree to leave.  MOST people that work there can't wait to leave and the ones stuck are miserable. The environment is so fake and they practically force you to donate to United Way for the company to look good...

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Clinton, MD
pros: As a part-time supervisor at UPS, I probably make more than most of my fellow college students. Despite having to pay for insurance, the cost is almost miniscule. You get 5 days off a year as well as two weeks of vacation starting out which bumps up to three weeks after 5 years. It's a great stepping stone to get into other jobs. I've been considered more heavily for other positions at the company since I have the management experience.
cons: How ever many bad days you have as an hourly employee, multiply that by 5, possibly even 10. It is extremely stressful and demanding. The raises are performance based and you can only do so much as your employees will want to. You aren't guaranteed job security by the union although its still very low-risk. You have to enforce rules and boss people around with practically no authority to do so. I've had employees cuss me out and flip me off to my face and I could do nothing about it except go get a union rep or my boss.

job_title: Package Car Driver in Staten Island, NY
pros:
The best part of my day was the end of the day. 
Health insurance, pension, overall compensation package is better than average.
cons:
I worked at UPS on and off for 8 years, as a seasonal pre-load worker, helper than finally hired full time permanent as a driver. After two years driving and being abused daily by management I had  enough. Management makes the art of delivering packages harder than it is. I understand there are production numbers they want to hit but treating the employee like garbage is not going to achieve those goals. The best advice I was ever given by senior drivers that I did not take was do just enough to get by, nothing more nothing less. I'll never forget the day I realized management cared more about the package car and the packages than they did the driver.

 During an on car ride with my direct supervisor who made my life a living hell for no other reason because I was white (he told me so) and because he could. I walked off the job during my lunch hour and never looked back and couldn't have been happier about my decision.
