review_title: Awful Job, Great Benefits (after a year)
pros:
If you can stick it out for a year you are eligible for one of the best health insurance programs in the country. About the only thing I miss!

Some of the co-workers and supervisors are cool.

They give you 2 weeks off unpaid after 2 years service which is superb for part-time.
cons:
Base pay is poor.

Working conditions inside tractor trailers are very dusty and dirty - no breathing protection provided.

Job is very labor intensive - you will always feel aches and pains, even as a part-timer!

Always picking up the slack of the lazy or crap workers who think they don't need to work hard.

Job is incredibly boring!

review_title: UPS....expectations are high, morale low, benefits OK.
job_title: Senior Admin. Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: With 20 plus years at UPS I am 'grandfathered' into the old pay scale which is average in todays work place.  Medical benefits have decreased and are average.  Getting time off for personal reasons is usually not an issue.
cons: Stress levels are high.  Senior management under pressure to "improve on the  numbers".  This all rolls down hill to whom ever is in it's path.  Supervisor morale is low.  If you're a while male, forget about being promoted past the first level. (Although it stll has the flavor of a good ol' boys club!)  If you don't have a family or can handle stress well.....then check it out.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Louisville, KY
pros: The good things about working at ups is that they have fantastic benefits after you have worked there over a year. Also if you are a student, they have a program called metro college, were they pay your entire school tuition. Also they do have some pretty nice and cool people working with you. To be honest if it wasn't for them paying tuition I would rate this job a 1 star.
cons: The cons can go on almost forever. First and formost, the pay is horrific! During the non-peak seasons. Expect to make a maximum of $140-180 a week for your first couple years. That's mostly due that ups wants you to work the least amount of hours possible. After listening in to some supervisors conversations. The less hours they give there employees, the bigger the raise that supervisor will get. Secoun, the work is hard and boring. Expect to lift heavy packages and get bombarded with bulk shipments. For the 3-4 hours you work a day. It feels like you have worked 5-7 hours.

pros: You will learn a tremendous amount about logistics management, the transportation industry, and 3PL logistics. You can drive your own professional development through portal-based resources. The long term financial rewards are incredible.
cons: Long hours, and working on weekends is expected despite what your hiring manager may tell you during the interview process. Work life balance is not a concern of management, you are expected to be available 24/7/365. There is a well executed annual review, but your performance is not a factor into a raise at all. Your bonus is not tied to your performance, but the performance of UPS as a whole. UPS rarely pays 100% of the bonus. For example, this year UPS only paid out 70% of the bonus potential.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: The only pros I can actually think of are the people you work with and it’s a good resume builder.
cons: Everything is a gimmick here. First of all when they hire you, they make it seem like the greatest experience ever. Wrong. They’ll tell you that you can make $50,000 including commission per year which is the biggest lie I heard. 9/10 you will absolutely not make that much because they make it so hard to actually get commission. They have some dumb way they determine commission and I promise you’ll never understand it. I’m pretty sure it’s like that for a reason. The people making $50,000 have amazing patches that have organic growth. They’ll also tell you they do tuition reimbursement but this is bogus. If you actually have an undergrad degree, you’re out of luck because they don’t reimburse tuition for higher degrees unless you get promoted. Which leads me to the next lie, they tell you that the opportunities are endless for promotions. Not true at all. They have a million stipulations about when and how you’ll get promoted. There are people who have been stuck for years because of this. Don’t work here. Trust me. It’s basically a slave shop.

review_title: Lack of leadership and vision limits professional growth and/or development
job_title: Business Development Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: For the most part, as long as you are semi-competent, employment is almost guaranteed.  It is highly unlikely you will be terminated (unless there is an ethical violation or due to a lack of education/skills they can't keep you in management).
cons: Every upper management person in virtually every function is cut out of the same mould-- all a group of "yes-men/women".  There's very little 'vision' or 'leadership' in this critical group.  In many instances, the 'purpose' of a large scale work project is "because {senior mgmt person} wants to see this"--whether it adds any strategic value to the organization or not.  If you're accomplishing all your goals/tasks, then the feedback is "good job, keep doing what you're doing"...which leads to zero career movement.

pros: I thoroughly enjoyed working as a seasonal driver's helper.  UPS provides the uniform (except for the cap).  It's great exercise, and while you have to be in reasonable shape to do it, it isn't as if you have to be Mr. or Ms. Universe.  And the pay in my area was pretty decent ($10.50 / hr, averaging around 7 hours per day).  Except for one day, I worked with the same driver for the duration.  If you are fortunate enough to work with a nice driver, they really appreciate the help!
cons: At first, I didn't always know if, or where, I would be working.  After a while, though, I stayed with the same driver and our meeting time and place became set.  Also, be mindful of the weather.  The helpers are in and out of the truck constantly, and the trucks are not necessarily toasty warm!  :)  If you work where temperatures can dip, I highly recommend wearing thermal underwear beneath the UPS brown.

review_title: It's all about who you know and your work ethic.
job_title: Part Time Operations Supervisor in Texas City, TX
pros: UPS is one of the best companies I've worked for ever. If you a re looking to be part time this is the place for you. The pay is worth it after some years of hard work and dedication along with the pay and the benefits are amazing. There is no other place I'd rather be than with my UPS family!!!
cons: There are some down falls to working at UPS they work you hard and the hours for preload are hard. I quit every other month, lol only in my mind because I know the benefits and pay out weight the pain and suffering. One day I will become full-time but until then I will stay in school and keep working.

review_title: Good benefits, but you'll need them for how little they care if you're starting on the ground.
job_title: Package Handling/International Clerk in Columbus, GA
pros: Free health insurance, M-F schedule, can be a good workout... or dangerous if you're unhealthy
cons: high pressure/stress environment, lack of regard for the employees on the ground, Center/District management avoids replacing workers who have quit or been terminated in an effort to bolster the "pieces per hour".  This last part usually results in those that are doing the labor to spread themselves thin running between anywhere from 2-5 stations in the warehouse to pick up the slack.  Generally, middle management does not help in these scenarios because they are not allowed to by contract but if you have a good supervisor he will help because upper management simply will not hire anyone else and he see's the effect it has on the employees remaining - even if it is breaking the rules.

review_title: Very corporate environment; not a fit for everyone
pros: If you are motivated to move up and beyond the position you are hired into, opportunities are available, and the company provides ample training and encouragement to do so. Benefits are good. When customers are satisfied enough to offer compliments, there's a great feeling of job satisfaction.
cons: Very performance driven, truly to a fault. Frequent--sometimes even daily--mini-assessments, which were sometimes worded poorly and troublesome for large numbers of employees. Raises were infrequent. Perks to boost moral often seemed patronizing. Contentment with a position at which you excelled was viewed as laziness or complacency, and the encouragement toward advancement became coercion to climb the corporate ladder. Shady, because the holidays are the busy season in the package business, it was made very difficult to take time off to be with family, especially if you needed to travel.

job_title: PACKAGE HANDLER SUPERVISOR SEP in Stone Mountain, GA
pros: Good benefits and the raise is 80 cents to the dollar a year. Weekends off is a plus and paid holidays off are a plus as well.
cons: They work you hard and try to talk to you any kind of way. When I got injured the safety manager took his anger out on me that day since cooperate came in randomly and was on his case for not having completed documents. He did not want to do the required paper work to send to my doctors for workers comp, and he compared me hurting my back to a train professional weight lifter that never got hurt. First off I am not a trained professional weight lifter and my managers push me to be fast when it comes to lifting heavy packages at a high pace in humid temperatures. They wouldn't let me go into plant engineering without being a part time package handler manager even though I just graduated from college.

review_title: Solid job for those inclined to physical labor with great benefits
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Nashville, TN
pros: Teamwork is authentically practiced in Massman Hub, Nashville, TN. If you suit up and show up every day, you will be rewarded over time.  It can be quicker to build trust than most companies.  You really rely on supervisors for guidance and coworkers to help each other load packages well.  This company is forward thinking, but experiences setbacks in the global business sector.
cons: Hard work.  No way around it.  It hurts when you get home after lifting over 1,000 packages a night.  Joints and muscles will ache.  Go buy some good gloves for lifting, and some ibuprofen because these things are necessities.

pros: Get paid for a workout!  Continuously in and out of the truck.  Offers potential for permanent employment. Get to know local businesses and discover neighborhoods. No set schedule but estimated times if you ask your driver.  (Same driver, same route each day)
cons: Only worked 3 hours per day except week of Christmas.  No set schedule but must be available and on call.  Advertised as part time but it is 5 days a week and only 3 hours per day.  Must wait for driver to call when ready for assistance.  Only uniform piece is a terrible vest that says "Seasonal Help" across the back.  Should be paid more for the amount of work they expect from a vest wearing seasonal helper!  Working in the elements.

pros: Decent pay if you can stick it out for a while, benefits are good. Some good people that work there that make it worth it.
cons: Lots of people call in "sick" every shift, management is disorganized, hard to move up in the company, massive turnover rate due to hard working conditions, constantly hounded to improve PPH (packages per hour) rate or else you'll be threatened with a write up.  General poor working conditions a majority of the time that doesn’t get resolved. Constantly under staffed which makes work harder for everyone there, which is directly related to why turnover rate is so poor. Batteries for scanners were constantly an issue, broken scanners as well. For a billion dollar company you would think broken equipment wouldn't be an issue.

review_title: We don't know what we are doing
pros: Benefits are good, few part time employers offer insurance, ups offers 100% free coverage if you can survive a year.
cons: Over the top physical demands, but only for certain employees, some of the people don't pull their weight.  Managment is critical of the people that work really hard but doesn't offer suggestions or help or improve.  Supervisors and employees feel like they are on opposite sides.  Supervisors stand around and talk and don't do any work while employees are breaking their back.  Two people on the sort line in Casper, WY doing killer work bleeding and sweating while supervisors stare at them and drink beverages.

job_title: Package Car Driver in York, PA
pros: UPS is serious about making sure its employees are working safely and fully qualified for the job. Too soon to tell if I will be pleased yet or not. Best rated benefits, pay and reputation in the industry.
cons: If you want to be a delivery driver, you will go thru a week long training program that has a surprisingly low graduation rate. I passed and now I'll be working part time early mornings, sorting packages at a much lower rate of pay than I need, until there's an opportunity to advance. Will definitely have to take another job to make ends meet, in case this doesn't pan out.

pros:
As a preloader, it was like getting paid to work out every morning.  
Steady hourly wage raises.  
Promoted safety with employee incentives (food, gifts)
cons:
Union job.. only promote from time spent and hard work won't allow you to move up.  
I would have actually stayed with the company forever except once you transfer facilities, your seniority resets to 0, putting that much further from driving (where you make the big bucks).  I lived in Cincinnati, Ohio and am eventually moving to St. Louis, Missouri where my family resides but due to the resetting in seniority, my already three years of seniority would have proven to be worthless.

job_title: Operational Manager, Overnight Air Ops Louisville KY in Louisville, KY
pros: Extremely well run company. Most management moves up from within. They know the job being done by those they are responsible for. Large enough that special skill and educational positions can be filled from within. Operational management highly motivated to achieve goals and standards necessary to provide a good wanted product, and make a profit. Conservative, cautious. I doubt they make many big moves that have not been thoroughly dissected. My guess is they have a great deal of money in reserve.
cons: Hooked at the hip to fuel costs. Have to deal with teamsters union whose time has come and gone. Beyond that, the same drag put on every corporation in this country by over regulation, an out of control healthcare system. The remarkable, creative way our government finds better and better ways to stretch a buck. No laughin...!!!

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Hartford, CT
pros: Enjoyable, straightforward, brisk-paced work, but with a focus on safe, reasonable pace. If you can get a full-time permanent position with them, you can expect to do very well. No work on weekends.
cons: Repeatedly made polite inquiries to HR as to whether assistance would be needed for each of two next helper seasons (Summer vacations and winter holiday season) to HR reps in two different states. Never received any reply, even though I politely asked for a callback either way, just so I would know what to plan for. It seems that, at least at those two locations, they won't give you the courtesy of a response unless they need your help. On another note, the hours run into the early evening, so your family's quality of life may suffer.

review_title: Stable company with heavy workload and friendly colleagues and open door policy.
pros: Salary is ok. Solidarity among same level colleagues makes you feel quickly part of a team. Although work procedures are pretty well thought out you still are given room to implement improvements. The company forces you to think in solutions at minimum costs which in turn calls on you using your creativity. It's a place where you can be yourself. As long as the numbers are in the green you can do whatever you want.
cons: Every penny must be justified up to the craziest detail and needs approval by to many managers makes the company very bureaucratic. Some warehouses have very questionable working conditions with minimal maintenance. A lot of hard manual labour leads to relatively high absenteeism. Very top down oriented military style management is more and more being implemented by corporate (us).

pros: You work with some really cool people
cons:
The work is VERY tiring and stressful. UPS doesn't give a damn about their employees, they will lie to your face constantly to get whatever they want. They once drop all of the part-timers pay by almost 25% without telling anyone. Their way of letting us know our pay was going down significantly was showing us our weekly pay checks about $150 less than usual. When the employees inevitably got pissed and there was a lot of talk about leaving UPS starting saying how the pay is going back up to our usual amount. After multiple weeks of our pay not going back up a lot of people were talking about leaving again so UPS said that not only is our pay going back up, but we are getting re-imbursed for our lower pay. That settled everyone but then jUPS reimbursed us for one single week before our pay went back to normal. They just got away with cutting all of our checks for two months with all their bull crap.
They lie about things all the time to get their employees to work/ continue to work for them because they don't give a crap about us.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Denver, CO
pros: ???  I honestly cannot think of any right now, but it is probably because my brain and body are fried from being severely overworked and under rested
cons:
Mislead about hours: "part time" 3rd shift is actually 11pm- 10 am, 6 days a week. With, 1 10 minute break, sometimes 2 10 minute breaks. Zero over exaageration. Fact: 12 hour shift of constant hard labor (lifting and stacking huge boxes up to 80 lbs NON STOP) and we usually get 10 minutes for a break.
I was told no weekends, and lo and behold, saturdays are a must, if you want the 200 weekly bonus- which is the only thing that makes the job even worthwhile, because without that, it is not worth it.

job_title: Part Time Operations Manager in Easton, PA
pros: health insurance is cheap if your single and a non smoker (if you smoke they will take $50 a week out for tobacco usage, and adding children and spouses can eat up a lot of your already slim paycheck.
cons: Dirty, dingy, and hazardous workplace. They only try and run the minimum amount of hours needed to sort and handle the estimated volume to sort and process, so  you will be lucky if you work more than 6 hours average a day usually closer to 5.5 hrs a day. They claim safety is their #1 priority but the reality is getting done on time and making their pull times trumps safety (They will turn their heads when they need to as long as it maintains production) Full time management runs like a dictatorship and they are more willing to criticize then mentor and train you to be a better leader.  Gross yearly income before taxes is around 35k with a 4 yr degree and working OT.

review_title: Stay away. Much better opportunities out there
pros: Not much anymore. I'm pretty hard pressed to find anything good. Pay is decent but not enough for the soul selling they expect you to do. You can make close to the same or even more somewhere with less hours and less high school drama.
cons: 12-15 hours days, 90% of managment are liars, thieves and cheats.  Lots if back stabbing. At least 10 of my employees were threatened to hide accidents and Injuries.  Over worked, to red and injured employees get harassed if you call in an injury. The amount of money vs the hours is not great at all. It looks good at first but then you realize it's taking away your life and making you a miserable person. Took me 2 days to find a job making the same amount for 40 hours vs 70 a week.. STAY AWAY.

review_title: Work safe, do not misload, learn the safety questions and be thick skinned.
pros: UPS is solid financially, the benefits are very good. I was fortunate to be trained by someone who was very knowledgeable which makes me very good at my job.
cons:
References to light building volume by part time and full time supervisors which are not relevant to my particular area. Directing us to work outside our area for half an hour to an hour daily and then refusing to take that into consideration when computing our production numbers. 

New hires now seem to be put into a job without sufficient training. As the end of the shift gets closer and these new hires are having trouble getting done, their supervisor just yells at them to go faster. What has happened to the supervisors who  knew the job and how to lead and instruct people?

pros: The potential for a fulltime position and benefits
cons:
- No breaks, at all. Even if you were promised you'd get breaks.
- Having to complete the work of others.
- Not being recognized for the work you do.
- How educated or experienced you are, does not matter.
- Part-time employees may work full time hours but do not get any respect or always do the work no one wants to.
- If you happen to work for ups. through a temp agency, good luck, you will not get paid what was promised. HR will lie in order to hire people.
- No benefits for a while.
- Lack of job potential.
- Out dated systems from the 1980's, packages are often lost because of old software being used.
- Packages are damaged and kept hidden or destroyed in order to avoid the delivery.

review_title: Didn’t take ups for con men
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Sarasota, FL
pros: If you love being cheated out of holiday 3 weeks of holiday bonuses, this is the job for you
cons: Absolutely no communication from lower supervisors to higher management. No one has any idea what they’re doing at the 17th Street hub in Sarasota. We get paid less than ten dollars after taxes an hour to do a literal drivers job. Never told anyone that the Xmas bonuses stopped for three weeks. Yet convieniently kept saying, “just a few more days, and they’ll be in on your next paycheck”. Well it’s january and I’ve been paid nothing I’ve been owed. Being promised and then conned into a bad position for pennies on the dollar of what the work is worth

review_title: A place where all dreams perish
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
-Great part time job to complement school schedule
-Working at UPS looks good on a resume, shows strong work ethic 
-Benefits are outstanding for a part time job but this doesn't really matter for people who only stay there a year or two
-They'll promote almost anyone to part-time supervisor but good luck getting any promotions after that
cons:
-Monotonous work, sorting basically same packages from same companies every day
-Pay is low compared to other warehouse jobs (Amazon, Fedex)
-2nd shift, usually starts around 5 (except Mondays are way earlier)
-New hub opened nearby so hours getting cut
-Management trys to play favorites but thankfully seniority trumps that
-You have to pay union dues out of your paycheck and all the union does is protect the laziest workers on the planet from being fired 
-A few awesome co-workers help pass time, but others are unbearable to even be around
-very, very boring work

pros: The ability to work this as a second job at night or early morning. They will pay $25,000 lifetime for education. Also, this is a union job with health benefits after a year. After working here, you will be in shape and they care about safety. It is a workout. They will hire you off the street with zero experience.
cons: They move you around too much, and that makes it hard for you to get good at your job. Being treated like an interchangeable part of a machine that just lifts and loads packages as fast as possible is not enjoyable. You sometimes work with no idea what you will be doing on any given day.

pros: Its a good physical workout and it is good for your body
cons: Management will lie to you to get you into a job that no one will take. Its 6 hours of work that they make you get done in 4. The faster you work the less hours you get the next week. This union shop treats the hardest working people in the hub like carp. Management will lie to you to get you on board and they are always hiring to many people because no one will stay. I would not recommend this company. To anyone for any reason. They will work you like a prisoner and short you on your hours and provide you with all the disrespect you can take

review_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Redmond, WA ( near Seattle )
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Redmond, WA
pros:
1) Active job, moving all the time, see interesting neighborhoods
2) Only work weekdays, late morning, afternoon, early evening
3) Located fairly close to home
4) Friendly driver who knows the route
5) The UPS training ( 5 hours ) was very good, with lots of good tips on safety and how to
deliver packages.
cons:
1) Minimum wage, so this will help pay some bills
2) Only 7 weeks
3) Can be wet and rainy.  Also, in the late afternoon and evening, dark, so a flashlight or headlamp
is recommended.
IMPORTANT NOTE - Do not take this job unless you are fit.  There is a lot of walking and climbing
in and out of the truck.  Fast paced, with potential for injury if you are not careful.  Many people sign up for this position, but according to my driver, few make it though to the end because the job is physically demanding.

review_title: The pay and benefits are good but there is absolutely no work/life balance at UPS.
job_title: Part Time Package Center Supervisor in Spartanburg, SC
pros: The compensation is good.  The benefits are good.  There is something to be said for working at a company as respected as UPS.  Also, it is very secure.  What little promotion occurs happens from within the company.
cons: Intense, intense, intense.  Extreme pressure.  Have you ever been screamed at, swore at, called names by your manager.  That is an average day in operations at UPS.  Absolutely no work/life balance.  All of the managers are either single or divorced.  Promotions are rare.

review_title: Don't Waste Your Time Working For UPS
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Miami, FL
pros:
Benefits only, nothing else to say
Hours aren't bad either
cons: You are allowed 5 discretionary days a year and your "Manager" has a hard time allowing you to take the time off. They promote who they want to promote even if your education background surpasses what it "Required". They claim you need a college degree but there are "Full Time Supervisors" with absolutely no degrees, SMH LOL. UPS upper management has No Respect for their part time supervisors, we are belittled infront of hourly employees and under-minded as well. The "Union" protects the houlry employee no matter how wrong they are, you can get fired 100 times and still keep your job unless you get caught stealing. Stop forcing your employees to give to "United Way" if a person does not want to give then they don't have to, If they was more then employees would give more.

review_title: Honesty to the most for a company i truly loved before i found out.
job_title: Territory Account Executive in Atlanta, GA
pros: you do not need to produce to get paid. you could be the laziest person on earth and if you get a job at UPS and did not violate the protocol and rules you are guaranteed the job even if you are NOT producing a dime.
cons: company is not consistent in applying their own set rules when appreciating customers or even employees. too much routine because of the big corporation that make the company lose the efficiency of speed which is the purpose and main core of the business. Very similar to a government traditions and management. Lots of LIARS in management.

review_title: Not suggested. At least not this building.
job_title: Package Handler/Delivery Driver Helper in Latham, NY
pros: Driver rate is pretty decent for required knowledge and skills. Will definitely work during peak season. Union will have your back though it is losing its influence.
cons: Treated like trash. Good work is rewarded with more work/higher expectations. Work done is not worth the rate of pay. Cannot handle peak season(mid Nov-early Jan). This building was the second worst UPS in the country for handling the last peak season. Work loads are nowhere near equal(even taking age, health, area etc. into consideration). You will need surgery or have movement issues if you plan to stay until retirement(I personally acquired arthritis by 25).  Management doesn't even follow their own rules until they're being watched by the union. Ten year waiting list minimum until full-time spots open up. Safety first is a lie. Package Handlers make terrible money/hours. Hard to find twenty words for the pros minimum requirement.

pros: Stability and consistency are advantages here.  While the total compensation is not as competitive as other firms, layoffs are almost unheard of and many people work here their whole career.
cons: Total Compensation is competitive with other large corporations.  However, management bonuses make up a much larger percentage (34% bonus for mgrs, and for 17% sups)  of your total compensation then average .  At first this sounds like a good thing, but half of your bonus is frozen for five years while the half you get is taxed at a high rate.   Also, remember that Total Compensation is in line with other companies means you get less money in your pocket.  Essentially what UPS is able to do is shift your compensation into your bonus which they can defer till the end of the year for the first half, and out five more years for the second half.

pros: Was promised good pay and union benefits thats the reason i applied
cons: This place was terrible i was going to be a seasonal driver, all the supervisors and managers are very very nasty people, the training was horrible,i was put under extreme pressure on my first day of training on the truck was expected to work like i had been a 20 year employee for them not like i just started working there, then when we got back to the center a supervisor called me in and interrogated me asking of the supervisor i was working with hit a parked car threatening if i lied i would be fired ,why would you ask me its my first day i was not driving and no i did not see him hit a parked car or hear any kind of accident, do not work here they will treat you like a slave, and plus senior drivers are treated like royalty

pros:
-Fulltime benefits for part-time work 
-Union
-Two weeks paid vacation paid vacation and two discretionary days  after a year
-During their busy season no cap on overtime
-Your entitled to 60% of your regular income for FMLA, or maternity leave
cons:
-Forced overtime if they are running behind, regardless of your obligations, if you leave its considered job abandonment 
-They keep supervisors who have a history of harassment
-Because of the union, any issue you have with management can take up to three months to resolve 
-Heavy workload, quotas that you have to meet
-Low retention, always understaffed the amount they expect you to complete is ridiculous
-No respect from management, they don't motivate they just yell
-If you're a good worker they use you to fix problems in other work areas with problem employees 
-The wait time to be a full time in the warehouse is 11 years+
-Pay is low for the amount of work and crap you have to put up with
-Management has little care for work-life balance

review_title: Ok for now. Not great. Not horrible.
pros: Security (for now). Though there seems to be movement to outsource IS functions. If you are performer chances are you will be trusted and left alone.
cons: Bureacracy which is found in larger organizations. Too much rah rah and emphasis on stock ownership which should be a personal choice. Promotions not always fair. I was passed over for promotion even though I had more experience and education than the person promoted. That person was good friends with the promoting manager. So they like to talk the line that they are fair, in actuality they are no different from other firms. IS has too many people and I can see more downsizing.. they do not call it layoffs. But it has happened in IS. Its called elimination of a functional area and people have to find jobs elsewhere or take a package which is never that great.

pros:
* Tution assistance
* The work is so stressful you build a great bond between coworkers.
* UPS does a geat job giving back to the community
cons:
*No time of during Christmas season
* Union is a cancer to this company, it only serves as protection for the worst employees
*Union employees arebetter compensated then the people who manage them
*The hours managment work are unheard of at other companies. 65-70+ hours a week isnt uncommon for an On-Car Supervisor.

job_title: Part Time Operations Supervisor in Commerce City, CO
pros: Pay is good, but I have been there a long time. Your fellow employees are good to work with. It is a union environment so that has pros and cons.
cons: High stress workplace without proper training to do your job. You are just thrown into a job and expected to get the hang of it, improve, or get the heck out. They have done so many staffing cutbacks in the past several years that it makes the job very intense because you are doing the work of a couple people and need to get it done in 5.5 hours. There is very little room for advancement to full-time- it is either work 5.5 hours or give your life to UPS. Every full timer I know works at least 14 hours a day- I dont think there is a normal 8-10 hour job at UPS at my facility.

pros:
Full-time medical benefits for part-time work
Good place to work as long as you stay within the Union
Good workout
Job security

Bottom line is that UPS is a good place to work while you are in school because they not only offer you full medical benefits for part-time work, but they also assist you in paying for school. If I could go back and do it again, I would have stayed hourly in the Union.
cons:
Lots of politics when it comes to getting promoted from within
Most part-time supervisor jobs aren't worth the stress
They could treat full-time and part-time supervisors better

Bottom line here to is not expect to go anywhere big in the company unless you know the right people. They don't really seem to look at the time, effort, and commitment that individuals such as myself have invested in the company. The full-time supervisors that I've had over the years have been nothing short of great, but I can't say the same for all the higher levels of management I've worked under.

job_title: Package Handler in Maple Grove, MN
pros: If you work hard, you will remain hired.  Finishing work at about 9:00 AM leaves the whole rest of your day free.  UPS makes it tough to receive funding for school but if you're on top of things, they'll pitch in.
cons: Working in preload wears your body out.  If you work hard, you will be taken advantage of and won't be able to move up due to being in a union.  Hours are very early, especially towards the end of the year.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler/Sorter in Vernon, CA
pros: Good pay. Medical, dental and vision.
cons: Management will shave time off your time card to meet production numbers. My hours worked were being shaved off on a weekly basis so that the full time lead could meet his production numbers. Also when I moved to a skill position of sorter I was supposed to get a dollar raise. Never got the dollar because when I took the sort test they never certified me on my methods on sorting so I never got the dollar. The only way to get paid properly is to grievence issues with the union because management won't listen to you. I work at the Grande Vista hub and our full time lead has been cooking the books with our hours worked and management just seems to look the other way.

pros:
-Solid structured job
-Good job security if you actually work
-Excellent benefits
cons:
-No airconditioning in the warehouses and lack of airflow.  If you load/unload it's pretty brutal. Fortunately I didn't do either; but still walking through their it was crazy hot / cold at times.

-Lack of room to grow. I came in as a supervisor but after a few years and consistently "excellent" reviews it just never seemed like there was an opportunity to proceed to the next level. 

-The union positions vs direct UPS employees battles were awful.  As a non-union employee if I even touched a package the union steward would immediately cry about it. One time I recall seeing a package getting destroyed because it got caught in the belt system so I jumped to try to save it. That resulted in a formal sit down and discussion with the union on how sometimes doing the right thing for the customer is more important.

review_title: Bustness Account Manager for Middle Market Accounts
pros: Help customers understand their shipping needs.  Help customers with Global Growth and Market branding for their company.
cons: involveLimited mobility for certain areas and Compensation not fair to areas that are depressed.  As an account manager you are not able to make top money because no matter how hard you work your area is losing market share. So you are working doubly hard and making no bonus while someone in another progressive are where there is GROWTH is making top money.  Not saying  those individuals aren't working to earn but it isn't fair over all.  Too many variables  that NO ONE seems to be able to explain.  I'd rather get my FULL PAY  and not worry about bonus compensation cause it clearly isn't fair.

pros: Good exercise and fast paced environment that had good benefits and was unionized. A free crayon when you start. Great job if you can handle it and you can meet a lot of people who also get hired.
cons: If you get stuck at the south building. Management cared more about money than workers. They say they care about mental health, but when a concern is brought up nothing is done. Nothing was ever their fault, always the employees. Never saw higher management in the building, yet they made the shot calls that made no sense. Winters are unique cause you might be stuck in the building with about 60+ running propane vehicles. Summers get hot and all they had when I quit was a few large fans moving air, but when you were hot enough that you almost passed out, that's on you. If you move slowly at any point, you'll fall behind and then receive no support because it was your fault. Stressful work environment that can force people to quit.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Working for a world-class, industry leading company that accomplishes the impossible on a daily basis.  Strong career opportunities once you get to mainstream UPS.  Majority of employees are there for the long run.
cons: Paperwork issues, as with many big companies there are so many reports going on from above you that you are constantly being asked to answer silly questions.  In the division I work for, Inside Sales we are sometimes viewed as the red-headed stepchildren to the "real" sales force in the field.  Our compensation is somewhat below par for the level of responsibility and there is an unfortunate lack of accountability for results which allows subpar employees to stay around.  It is nearly impossible to get fired even when you cannot handle your job.  They have recently added channels by which you can move from Inside Sales to mainstream UPS but the opportunities are too few and far between.

pros: None, Training is poor.  Numbers and share holders is all the company cares about no longer a customer service oriented or driven company.  Big named companies are allowed to do what ever they want when shipping with company and little shippers are held to rules.
cons: You are not protected like you are under union.  Your benefits get smaller and smaller to show a profit every year.  The rules need to be the same in the company and not the good old boy club, or favoritism for people.  The rules need to be enforced more evenly.

pros: I enjoyed the workout I got each morning and the friendliness and helpfullness of my co-workers.
cons: Employees are treated like GARBAGE if they are not part of the union. Workers can join the union after 30 days, and during that waiting period workers are treated like trash by their supervisors who are rarely any help. Ask them for help and they will stand in your way and write on their clipboard and have you sign papers covering their complaints on work quality. Workers do not get properly trained at UPS. To keep your job at UPS you MUST join the union. Meaning you have to PAY YOUR HARD EARNED MONEY if you want to keep your job. I have worked pre-load and for those considering a driver position at UPS, drivers I have met have done nothing but complain about the company and the micromanagement they have put up with. This company does NOT deserve anyone's time or hard work until they fix the problems with the lazy and unattentative supervisors and staff.

pros: Compensation, benefits, outside work, knowing that I am giving the sole responsibility on a daily basis to achieve a certain task and goals. The pay is probably the best in the industry and you can't beat the workplace atmosphere., especially if you have a rural route where you get to see alot of the country. UPS pays for our health and welfare ang generally the coverage is good. It is one of the only jobs I know of where you are giving a set amount of work at 9 am and told to git-r-done and do not have to watch the clock till 5 pm. You run your route and when your finished (sometimes after 9pm) you take it home.
cons: Long hours, very demanding goals, hard to get days off  , or get off early for family events such as childrens programs, graduations, an occasional childs sporting event ect.

review_title: Good pay but no regard  for the individual!!!
job_title: On Road Supervisor in Sylmar, CA
pros: Good pay, great vacation time, very secure company. Used to be a great company that treated it's management as a Partner in the organization.  Large diverse corporation with plenty of career choices.
cons: In 2010 the corporation downsized the number of district within the US from 46 to 20. They offered early retirement options for some, but most of the management did not take it.  Which left people being demoted to lesser jobs through out the company.  Since this happened the pressure to perform has been outrageous!!!  The goals and expectations are not even realistic and everybody is just miserable.  14 hour days are the norm and you never hear anything positive only the negative. Ive worked here for over 20 years and loved the people and the company, But now I wouldn't wish this job on my worst enemy.

review_title: Why Hire if you don't have the work?
pros: Drivers were good to work with.  Pay could have been decent if work was available.
cons: No Hours, Poor Communication, Misleading Orientation.  As a seasonal driver helper,  I was told to expect 20-30 hours per week.  I was called for the first time 7 days after orientation and told to be ready to work.  I met the driver on time, finished the route with him in 2 hours, went the next day, took 4 hours, then didn't get a call till the end of the next week.  They call you, spend the money to onboard you, then don't give you the hours to make it worthwhile.

review_title: One of the better corporations to work for!
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Cleveland, OH
pros: People have a lot of negativity towards corporations but UPS is probably one of the better ones out there. It offers both Union and Non-Union work, management career opportunities, sales opportunities, and driving opportunities. I am a Union employee at an air-hub where I put in 3 hours a night and get full health, dental, and partial eye care coverage after a year. There is also 401k opportunities as well. The Drivers have really good careers made out of UPS. When there are employees who've worked 10-20-30+ years in the company it is a good sign.
cons: When you're Union, you are somewhat restricted from transferring or moving up to different facilities or work due to being in a specific Union (package handlers). You have to take the risk of quitting your current job to pick up a different one.

pros: They pay for you to go to college, great benefits after a year of work. I've met some pretty cool people working here.
cons: They only pay full tuition if you are in state. I go to IUS in Indiana and they only cover a certain dollar figure every year of a little more than $5,000. IUS is a cheap school, but they won't pay full tuition, but they will pay UofL's high tuition in full because it's in state. You don't get your insurance or vacation until you've been their for at least a full calendar year, and they offer new employees bonuses on their checks for joining when they need people to work but never give the existing employees anything. The third shift life sucks and you will miss a lot of stuff with friends and family throughout the week.

pros: The benefits, school reimbursement, flexible hours
cons: The treatment from most managers is as if you are an animal. You are “commanded”, never asked. Even the best employees will be ridiculed as a “joke”. Women and the elderly will receive easier jobs, even though in training they will state UPS treats everyone the same. If you get an “easy” position, you will last a long time. If you get a difficult position, they expect to burn you out and hire your replacement when you’re fed up.  I’ve seen several verbal alterations and been told of numerous physical altercations. Unless you have an easy position or are looking to do this temporarily, it’s not worth the hassle. A Fast food job would treat you better for about the same pay.

job_title: Service Provider in New York, NY
pros: Salary, benefits (subjective to whatever teamster local you belong to),  stability.
cons:
Not enough of a emphasis on safety.  Company does not practice what they preach.  

Unwanted overtime, low morale, out of touch and inexperienced management, lack of compassion, extreme micromanagement.  

Constant harassment for the sake of greed.  

The environment and corporate culture do not allow your ambition to flourish.

job_title: Sunrise Pre Loader in Hodgkins, IL
pros: I worked there only a few months before I hurt myself outside of work.  UPS did everything to keep me but my doctor refused to let me back to work as I injured myself pretty badly.  Because my doctors assistant never gave him my Disability papers to fill out so UPS could hire me back on in a different position they had to let me go. It is a great place to work but know you will work hard. Even though the pay was $10/hr you get all your weekends and holidays off unless you want overtime. I worked the Sunrise shift so I got off work at 9 AM and did not go back to work until 4 AM Monday morning. It was awesome getting out of work while all my friends were just getting into work on Friday. Do not be afraid of hard work. There are payoffs in a different way.
cons: I honestly have nothing bad to say about UPS-CACH

job_title: Sunrise Pre Loader in Hodgkins, IL
pros: I worked there only a few months before I hurt myself outside of work.  UPS did everything to keep me but my doctor refused to let me back to work as I injured myself pretty badly.  Because my doctors assistant never gave him my Disability papers to fill out so UPS could hire me back on in a different position they had to let me go.
