cons: I honestly have nothing bad to say about UPS-CACH

review_title: Once great company and place to work, now so focused on stock price that have lost what made it great.
job_title: Senior Account Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Security, market leader, great brand, it is great if you want a job where you only have to do what you are told and not think for yourself. Cameraderie
cons: Tremendous pressure to meet numbers. Big Brother is watching you at all times. Micromanagement. Cultural acceptance of mediocrity. Corporate humility is great as a community citizen, but not as a public company. Do not manage investor relations well at all. Gong public was the worst thing that ever happened to UPS. Management used to be very focused on five years down the line but now focused on current stock price.

review_title: Long hours, sore backs, empty wallets.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Redmond, WA
pros: Very hands on job, part of one of the biggest customer service processes in the world. Good opprotunities and benefits once you really establish yourself. Great workout.
cons: Hourly pay is pretty low for the amount of labor put in. Management relies too much on the package handlers and thus becomes visibly upset at workers who really didn't do anything wrong. Also, attempts to solve problems by using logistical figures instead of common sense and real life scenarios. New benefits package kicks in after 6 months of working and one year for family. When economy tanks, job security is low and minimal hours are worked. To solve overtime problems, they hire dozens of seasonal help to help handle the winter workload but seasonal help is clueless and inexperienced so it ends up being more of a problem.

review_title: The Buddy System at it's BEST
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Houston, TX
pros: There are none, and if you found some let me know, who you paid off. The only thing I liked about the job is some of the friendships I gained.
cons: If you are not drinking buddies with upper management ( Hub manager or above.) Or don't suck up. Or not related to somebody in upper management. YOU WILL NEVER BE PROMOTED. There promotion process is a joke. You take a test with multiple choice and math questions, only one right answer but 2 people grade your paper seperately. That place is one the downward spiral and they did it to themselves. Steer clear of UPS' management jobs. There is suppose to be a supervisor go driving every 6 driver job openings automaticely but they don't fill the positions and when they do its only with their friends.

review_title: It's a great place to work if you can handle it.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Gainesville, FL
pros: The people were really cool, everybody understood that we were there to work. The supervisors really cared about you as a person and were interested in your growth. The pay is great and the benefits are better.
cons:
It's really early and the work is really, really hard. Lifting packages can be painful and if you're not careful you could get seriously hurt. Cuts and bruises are very common, and if you get hurt too often or are too clumsy then this might not be the job for you. 

If you work a belt system then you have to move very quickly and things can get backed up if you're not careful and play it smart. Watch your load charts, map it out in your head before the sort starts and try your best to stick to your plan but remember toe xpect the unexpected.

Really sucks when you get those three overweight hazards that mess you up halfway through things.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Ashland, MA
cons:
•  Starting pay is $11.00/hour (minimum wage in MA). Competitors advertise higher starting wages, but after speaking with several current and former employees, I chose to not pursue employment with them. (I had an offer from one, but declined based on reports of company culture.)
•  Injuries. They’re going to happen. (People + companies ship the darnedest things!) But your adherence to safety rules can mean the difference between a minor injury or a major one: choose wisely.
•  Not climate controlled. Trucks back into an open loading dock, so the weather outside greatly influences the climate inside. But think of it this way: It’s an excellent conditioning opportunity for you! And hydrate, hydrate, hydrate! <-- This should be your new motto.
•  If you’re looking for an intellectually stimulating position, this job isn’t it. However, it does get your foot in the door to advance into roles that will provide that type of opportunity.
•  You learn to never ship high-tech items, such as TVs, monitors, and computers. Just don’t do it. No, seriously, people. Don’t. Do. It.

review_title: Fair Pay for Thankless, Hard Work
pros: Pay was pretty great compared to many similar employment options. Lots of overtime hours make for huge paychecks during peak. Free swag passed out from time to time.
cons: Overtime hours are not optional, you will be expected to work until the job is done, possibly 70+ hrs at peak. The work is very physical and turnover is very rapid.  Pressure to meet demand cause management to turn a blind eye toward safe or smart work, only caring about speed.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Toronto, ON
pros: For a part time it's pretty good, get benefits, tuition assistance, experience with recognizable big company.  Their Always hiring so if you need a job quick and temporary it's good choice if you don't mind sweating a lot. You can also move up or around different positions if your looking for long term options.
cons: Ups will push you to your breaking point at times with the physicality and mental strain, feels like a workload and half. Everyone tolerates it differently but no one escapes the wrath at Ups. Other then that I call the environment organized chaos because everyone is being pushed that you have Forseen errors or people not do what they should that cause chain reactions we all have to adapt to finish the work on time. It's a warehouse so there's people talking and joking trying to make the time better mostly good but some love to talk smack about each other in a negative way, which depends on people but the environment contributes.

review_title: Good benefits, a reliable yet small paycheck, extreme criticism & stress, management by intimidation.
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: Great benefits and a reputable company that delivers a superior product and that isn't going away.
cons: Poor pay.  Incompetent management.  Ever changing "plans" to help you get ahead.  Unrealistic demands.  Lack of integrity regarding internal reporting.  Unreasonable rules that work well in outside sales headquartered in the UPS centers but totally irrelevant to the Inside Sales environment.  Questionable promotions.  Failure to prepare promoted individuals for their new jobs.  No opportunity to allow new employees to consult with the people they are replacing.  Threatening employees jobs if they fail to meet multiple unrealistic expectations.  Having employees sign documents stating that they recognize all their shortcomings and that if they fail to meet expectations they will be terminated.  Time wasted in meetings and consultations with management that take the ISR away from their job.  Worst job I've ever had.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: This is a good start as an entry level sales job, but with recent restructuring and consolidation of positions there are less growth opportunities available. UPS has great health benefits, and this role allows you to have a work/life balance because you don’t get emails or calls from home. However, if you are looking for a more flexible work environment be aware that although the job is salary, you have a “clock in/clock out time” to meet. They do offer time off coupons which is really helpful.
cons: Less promotional opportunities in Greenville because they recently consolidated two promoted roles into one role. No work from home options. No paternity leave. If you don’t like making phone calls this job is not for you. It can be challenging to hit certain goals depending on which territory you are assigned to.

review_title: UPS a great place to work, unless you want to have a family or a life.
pros: UPS provides a very steady secure job, if you are not the lowest guy on the hourly totem pole.  If you can get on board, keep your head tucked down, and do your basic job you don't have to worry about getting fired, layed off, or otherwise be out of work.
cons: Once you get into management (including Part Time Management) you can expect to spend more time dedicated to UPS than your own family.  UPS is much like the military with it's assignments.  You are told where to be and when to be there, and you don't have much of a choice.  If they need some help in another building several hundred miles away, you're told to go and help.  It doesn't really matter if you have committments with your family, you go.

review_title: The job is extremely stressful but if you have good time management and assertivesness skills, you will be fine.
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Chicago, IL
pros: Professional Growth, Great benefits along with 3% match in 401 k plan, Great training, Looks great on your resume, Great workout.
cons: Stressful, Loud, Depressing (No windows, Dim lighting), 101 ways to get hurt if not careful(even if you are cautious, you are still likely to be injured in some form or way), Weather conditions outside are the same inside but worse (100 degrees outside= 120 degrees inside, 0 degrees outside=      -20 inside), long exhausting hours.

review_title: Great place to build your skills and resume and then leave
pros: UPS provides great entry level management opportunities.  WIth relative ease one can achieve p/t management promotion and begin to develop skills that will assist you as you transition into your career.
cons: UPS expects p/t supervisors to permanently stay in their positions.  Many employees are lured out of the union into p/t supervisor status only to discover years later that this was an unwise choice.  If you have no desire of attending college do not accept a p/t supervisor position as this will almost certainly guarantee that you remain a p/t employee indefinitely.  Also, many high seniority union employees make terrific wages while f/t management receives mediocre compensation juxtaposed to the extended hours (60 +) work weeks they endeavor.

pros:
Great school fro work benefit for undergraduate (when working 3rd shift)!  Highly recommend for all high school graduates to consider the sacrifice of 3rd shift part-time work to get your Bachelors Degree paid for!
Overall, the management and supervisory team are supportive and have a passion for the business as well as your professional development.  There are a ton of possible areas to work within (more than just getting the boxes to and from customers).  The sky can be the limit, for a rewarding career.
cons: Some lengthy time involved with growing in a role towards promotion (but it depends on area and the supply/ demand equation for positions).  Dress Code is somewhat dated as compared to current acceptable society norms/ standards.  Some areas are better to work in than others (as with any corporation = it is really your direct supervisors that create the culture and experience).

pros: Great benefits and the ability to buy into the company.  The jobs are stable without the fear of being laid off.  Great resume builder working for a company as large and well known as UPS.
cons: Very slow movement within the company and if you are looking for promotions other than operations be prepared to wait 5-12yrs. Those in the manager roles stay there because they are comfortable which causes those just coming in the company the inability for advancement.

review_title: If you want a life - DONT
job_title: Driver Service Provider in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Regular drivers are decent lads and will help you however they can.
cons:
Integrad..... Like military school. Uniform inspections, polished boots, shirts ironed and must have sharp creases that would shave a hairy man in 20 seconds..

The job itself..... Long long hours, management don't give a crap how long you work for once you deliver every single parcel and pick up every request that's sent to you regardless of where you are on your route.... If you do 100 stops you'll be expected to do 110 the next day, without any thanks or recognition, but beware the day you can't complete all your stops.... You'll be hauled over hot coals to demand answers as to why you failed the company and didn't deliver everything... 

I lasted 2 months with this and left as soon as I found another job. 
Management will big up the company, the job etc but if you are seriously considering a position here find a driver and ask them what they really think as they will tell you the truth... 

Money is also rubbish for the hours you are expected to work.

review_title: It's hard work, but it pays...
pros:
-Work hour choices are flexible
-the supervisors are helpful
-the career opportunities are definitely there
-once you past your trial period(usually 30 days) the UNION will fight for your job if you get into a jam

Everybody's experience is different. I'm making the best out of mine. It's funny, the people that complain about things not being fair and supervisors being mean are the ones that always come in late, or don't come in at all, or have the most mis-shipped boxes. The bottom line is, if you come to work when your scheduled, on time,  with a good attitude, and are accurate when doing your job, you will move up quickly
cons:
-breaks/lunches are short
-very hard work

Doing this job for a long time can put a lot of wear and tear on your body because of the constant movement, thus Id not recommend doing this job for a long time. Try to move up doing something else as quickly as possible, as you will also make more money quicker.

review_title: A good start, but there are better seasonal jobs out there.
pros: It is an alright job if you are looking for seasonal work.  It is also a great start if you are looking to work full time with UPS.  Many drivers started out as a driver helper.  Some drivers are fun to work with.   In some cases the driver will pick you up from your house every day and you will end up delivering in your neighborhood.
cons: Since the economy is in the tank and there are plenty of people looking for work, they lowered the pay for the position from around $11 to just above minimum wage.  They make you pay union dues, but what is the point of joining the union when you are only working there for 1-6 weeks.  Also, some centers would pay more for their driver helpers than others, even though the centers were 20 miles apart.

job_title: Part-time Package Handler in Miami, FL
pros: Benefits are great, and there is potential to grow within the company, well the warehouse since that's where package handlers start working from, you can start at $9.50 (back in 2010) and by the 3rd month you get a dollar raise and are allowed to take a "sort-out" test for another dollar raise, so within the first year you can go from $9.50 to $ 11.50 the hour.
cons: work conditions are pretty bad, there are time trailers you will need to load at over 90 degrees hot inside since they haven't been opened, very fast phased so it might be as a "con" for some people, have patient because you will be bossed around and told what to do, the place is very loud and fast so you might take things the wrong way when being told.

review_title: You would never believe what part-time supervisors are subjected to
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Cincinnati, OH
pros: 2 weeks paid vacation for years 1-4, 3 weeks paid vacation after 5 years with company.  health insurance with $2000 deductable for only $250 per year in premiums.
cons: Be prepared to be blamed for absolutely everything that goes wrong, even if it wasn't your fault.  You will receive absolutely no praise, even when you work as hard as you can, day in and day out.  You will come home beyond exhausted and have no energy for the rest of your life.  Working from approximately 2 am to 9:30 am will mess with your sleep cycle and make you feel tired all the time.  Having to train dozens of people that you know will quit in around 10 days is maddening

pros: The pay was decent for being part time, decent benefits. Not manual labor (supposedly)
cons: Upper management will yell at you, union workers will yell at you. Yelling at lower management is what everyone in the warehouse does to release their anger. Upper management will yell at you to help the unloader or loader if they aren't going fast enough, but then if you get a grievance filed on you they will yell at you for that. I'm pro union, but finally going to management made realize just how bad teamsters are. Nothing can be done about bad employees. You write them up a few times then they fight it and keep their job. Going into management at UPS was one of the worst career moves I ever made.

pros: UPS is obviously a very large, well-known company, and is an industry leader in logistics. This review will be in regards to sales positions. The work/life balance is good. The people have a good work ethic and are very well meaning (the vast majority, at least). It is not easy to get fired.
cons: The pay structure is terrible, and anyone who has the ability to do anything about it has been with the company for 30 years, and doesn't understand what the younger work force is looking for or how to pay them fairly. Senior Management is blind. The CEO gave himself a 35% raise in 2014, the same year that I received 3%, coming off of my best year.

job_title: Part Time Operations Supervisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good benifits, great place to work if you do not have a college degree or if you are working towards it. Some locations provide tuition assitance.
cons: You are expected to take shortcuts to get work done quickly, but are then held accountable for not getting work done properly. Extremely difficult to move from part-time to full-time because there are very limited opportunities to gain new experiences as a part-time employee. It is also a union labor force which, in my own experience, creates an environment where employees can not show up to work, are frequently late, and work inefficiently on purpose with very little or no consequences at all.

pros:
Great Benefits
Friendly People
Challenges and Work changes daily
Typically has enough labor to cover functions adequately
Though operations thinks its a stressful job, its not
cons:
From an engineering perspective, the company is stuck in the stone ages. Even in the newest 'automated' facility the technology being utilized is over 20 years old. The support system for these automated systems are garbage and there is no training for local engineering teams. 
Also, the company's management is ass-backwards with operations and transportation being the primary functions that govern the company. As opposed to engineering leading the company; this usually creates problems because operation teams will use equipment improperly and break copious amounts of equipment.

pros: It's close to my home, decent pay and I truly love my team. Paid vacations, holidays and OT when available.
cons:
It sucks being the only female sometimes, there's no A/C or working fans during the Summer and Winter (it's Arizona for crying out loud!), I never received the consistent help I was promised  and asked for from my supervisor, if you have a vacation planned and some one else requests that week before you, there's a "sucks to be you, you should have put in sooner" kind of attitude.
I can't speak for every warehouse or other UPS positions, but everyone hates our supervisor. He's a gossip mill about me and my team mates, lazy and if it doesn't fit his agenda, it likely will never happen or be discussed.

pros: During the 2017 Holiday Season I was a Driver Helper and then an independent helper for UPS. Definitely a great way to pick up some extra money, especially if you end up working overtime hours (which in some cases became applicable after only 20 hours a week). If you are with a driver, you might be able to develop a good relationship with them and if you are an independent helper, you can more or less set your own schedule.
cons: Working with a driver can be tough because you don't your schedule until the day of, which was definitely stressful for me. And as an independent helper, there is little interaction with other people and can sometimes be lonely, and people might sometimes make fun of the golf cart you are delivering packages in.

pros:
- I worked for UPS Europe 3 years, in HR
- even on beginner experience level people are gettin a lots of responsibilites. You get to work on interesting projects and you can learn a lot in very litte time
- Safe Job - the company is rather stable and not making peope redundant that easily
- Engaging company culture - UPS makes you feel you are part of  something bigger and you contribute to company´s success
- Great community involvement activities - UPS supports local charities not just financially, but also by actual work done by employees. 
- Open door and inclusive culture
cons:
- management is changing way too often and therefore some managers don´t take any responsibility for their past mistakes
- incompetent people can get unbelievably high in the company´s hierarchy
- company is not able to keep employees as the salaries are not market competitive - especially the younger specialist employees are suffering 
- too many dated rules and policies - dress code, shaving policy, family members policy, social media policy, etc.

review_title: Only if you're desperate for college reimbursement, become a PT supervisor.
pros:
The benefits are good and the tuition reimbursement is the only reason you should ever become a PT supervisor.

If not, STAY IN THE UNION.
cons:
All they care about is numbers, not you.  You have to beg for time off, the pay is poor compared to what you have to do, only recently did they pay if you worked more than five and half hours, you never get repairs for your equipment when you needed it, all the departments work against each other, they constantly under staff you and forces you to work which then leads to some of the union workers to correctly file a grievance with you.

They lie to you about being promoted to full time management and they expect you to lie to your workers that they'll be drivers within 2 years, when it's realistically a five to seven year wait.

review_title: UPS is an excellent company to work at for 5 years, much longer and you risk having the company run/become your life.
pros: Career advancement for diversity (minority and women) employees.  Benefits package is very comprehensive, salary is acceptable.  The legacy from the company's founders is very important to true UPSers, which is refreshing in a world where most companies don't have the history of being in business for over 100 years.
cons: The culture of putting the company first at the expense of family and personal life.  Career advancement for non-diverse employees (white males).  Demotion of employees instead of terminating low-performers.  Demoting an employee from a manager to a supervisor creates a life long supervisor that blocks the number of available slots for new (better qualified) candidates that join the company.

pros: The pay is good. The benefits are excellent. You have the benefit of union support and protection in some jobs. While the company does seem to be running itself into the ground, it seems safe to say it will be around for a while yet.
cons: I have never seen worse employee-management relations in my entire life. Management is very openly anti-union. The CEO is a technology guy and pushes to solve every problem by introducing a new layer of technology that ultimately causes more problems than it solves. The drivers spend 20-30% of their day doing meaningless tasks to appease the industrial engineers, then punished for not being able to get enough work done. My 20 years of hard work for this company has been rewarded by being constantly told that I am a stupid, slow, lazy, untrustworthy, whiner.  I would encourage prospective employees to take a deep look into this company. Look much deeper than the pay and benefits and make an informed decision.

review_title: UPS is a thankless employees with a large number of dissatisfied employees. I am looking forward to finding a different employer and escaping this toxic environment as soon as possible
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Des Moines, IA
pros: The best reason to work here is for the benefits package for hourly employees. It is negotiated by the Teamsters union and is truly second to none.
cons: Management is constantly breathing down your neck and demanding that you work at very high rates of production that prove impossible for most to sustain over time. The starting wage is terrible for the pace and menial nature of the work you will be asked to perform. They only offer a very small tuition assistance program on the midnight/graveyard shift--everyone else is simply out of luck. There is a constant, and ridiculously high, turnover of new and established employees, as most self respecting people find themselves unwilling to work under these types of conditions.

review_title: Good job, with the right management
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: It's a good job for college students and people interested in becoming a driver. The work is hard, but if you get the right managers it's not terrible. Overtime pay is nice and pretty much guaranteed during peak.
cons: I have heard some horror stories of bad managers and terrible situations. I never personally encountered them, but I would not have kept working there if I had been in one. The work can feel tedious and get mentally exhausting (on top of the physical) at times. Also, peak season really sucks. It gets super busy and you end up working super long shifts, which you can't just leave because the work has to get done.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Chelmsford, MA
pros: In general everybody is pretty nice and you get to know a lot of people on your route who are very friendly. You get paid well and it's a great workout that will keep you in good shape. If your not a lazy person who hates manual labor I would highly recommend working here.
cons: Some days can get pretty bad if the weather isn't nice or you have a lot of packages to deliver. Plus dealing with dogs can be a pain in the butt. You will also get some annoying customers but that is to be expected in any prrofession.

pros: 36.40 an hour. Average 8 hours per week of over time at 54.60 per hour. Union protection. Made 99,xxx $ last year. excellent benefits package that costs the company over 30k per year. top of the line health benefits. 6 weeks of paid vacation per year. early retirement with a great pension. West coast pension fund is one of the strongest in the nation.
cons: overtime can be brutal. zero flexibility with the job. Physical nature of the job can easily lead to injuries if you are not careful. Lots of old guys retire with wore out, broken down bodies. home late and never see your family. lots employees here get divorces.

review_title: Driver Helper...Unreliable hours and sporadic management
pros: It's a fun job and low stress. It'd be good for a college student on break or someone looking for a little extra cash during the holidays.
cons: Management gave few details about the job before sending you out. The 1st day I showed up as a driver helper the driver was forced to send me home because he wasn't authorized to keep me longer. Hours have become limited to a max of 3 per day. They don't give you a heads up when they expect you to work on a Saturday, only give notice the day of. Low hourly wage but considering the job I don't think it's unfair.

review_title: Mental abuse simply not worth it
pros: There is a sense of pride in doing the physical work. They do offer great benefits if you make it through the gauntlet. I have great respect for those that just put their headphones in and ignore incessant talking down.
cons:
No matter how much you are willing to adjust and do it is never enough. You can give it 110% and they will demand 120%. Give the 120% and they demand 130%. Almost comical when being barked by an extremely immature adult-child supervisor.
The benefits are intriguing and can really be a good thing but you really have to weigh your dignity vs benefits. The pay alone is ridiculously small compared to the large demand always put on you.
If you are the type of person that enjoys waking up at 2:30am and going to work for a mere 3 hours and getting paid a lousy $20 after taxes and other deductions all while having an unqualified supervisor treating you like garbage then this is the job for you!

pros: Awesome manager, nice co-workers. I actually felt bad leaving (that is why I gave it a 4 star rating)
cons: Dirty work enviroment ( yes it is a shipping company but the offices are dirty), management talks to each other over phone calls like garbage. Very degrading towards each other. The company will consume your life if you allow it to, they expect long hours worked with no overtime for management positions.  Little to no appreciation. Management is extremely underpaid compared to the union workers who do get overtime and free benefits ( your expected to supervise workers who make more money than you and get free healthcare, figure that one out!) Your not going to make decent money unless you are with the company for well beyond 20 years, small pay increases on top of low pay.

review_title: Work here longer than 3 months if you're going to accept the job
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Madison, WI
pros: The work is fairly simple and you can easily work a second job if you work for UPS.
cons: Often times, the trucks are packed so full of packages that you can barely (if at all) walk through at the end of your shift. This makes it frustrating to find a place for everything and to make everything fit nicely, especially since packages tend to come down the conveyor-belt quickly. I also think the pay is low for what kind of work is performed. If you accept a job with UPS, work beyond the 90 day period it takes to get into the union because otherwise, the job's just not worth it. UPS takes money out of your paycheck each week for the union before the 90-day period has passed.

review_title: It's tolerable, but definitely needs some improvements
pros: I worked as a driver helper. The seasonal pay was pretty solid compared to other temporary and seasonal positions. You can also get a good workout with the physical demands of the job.
cons: Communication at the company leaves much to be desired. In the helper position, I was told that I might work on a particular day and that they'd get back to me for sure. After the time I was supposed to meet the driver, I got a call asking why I didn't show up. I did show up, but the driver wasn't there, so I left, and I received the call on the way home. On top of that, many loaders can't read numbers and won't put packages in the right place in the delivery trucks to make the delivery process as efficient as it could be.

review_title: Values Length of Tenure over Quality of Work
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Good work/life balance for non-management
Corporate office is a nice, secure facility
Pay was average to good for industry
Good benefits, even for PT employees
Most employees were polite and overall nice people
cons:
Corporate culture is creepy to anyone who has been with the company for less than 15 years
Lack of training and resources for admin staff
Understaffed -- management would rather save $$ by dividing up departing employee's workload instead of hiring a replacement
Very difficult to get promoted unless you relocate
Extremely old-fashioned -- office still uses metrics that other businesses abandoned in the 80s and managers still use Blackberries

pros: Benefits Package for part time workers, Union Contract,  easy to get hired, hard to get fired after first 30 days
cons: Low pay for Package Handlers, Management by Stress, weak/corrupt Union, inexperienced Supervisors, high production goals over short period of time,  no bonuses, little vacation, difficult to get sick days,  increasing Contract violations, high turnover rate, unnescessarily unsafe working environment, lack of hub maintaince, blame the worker approach to workplace issues.

review_title: What Happened to this once known as " A Good Company"?
job_title: Senior, Programmer Analyst in Mahwah, NJ
pros: The benefits are good and the employees work as a team...almost family-like.
cons:
Low compensation and micro managaing! Literally, some managers sit by the entrance to watch employees, 

Not a place to work if you have school-age children as there's no worklife balance at UPS throughout the U.S. In order to be considered for a promotion, you must work at least 45+ hours a week. Promotions are limited and some have passed up because an employee "only works 40 hours". There are many who have reached the point where they're "ready for the next level" but have been at that point for years due to the # of people in the pipline,

review_title: The benefits of working at UPS makes the cons worth while.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Hodgkins, IL
pros: There is a strong union, that has decent insurance that is paid in your union dues.  You aren't able to receive the insurance until a year.  I don't know about all locations, but the CACH location offers company advancement, and will pay for a good deal of your education.
cons: Very physical, stressful and dirty.  If you have a week immune system don't work at UPS.  Breathing that air seems as bad as smoking.  The first time I walked out of the warehouse I blew my nose and it was all black.

review_title: Great company brand; little room for career advancement and development in engineering.
job_title: Industrial Engineering Supervisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great company brand and strong culture.  Great Management experience if you can deal with the stress of working in the District.
cons:
There is little work-life balance, and will be very stressful working in the District.
Very "old-school" in some areas, which makes it undesireable for the younger management.
Few career advancement opportunities outside of Operations.
If you are in a position within the District, it's difficult to move to another business unit even if your educational/work background fits a position outside of the District.

pros: The best health insurance ever.
cons:
You will need said health insurance to cover all of the injuries you'll have here. Also, it's a soul sucking job and no one there is happy. Not even management making 6+ figures. 

Even with the injury prevention training you get, the repetetive motion of the jobs available will result in strain. I sorted small packages for about 5 years and I still have issues with my hands locking up and general shoulder pain. 

Drivers make pretty good $, especially since you'll probably get lots of overtime because they understaff so much that it's basically required. 10-12 hr days were not uncommon in my facility. Also, they didn't really care much about our equipment, if it worked or not. I was in a smaller facility that got the bigger facility's old equipment. We upgraded once. It wasn't much better. 

Over all: Don't do it.

pros:
For part-time work, the pay is good.
Coworkers are helpful.  
Benefits are great for part-time workers.
cons:
Supervisors are horrible at communication between themselves.  
Rarely do they inform the employees what the start time is Monday, and the employees have to call out the supervisors on this. 
They say they promote safe lifting, but they really don't care.  They mainly care about speed loading/unloading and that the packages fit well in trucks first and foremost.  Safe lifting is a secondary priority. 
The lifting will break your body down over time.  Young guys try extra hard, but it breaks them down over time too.  
Very difficult to get into a full-time position, and supervisors will look for any excuse to keep that from happening.

review_title: Experience was positive and allow a lot of opportunities for career advancement
pros: Salary and benefits are excellent, the training in Corporate schools are the best, UPS has an excellent sense of community with their partnerships with United Way and the National Urban League.
cons: Too many people that are not qualified for leadership positions are given positions of authority.  Promotions are given all the way up to the mid-level senior management level to people who do not have the education and/or experience to have position.  Leads to very poor management and poor work enviroment.

pros: Company has some decent benefits, some nice people to work with. As a supervisor you get benefits right away, there is no waiting period like it is for some of the other positions like package handlers.
cons: First off, the salary is a joke starting at about 15 bucks an hour in Phx. You can make more being a driver part. Management has some young dudes who think they are Generals of an Army. Not much interaction with non management personnel and management personnel. The box pushers are treated more like boxes than human beings. Training is mundane and the work is very repetitive. If you like repetitive, robotic like work then UPS is for you. For me, staying on your feet for 6-7 hours looking at packages all day with low pay didnt entice me to stay. Turnover is very high.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Roanoke, VA
pros: A great workout. the benefits were awesome. The jab is a great first job to work on your team building skills.
cons: When I got fired from UPS, they were firing me for not turning another employee destroying company property. I was 18 and this employee was my best friend at the time. They caught him on video destroying company property and I watched and after he was done destroying the company's property I poked at it to see the damage. They fired me for that little incident. I got the option to quit or file a grievance. Of course I thought I would get my job back so I filed a grievance, so he fired me right as I did that. I called the shop steward and he would never pick up my phone calls and there was nothing I could do! Now I am being affected by this in my life because when I fill out a application and it says have you ever been fired from a job, I have to say yes and I never get calls back.

review_title: great pay if they would work you. takes 7-10 years to get full time.
pros:
Great pay if you get the hours
Excellent Brand
Excellent Benefits
cons: only those with 20+ years get hours. it takes 10 years to work full time. No set schedule. On-call. Cant afford to work here unless you have a working spouse or are independently wealthy. They put a good wage in front of you but you spend years chasing it. work till 8 PM each night if you do work while they leave other drivers at home unemployed while other drivers are out with too much work. Poor Management.

pros:
I was treated very fairly and with a lot of respect. I was teamed up with several different drivers over the Christmas holiday and each one was incredibly friendly and fun to be around. 

I was given a lot of hours on a regular schedule. It's also nice to deal with people and get to know local businesses.
cons:
Some drivers are definitely better than others. It can be frustrating to have a slower driver when you're trying to work as efficiently as possible. 

It's tiring work, but it definitely gets easier as the days go by.

I have heard some people have trouble getting picked up for hours, but as long as you work hard for your driver and show up on time they will probably request you each day so you won't have to call into the dispatch center every morning.

I had to buy a brown jacket out of pocket because they ran out of the uniforms.

review_title: Its was a good job if your in a position to sacrifice your time.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Memphis, TN
pros: Its a hard company to work for until you put in your first year. Until then expect low pay for backbreaking work. If your in  a position to give year making vary little money your investment will be grand. But I have a family, I cant work for $10 an hr only working 6 hrs a day not to work much more than that. Delivery drivers make good money but its a bidding WAR to get that far.
cons: Need to be in a good financial situation to allow for your time to be invested in the company. Packages get thrown around by people who are to high to be fired over. Its union. Good luck getting on full time, the terminal in Memphis, manager told me its been over 10 years since they hired full time position.

review_title: Management Takes it on the Chin
pros: After 25 years in Management you get 6 weeks of vacation
cons:
1.Management can't take vacations when they want.  Only when company wants them to.
2.Union gets their health benefits, Management has to pay for theirs...increases every year.
3.Management no longer receives retirement, Union employees still do.
4.Management required to work a minimum of a 10 hour day with no lunch or breaks More comonly 12 to 16 hours. FT teamsters  receive time and half after 8 hours and an additional 20 minute paid break after 10.
5. UPS will preach Safety, but the only reason it's pushed so hard is because of the cost of being self insured.  
6.  Recently cut the management ranks signifacntly.  When people quit or retire, they are not replaced.
7.Very top heavy in upper management. 
8. Rank and File management feel the Partnership Legacy that UPS always totes is long gone. 
9. Conference Calls are all norm.  No one ever gets trained properly.  Just take a CBT or listen on a Conference Call.  Too many folks doing the calls have never done what they are asking you to do.

review_title: You are a work horse. Don’t believe the BS.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Lenexa, KS
pros: The pay is nice, but hardly worth the work.
cons: Favoritism, they will literally work you until you need to see a doctor, no leniency on injured employees. The hours are NOT set, as the managers will force you to stay hours beyond what the agreed upon hours are. This job was a night mare. People praise this job and I have absolutely no idea why. Your back WILL have permanent damage after working here for a period of time, and UPS will not take care of it for you.

pros:
Benefits
I enjoy the early mornings and have day time for family/yourself
Keeps you in shape physically 
Promotes within offered being a PT then FT driver within 6-9 months of start date
Done by 9:15am each day if not earlier
Union protects you and your job
cons:
Managment takes advantage of hard workers by giving them more/harder work. 
Gets overwhelming at times
Heat during the summer is bad and is even worse since Warehouse is warmer than outside. 
Lazy people get helped and are protected by union

review_title: A good or bad company to work for depending on what your age and position is.
job_title: Senior Web Developer in New York, NY
pros: Job stability.  An extremely stable company that you do not have to worry about being laid off.  It is especially great in a down economy.  Friendly people.  The people I have met in this company so far has all been friendly to deal with.  Flexible schedule (at least for IT positions).  I have been able to take the time off whenever I needed it.  Many available jobs to choose from (depends on your position too).  UPS is a large company and it has a great variety of positions if you have the skills to do it.
cons: Compensation below market (you pay for stability) and not based on performance.  Difficult to advance (at least for IT positions in certain groups).  Company culture/traditions maybe too ancient for the younger generation.

review_title: UPS had good jobs with descent benefits but needs more job flexability
pros: UPS has an average compensation package for both part time and full time employees.  No place is 100% safe but UPS also has pretty good job security especially for its union employees.  In may jobs you are lucky to get a raise at all but at UPS you can always count on the 3%+ every year at the same time.  They also have college tuition reimbursment for those looking to continue their education.  UPS is especially great for women and minorities.  They have MANY oportunities for advancement for both.
cons: Depending upon the department you work for you may not get much family time.  Many of the supervising jobs require MANY hours (60+ hours).

pros: The best reasons to work for UPS is great health benefits, career advancement and stability. More over this company will give you time off when you need to go to school. For example, some of the workers can get two days out from the week to go to school and still gets the full benefits.
cons: The downsides of working for UPS is the labor part. Majority of the new workers do not make it in the first three months, it is extremely hardship and contains a lot of energy to finish the tasks. Furthermore, the pay in the beginning will be only a little bite more than working in the fast food links.

review_title: Overall, UPS was better than most employers but I did not feel that the company culture was a good fit for me.
pros:
- Very strong customer focus
 - Great hours for a part time job, especially for college students
 - Nice tuition re-reimbursement
 - Physically active work duties feel great
 - Great people to work with
cons:
- Very hierarchical company culture
 - Employees are discouraged from thinking for themselves
 - Sluggish internal logistics (replacing vacant positions, staffing, etc takes forever).
 -  Inefficient or counter-productive job duties are assigned, adding unnecessary steps
 - Limited benefits package choices, one-size-fits-all approach
 - Stressful work environment
 - Centralized decision making in Atlanta attempts to micro-manage but is out of touch with individual centers throughout the country

pros: The BEST health and dental insurance for your family. The best job stability in the industry. The best pay rate in the industry ( if you can survive the early years of part time hub life.)
cons: If you plan to go into part time management, just get in, get out as soon as possible to get a great management reference on your resume. Fulltime management will eat you! If plan to remain hourly, join/support the union immediately and enjoy a long stable, well paid career driving the BEST maintained equipment in the industry along with the best benefits. Just expect long hours and weird shifts until you reach a higher level of seniority.

pros:
I was very fortunate to be hired off the street into a full time driver position, I had no idea what I was getting myself into, but this has turned out to be the best job I've had!  

The pay is good enough for my age and will increase over time to a very good level.  The benefit package is phenomenal, so far it seems I am covered for everything and do not pay for any of it directly (I suppose I do through union dues).  

If you like fast paced work that allows you to problem solve all day long this would be a great job to look at.
cons: There are not many things I do not like about this job, although peak season (winter months) is rough on the work/life balance.  At times the relationship between management and drivers can be a bit strained, but that comes with all union positions, so it is not exclusive to UPS.

pros: Average pay, Clean break area and bath rooms, good parking, security a plus,  easy to locate, hard working and loyal workers on the sorts.
cons: You are not given any notice to changes being made concerning the work you do it is always at the last minute, even if you had just asked about it a few hours before. A lot of the supervisors will not allow you to ask questions, they tell you to just listen.  It is like they were taught to do that because most of  them say the exact same thing. It seems to rub off on some of the other employees too.  The other shift sorters don't even want to talk on break or anything.

pros: Pay - awesome esp with overtime.  If a low volume day, might get asked if you want to take the day off (no pay). Great if money is the main thing...
cons: Can't always count on overtime.   January always takes a nose-dive so not just a ton extra because of Christmas. Managers may or may not work with you for days needed off. No time off after Thanksgiving to Christmas.  Very hard on the back/feet etc..  Heavy lifting. Get a helper for 70 lb loads is a joke (who's going to be there?) Work in the rain, cold no matter what usually. Only closed down a couple times in 20 years. Bonus for the holiday is a frozen turkey (hope it isn't warm out that day!)

review_title: Very demanding with high standards, a fair amount of stability & new opportunities opening up due to retiring.
pros: A decent amount of stability. Big company. Around for a long time. Many 15, 20, 30 year employees retiring, so new positions and promotion opportunities opening. Heavy investment in IT.  Their IT dept is huge and dwarfs many entirely Tech companies staffs.
cons: They push people hard to deliver results in a competitive industry.  Slow to change and adopt new ways of thinking.  Some Enterprise IT systems badly need an overhaul.  A lot of long term management have spent their entire careers there, so have no comparisons. So they expect you'll be like them: ask more and more of you and you'll just stick around like they did.

pros: i dint find any expect few policies- promote from within (with ofcorse condition of being biased.)
cons: if you are MBA finance don't even think of joining this company as other companies wont consider the experience at all. people here are literally worst to deal with. don't support at all and management is biased. will get into your personal life and judge you by that. bunch of ******* are working here. HR people don't work they just roam from one room to another. you can't even use your cellphones. where management don;t support you at all and they will ask you to leave if you don't follow them (here i am not talking about breaking any policy). Don't think of dressing up properly they ll think your from the reputed background so you don't need a good hike. . you have to plan your sick leaves too. lol. else it will mark as an unplanned and if you take an unplanned leave you are not eligible for IJPs and  R&R and it will hamper your future in the company because you fell sick without knowing.

pros: Of course, the main pro is the company is stable.  Founded in 1907, and still going strong, they maintain focus on POL, almost above everything.  They offer a great benefit package, but it has fallen far from the "Cadillac" plan they used to offer management.
cons: The hourly employees have a much higher standard of health & welfare coverage, with zero cost to them.  Management pays an enormous premium.  They talk about work/life balance, they want everyone to say it, but they would rather you work until you drop, then say "thank you".  The company treats their managers like slaves.  It's not uncommon to walk into a meeting where the Division Manager is screaming like a lunatic at the managers he oversees.  It has gotten worse over the years.  It has become extremely difficult to find hourly employees that want to be promoted because they see the way management is treated.

pros:
-If you want some extra money don't mind giving up sleep and can do lot of hard work, then can try UPS.
- Health benefits are good(after 12 months employee/18 months family).
cons:
-Most supervisors treat like you are worthless and bully a lot.
-Get used to metal flooring, it's not good for your back, neck and long term health issues.
- They lure you with health benefits(after 12 months employee/18 months family) and then exploit your weakness  that you are there for health benefits.
-Actual working hours differ from what's mentioned in job description.
- Seen atleast couple of people get hurt every week.
-it's $11/hr, if you can get same pay some other place go for it. The pay is less for the hard labor work.
-They say they promote from within which I have found to not be true. Some of their supervisor's don't treat the hourly with a level of respect
-No HVAC in in work area.

review_title: Seasonal Driver Helpers Left In the Dark
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Houston, TX
pros: Easy job, peak bonuses, and you don't have to deal with people all that much
cons: Not in control of recording your own hours, lazy or vindictive drivers who don't report your hours on their sheets (that's if they even have one), and incorrect recordings of your hours if you work overtime. Say you will be employed till January 15th but only keep helpers the week and days before Christmas. They do not tell you are no longer working and you pretty much have to find out from your driver. They do not give your last paycheck and you pretty much have to call their dispatch number before they stop using it or you have get in contact with hr and/or go to facility to get their attention for once. They SHOULD mail the last check, but of course this company does not do that (so far). Them not telling you when your work ends, when and where you will get your final paycheck, and when their dispatch number stops working was a fitting end to working with and an unprofessional and disorganized company

review_title: Good for parents and students, but management is atrocious.
pros:
- Good benefits
- Good scholarship
- Flexible hours
cons:
- Depending on where you work inside the plant, the work conditions range from okay to awful
- Depending on which shift you work on, the supervisors range from decent to horrendous. Some of them are just terrible people to work for who see those under them as dispensable workers, as opposed to human beings. 
- The union is an outdated agency that exists to protect the small freight package-handlers from the supervisors. They take a cut of your paycheck once a month which increases a little over time the longer you work there. The good thing about the union is that they protect you from bad supervisors. The bad thing is that they let bad small freight workers keep their job, unless they get into a fight, in which case the union can do nothing for them.

review_title: It was a good job for school.
pros:
-Short hours; for the time I can spend on personal projects. 
-Start out at decent pay per hour. 
-Can help you stay in shape, somewhat.
cons:
-Short hours; unless you can make it to full time, management, or unless you have simply worked there for several years, you wont really make enough money to cover the bills. 
-Depressing working environment; There is no effort in making the hub a place anybody would ever want to be. Its dirty, dark, loud, dusty, and devoid of color or anything happy. 
-Some of the managers aren't above lying to get you to come to work, even if you have a perfectly good reason not  to be there, like a death in the family.

pros:
-Great for an entry-level seasonal position, compensation was $12.88/hr.

-My dispatcher and assigned driver were a pleasure to work with.

-Work is simple yet involved, provides great exercise! Involves: Lifting packages up to 70 lbs unassisted, constant walking, organizing packages in back of truck, logging upcoming and delivered packages in the DIAD board, and keeping a friendly demeanor!
cons:
-Most helpers will not have a solid schedule or permanent driver.

-Management can seem out of touch with the guys out on the road.

-No guarantee to stay with company after seasonal work, if you're persistent apply for package handling positions and you should get preference.

-Work is unsuited for the lazy or extremely unfit, you're moving and using your arms & legs at a constant basis. Even athletic individuals will be sore into their first week.

pros: Great Compensation, great co-workers. Flex time with your schedule. Management are great about giving you requested time off.I would still be with them except I moved out of state and the UPS in my current city has no openings at this time. I worked for them for 14 years.
cons: Pay could be a little better, but not bad.They need to rotate some of the older Management out more. Some have been in the same Dept./area for too long and have become a little stagnant and non-caring.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Houston, TX
pros: Good Exercise.  The pay is above minimum wage and overtime starts after 5 hours.  After a year, part-time employees are eligible  for health insurance.
cons: Dangerous!  The place is an OSHA nightmare.  Supervisors are constantly yelling to work faster but do little to assist or actually supervise.  To handle the work load and keep up with expectations, you are required to cut corners.  Safety is an afterthought.  Injuries and near misses are under-reported and a lot is done to discourage any worker's comp complaints.  The work is rough and wears on you.  Unloaders are expected to move packages weighing from 1-70 pounds at a rate of 1200 packagers per hour.  if you can do lifts and squats continuously for 4-5 hours, then this is the job for you.

pros:
Big name to put on your resume.
Nationwide... Perhaps other centers are better?
Reasonably stable company.
cons:
The center I worked at had a very negative cultural climate. No matter how fair you tried to be it was "us vs them." As a part-time preload supervisor I was told that my job was to get a "fair day's work for a fair day's pay" out of my union workers. What that boiled down to was the management trying to squeeze every last minute of work out of the hourly union workers, while they on the other hand looked for any opportunity to bring a grievance against the management. Both the preloaders and the drivers took every opportunity to make snyde antagonistic comments against the management often peppered with colorful language. There was a palpable sense of enmity between the two sides. 
Preload hours are miserable... around 2:30 am until 10:00ish.

review_title: Workin' Smart Not Hard- Taking Every Opportunity to Be Great
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Commerce City, CO
pros: Incredibly fun! Getting a work out while working safely paid off for my body. The pay was awesome and the fact that you can work your vacation made it even better. I loved my co-workers and my supervisor's we always had a game plan every night. Between team work and hard workers we always rocked the house!
cons: The Management was not always bad everyone has their ups and downs. When I started going to College I never thought twice about My supervisor and Manager having problems with it, Until I joined a Team that required some work flexibility- one day a week for practice. Next thing I know Threats of getting let go or transfer to other shifts made me realize I wasn't a part of the team anymore.

job_title: Seasonal Package Car Driver in Chicago, IL
pros: High dollars per hour, if you are willing pay your dues working a grunt part time for a few years, you can work yourself up to full time driver, which pays well for hard work. Good benefits after 1 year.
cons: Incomplete training, we had a few hours in the lab to complete what should have taken 40 hours of computer time or more. Then when it was time to go to work, they expected us to know stuff that was just glossed over in class. Very high pressure is put on to perform tasks as fast as possible.  They promise you this good money, but its only if you are actually working. I only worked 1 day out of the first six that I reported for. Those other five days, I showed up and waited several hours to see if I would get assigned a route. Then I would get sent home with no pay. I could have been training with one of the other drivers who had routes, but they were trying to save money. So when I finally had work, I was unprepared.

pros: Pros were the medical benefits
cons: Union/management tension was horrible; everyone on all sides was paranoid. I was hired to work in a backwater, remote location, where it was every person for themselves. I was sent "back to the future" to a training facility that could have doubled as a set for a bad 80's movie (to be exact, 1984, as in big brother was watching). Had to be at training at 3:30 am; trained by two career "extras" on set who, when they weren't at UPS, were down the street at Chic Fillet gaining another 30 lbs. Returned to an undisclosed location to report to work and received continued training from an aderol-ridden 24-year-old who never slept. I actually liked most of the drivers but they were so entrenched in the toxic work environment they couldn't see that there was any life beyond it, it was all they could do to beat the clock, barely. Hands down, the most BIZARRE place I've ever worked. BONUS!!: I got to break up two fights between male drivers and I'm a woman. Stranger than bad fiction; all research for the book.

review_title: As a leader, no win situations is life
pros: Stability of largest shipper that is always on the forefront of shipping technology.
cons: Terrible culture. Supervisors and Managers walked on by the union employees who not only choose how hard they work, they make a ton more with better benefits.

review_title: Communcation is the key to success and teamwork not Greed
pros: The infrastructure and great career opportunity
cons: The managers never ask drivers opinion before implementing certain situation that deals with a drivers everyday routine. Sales reps not being more aggressive about going out and getting business or checking in on customer to see how service is and how if any way possible could we as a company assist them anyway different, with are array  of services..

pros: I have only been here for four months and am being promoted to PT Supervisor. If you work hard and smart, you move up the ranks. Even if you don't, you also move up the ranks...only much more slowly. Either way, it's a win win.
cons: It's a dangerous, and exhausting job. That feed is always more than any one person can handle if they have any idea of awhat a quality load is. If you are a stickler for quality, you will have a difficult time here.

review_title: if you knew better, you'd do better.
pros: good daily work out, weekly pay, 401k, union
cons: extremely hot inside loading trucks.. add 10*-12* degrees to the outside temp. only one ten min break which is actually 8 mins cause you have to be back in your area at 2 mins to time of your 10 min break being over. No origination at all on how the packages come to you down the slide and nothing to protect you from getting hit in the face or wherever when the packages start coming . It consistently boxes on the floor to the point where you cant get out the truck with out climbing or stepping on the boxes which we are not supposed to do.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Albany, GA
pros: They pay well above minimum wage and the benefits are good(even though you only receive them after a year of employment).
cons: When me and 3 other coworkers were hired we were told about pay being 9.50 from day one, benefits starting by the 3rd month, and raises every August and February. They did NOT tell us that policies had changed, so instead we started at 8.50, had to wait 3 months to get pay bumped up to 9.50, didn't get benefits until after a year, and no raises(other than after the 3 month probation period) during the 1st year. I worked at the airport hub which required waking up at 4 in the morning (excruciating!). The company decided to cut corners and bring in less planes, so hours were cut to a mere hour and 45 minutes a day!

review_title: It is not what most outsiders think it is
job_title: TSG Field Tech I in Hodgkins, IL
pros:
Extremely structured. Has a way to do everything. 
Good benefits compared to most.
Promotes from within
Excellent education benefits for a degree.
cons:
UPS is an extremely anal corporation and lacks flexibility at all levels.  Package people have it the worst. 
Time is money so it is everything.
It heralds itself for it it's long traditions and value of people, but since the IPO money is the only thing that matters. 
They claim to want people who are innovative and think out of the box, but reality tells another story.
Anyone who wants to be an individual is harassed and eventually one will do what they want or will be made to fail.

job_title: Feeder Driver in New York, NY
pros: You can make a good living if you dont mind putting the hours and the B.S. You can have a good experience in Package if U.P.S was to stay off your back and let you do your job. I had a good time out on the route, but hell in morning and coming back at night.
cons: They are never happy with amount of work you do. Everything is your fault as the driver, they wont go after part-timers, cause they dont care.. They preach safety, when all that matters is stops per hour. They micro-manage too much. In feeder we are told we cannot stop to use the bathroom, even if its an to hour drive. In package they lie all the time, you cannot get a straight answer from them about how many stops you have on your truck.

review_title: Forget all the BS going around and just keep working
pros:
Work hard time goes by faster
Kiss booty you will move up faster
Safety is always #1
Good workout
cons:
Always finding something for you to get blame for
When your busting your butt working hard, the guy next door is not and you will have to help
Seen young supervisors as young as 18 telling adults to hurry up using bad langauge while they sit there staring at you on their phones while u bust butt working

review_title: Security with little growth unless you are one of the few.
pros:
UPS IT does things right. It pays people well and invests in technology and infrastructure and process.
There is generally plenty of time off allowed, except during the holidays.
You have a lot of job security no real fear of layoffs.
cons:
Required to come to work in the worst weather conditions and do dangerous airplane loading jobs you aren't used to doing, in the worst conditions - a recipe for disaster if ever there was one.
You cannot advance unless you are one of the few, so you have to learn to be underutilized and basically bored in your position. This leads to a lot of people doing the least they can, because they see people with lesser qualifications moving up.

pros: If you get along with the driver you were assigned to, then there's not much to it. The driver I had was good guy and we just delivered packages. It was low stress and you get a pretty good work out from it.
cons: The only negative thing I can say about my month experience as a seasonal/temporary worker was that I was only making $10.00 an hour part-time. But that was kind of a given so all in all still pretty good. Now if you wait 8 years and work part-time to become a driver, then its one of the last great middle/upper (frequently 6 figures a year) job with full on benefits and it just might possibly get a defined-benefit pension, but not sure about that. Good union, great job.

review_title: Complete employment...immerses you in training, opportunities, perks, and culture.
job_title: Package Dispatch and Preload Supervisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Very good salary and benefits. Training around the country at its many training facilities on a yearly basis. Many perks and discounts. A solid company.
cons: Got to have very thick skin and realize that hitting your goals/numbers is a must. You better have a legitimate reason for missing set goals/numbers and how you plan on fixing them in the near future. The union the employees are in have a lot of sway with how things are ran and can make it difficult to discipline employees with production or performance issues. Also seniority with union employees can make for a sticky situation when you are trying to put your best people in a position that will better serve the operation.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in San Jose, CA
pros: Great pay, great benefits all around the board including employee discounts at hundreds of places. You become part of Teamsters Union even though it's seasonal or pt time with Union Members Rights. I absolutely loved working here and hopefully by next season or sooner if offered a permanent position they will have caught up with each other and all management will be in the same page!
cons: Lack of communication through the entire management team all the way up the district chain. Missing wages and miscommunication on start end times due to not having a proper way to clock in. Shuttles to and from would be on a confusing schedule and never the same times confusing a lot of people. Need I go on. *** If you have good management none of this will happen and you will love working for this company as well!

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Farmingville, NY
pros: You get to work outside and be on the road all day.
cons: Working outside can be terrible when it rains. You work 5 days a week with your driver. You have a small, old and uncomfortable drop seat to sit on for 8 hours a day. Your tailbone will be sore and you're going to hate potholes. You get an hour break but you cant get dropped off and you have to eat where ever the driver goes. This means eating fast food 5 days a week. The pay is minimum wage. They will promise you an attendance incentive of $100 for not calling out on a work day. I never missed a day and never received my attendance incentive. It took over a week for my last paycheck to be found at the facility. The supervisor even said why would anyone want to work as a driver helper when you can make more money walking around a heated store. Dont do this job. Youre better off seasonally at Wal Mart or Macys.

review_title: The only way to survive is to not care.
pros:
·Listen to your headphones while you work
·Physical workout if you put in the effort
·Awesome benefits for being part time
cons:
·Oftentimes receive your only break an hour into shift 
·Clear divide between management, supervisors, and part timers
·Consistent turnover.
·Part time supervisors usually on a power trip
·Packages are guaranteed to fall and hit you
·Borderline sweatshop conditions during summer
·Tight work space and can hurt yourself
·Supervisors unload and sort all the time and they are NOT allowed to, regardless of what they tell you. "I'm sorting to help you." No. It's to push the volume out faster to meet their numbers, which means less pay for you and rare chances for overtime (unless it's during peak season).

pros: Great corporate environment to work in. The people are exceptionally friendly and interested in meeting young people. They are open to new ideas and new experience. It is incredible that people stay with this company for 20+ years, which shows promise of growth and a love for the company.
cons: I found that at times I was not properly utilized. I feel as if they were a bit unprepared with taking on an intern. A lot of days were spent sitting at my desk asking if there was work to be done instead of them having any kind of set schedule set up for me.

pros: Good company. Good benifits
cons: They don't reward hard work as mutch as stupidity.  Room for growth can be limited. Pay for shifters is an absolute joke, I mean they work harder then drivers and payed 10.50 an hr to start and 15.00 in peak sad ! They push you alot, can be nerve racking to some.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Bedford Park, IL
pros: Physical exercise is really good. It's interesting to see how a delivery company like UPS is run from the ground. The driver I worked with was nice. All the customers are very courteous and see the UPS driver a lot.
cons:
-They take out $13 out of your salary each week for Union dues even as a seasonal part-time/on-call Driver Helper. I was told it was $6.50. So, now I have to send in a form to the union to get back the money.
-After my employment ceased, it has taken forever for them to get me my last 2 paychecks. I still haven't received my last one. It's been about a month and there is no sign of it. I had to call them to ask where my check is.

review_title: What can I say....... A Lot!
pros:
Great experience! Prepared me to open my own company and how to manage for results. 

Had it not been for the struggle I wouldn't appreciate the beautiful moments....
cons:
Underpaid, extremely conservative, they expect you to work 24 hours of the day and night with little compensation, no one can really explain why the metrics are the way they are and how they are obtainable, threatens your job even when you are performing. Management allows senior management to discriminate and harass others. UPS corporate investigators receive complaints yet they never actually do anything about anything. 

Advancement only takes place if you rub the right elbow. Management loves yes men and women. They are interested in people who care more about work then there families.

HR can not be trusted. They are in the bed with other managers. Hence why HR was revamped due to so many internal complaints. The new VP is trying his best to change the moral but it's not working. Turnover is high due to stress, under appreciation, underpaid, harassment and discrimination.
