job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Las Vegas, NV
pros: The position offers a nice bump to your income, coming from a loader, and has some decent benefits if you are single. The tuition reimbursement program helps a lot with your education. During "non peak" times, the hours allow for a comfortable amount of free time outside of work. UPS hires from within and this is a great position to move up into full-time supervisor or on road supervisor.
cons: Hours can be extreme, up to 12 hours per day during peak season. You will be moved around do different positions with/without training and will be responsible for that areas history of problems. Union employees will hound you for any infraction on hourly work. You may experience vocal harassment from your employees.

review_title: UPS is a solid company to work for
job_title: Lead Technical Specialist in Timonium, MD
pros:
The company is solid.  Senior Management knows its place in the global economy.  

Promotions to senior positions are made exclusively from within.  People stay for the long term.  You are still considered a new comer until you hit the 15 year mark.  It is not uncommon for people to spend their entire career at UPS.

Decisions are always made by a group of people and not individuals.  This leads to the promotion of many ideas and different points of view.  

From a technology point of view (which is my field), we are cutting edge.  The drive of our technical people and CIO positions the company to be successful in the future.
cons:
Decisions are made by groups of people.  Sometimes you just need someone to say "We're moving in this direction. End of discussion."

Office politics sometimes trumps what's good for the company.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Dallas, TX
pros: You are paid weekly. If you opt for direct deposit, it doesn't kick in until 2 or 3rd week. Medical benefits aft 1 year but if you can hang in, company pays medical. It's free medical!
cons: Very labours work! This job isn't for everyone. It is very physical. You are expect to keep a certain pace so packages keep moving.  Which isn't easy as packages come in various sizes (envelopes, to car parts)  No need to dress in you best because you will ruin you clothing. Also, expect to sweat! My shirts were soaking wet every night I left. Oh, if you quit, they don't allow you to come back. I left due to pick up issues with my kids and as a single mom I did what I needed to for my kids. So, hang in there as it is tough but the.rewards a plenty if you stay.

review_title: There are days that are okay, and then there are days that straight-up awful.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Oakland, CA
pros: Good workout, alright days if you have the right supervisors.
cons:
I had some pretty bad experiences here. 

Once, I was yelled at 4 hours straight because we were getting hit with a lot of packages and we weren't moving fast enough. We had no breaks and we were way too understaffed. 

Often times, breaks/lunch are ignored. We have to sneak in our breaks/lunch.

One supervisor likes to micromanage me while the entire belt was texting/chatting/slacking off. 

Every week, my hours are VERY off and payroll/management takes about three weeks to be corrected. This is something I can't compromise. It's complete bs that I only get 1/3 of my paycheck per week. Every week I've kept tracked, I've been shorted heavily and I don't think management cares enough to rectify it quickly enough.

review_title: Worst company I have ever worked for
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Bellingham, WA
pros: I honestly have nothing good to say about this job, I have worked many places and this place is the worst.
cons:
- The union rewards mediocrity, no one has to try as soon as they hit union status.
- New hires that can't hack loading trucks work other spots, but take up work slots for people that deserve it.
- Senior employees can leave early leaving more work for the rest of the workers.
- People show up late or not at all and nothing happens.
- The 'supervisors' are nothing more than glorified babysitters, they have no real authority except where you work each day, and even then it sometimes depends on how good you are at your job.
- Becoming a driver would be a Pro due to all the perks, except that it can take almost 10 years to get there.

pros: This was a fun way to learn how things work at UPS from the driver's perspective. For those who enjoy a physical job, it's a great workout. If you perform well & impress your driver, you might have a leg up when it comes to applying for a permanent, entry-level position at UPS.
cons: UPS is very particular (i.e., stingy!) about how many hours drivers are allowed to use their helpers. I was hoping for a lot of hours, but in reality I was only allowed to work between 4-6 hours most days. My driver had been at UPS a long time & toed the line in terms of only using a helper the amount management wanted. I worked most week days from after Thanksgiving through Christmas, but not a day after Christmas. So, don't expect to be working as many hours as the drivers do. This is a part-time job with limited hours that only lasts a few weeks.

pros: Great experience working in a fast-paced and challenging environment. Opportunity to learn a lot of useful skills and knowledge. If able to approach and communicate with co-workers/employees effectively and respectfully, there are some great relationships to be made.
cons: The company culture that starts from the top down is less than true leadership. If your way of management does not conform to the "UPS way," you most likely will not grow within the company and depending on how stubborn ( or smart) you are, will eventually be squeezed out all together.

review_title: Back breaking hard labor great money
job_title: Package Car Driver in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Make just under a 100000 a year weekends off holidays off lots of vacation time.Union job so seniority always reigns.One of the few company's left that offers a pension also health benefits at no cost to you and your family
cons: Hard labor at a break neck pace with constant pressure and micromanage ment being applied to you every second.You are constantly being monitored and held accountable for your performance.The bar is raised every year so as you age you have to become faster at completing your route.The pressure is applied from the top down turning the management and hourly employees into adversaries.You are basically a beast of burden

review_title: Work - The Way it Should Be
pros: The pros of being a UPS package handler are many! Getting to be a part of a great team, working a physically demanding job, and great tuition benefits are just the beginning. UPS offers up to $5,000 tuition compensation for part time employees. Also after a year of working with them they offer full health insurance - a pretty good deal for loading packages for 4 hours every day!
cons: Start time is usually 3:30. Can't bring my phone into the building. Very fast paced and can be stressful (I threw up on my first day).

pros:
My role offers great opportunities, the work environment can be pretty relaxed, your working for a world renowned company.
The staff are good at what they do and there is lots of experience to utilise.
cons:
The running of the daily operation does rely on the effort of the staff on shift, spurred on with shouts and " whip cracks" . Morale within the staff is variable from day to day, with some seemingly in a constant bad mood. 
It is expected that all staff do a certain amount of  unpaid overtime, with no tangible amount of overtime being advised. Unwillingness to do overtime is perceived as not being a team player.

pros: They hire from within so if you can hold on there are many opportunities to become a driver or other management positions. They try to put you in an area that you enjoy instead of making you work there. They usually try to find people who enjoy the other areas if they need them there. UPS uses Encore to pay for some of your school which is really nice. They also give you free health insurance after a year and it's actually better than any other insurance with other companies.
cons: If you go to management you are out of the union, but for some people that is a pro. If you go to management it's usually because you are in college to become something else because once you are out of the union then you can't become a driver.

pros: UPS has great benefits and plenty of room to career advancement. It's fairly easy to get hired as a package handler, especially during the holiday season.
cons:
Starting pay is very low. Hours can be unpredictable during the holiday season for new hires. The shift I was hired for ran from 2am to 6am. However, during the holiday season I'd often work from 2am to around 2pm. This is great if you're trying to get more hours, but if you have another job or other responsibilities if could become an issue. Several people that I was hired with ended up quitting because our supervisor would not let them leave to go to their other jobs. 

However, I think this was more of an issue with my supervisor and not really a fault of UPS.

pros: Benefits, contractually mandated yearly raise.
cons:
Quantity over quality is the MO here. Push as much volume across the belts as humanly possible, and you'll surely make up for the thousands of packages that are lost / damaged / destroyed in the process every day. Floor Employees are basically treated like equipment; if you can't keep up with a break-neck (and back) pace you will be screamed at by 20 something 'supervisors' who shame most 'weak' young staff into quitting, or you'll face constant write ups for trivial BS.

Audits are a dog and pony show. Supervisors know when they're coming and the show goes on just long enough for the auditors to walk by, then it's back to package smashing as usual.

pros:
ABOUT PACKAGE HANDLING ONLY 

- Pay minimum $2500 a semester for your schooling
- Some schools UPS will pay the entire tuition as long as you receive a C or higher in 
   each class
- Make good friends
- Easy to move up within company
- Builds good work ethic 
- REALLY good heath insurance / 401k plan
cons:
- Have to work holidays, including Christmas (but get triple pay)
- After Thanksgiving you are required to work every single day until the day after 
   New Year's
- Will work you harder than any employer should

pros: No pros to speak of.
cons:
Day 1: Told I would be called by a driver and asked to meet for first day of work. Driver told me he was in a location quite a ways from me. I would have had to drive 45 minutes there and then probably over an hour back during rush hour traffic just to work for 4 hours.
Day 2: I was told I would be assigned to a driver, never happened, no calls
Day 3: I was  assigned to a driver, driver never called, called the coordinator and she said there was a mistake?
Day 4, Day 5, and Day 6: All the same as Day 3, more disappointment.

I ended up finding another job. They texted me asking if I wanted to be assigned to a driver the next day. My reply was "No thank you, I have found employment elsewhere." They assigned me to a driver anyway and the driver called me the next day.

After many phone calls, getting ready for work multiply days for no reason, and constant disappointment,  I never actually got to work.

job_title: Senior Package Handler in Toledo, OH
pros:
+ great benefits in the long term.
+ friendly people/coworkers.
+ job role is very easy once you master the learning curve.
+ freebies once in a while (cooling towel, branded water jug, etc.).
+ decent place to network.
+ promotions come quick to those who show persistence in excellency.
+ you can be late a couple minutes, just don't do it often!
+ low chance people will pry into your belongings even if you leave them in an open spot. the San Bernardino facility has lockers too.
+ my facility supervisors were supportive when I said I got a new job in a different city :)
cons:
- fairly laborious work.
- sometimes people leave the workplace cluttered with trash, sometimes even their own.
- some people may hate you for who your are/ what you look like, even favoritism happens.
- if you work in the sun, you may get sunburns rather quickly.

review_title: UPS delivers when it comes to pay and benefits
job_title: Regular Package Driver in San Bernardino, CA
pros: Pay, stability, excellent benefits, company loyalty, ups brand recognition, ground-up business growth.  Internal recruitment rather than seeking outside talent is crutial to employee loyalty.  UPS is great at maintaining profits in various macroeconomic situations, producing great employment stability.  Plentiful vacation time is essential for employee moral and productivity.  Profits are more equitably shared between employees and stockholders.  Benefits provide excellent source of tax free compensation.
cons: Focus on the numbers game rather than personal accomplishment.  An employee is more than a set of performance numbers.  Top down management needs to be reduced.  Customer service from the 800 phone centers is dreadful.  Relations between management and hourly employees needs improvement.

pros: Benefits are great. Even after changing them, they are still some of the best offered by any employer. Most co-workers are like family. Night hours permit time for doing things during the day. Pay is pretty good.
cons: Some managers are clueless about how to manage their people. They tell you to do something that you are in the process of doing already. Some co-workers are extremely childish and set out to make others miserable. Enforcement of "Zero Tolerance" policies are not very good. Zero tolerance means no tolerance, not a slap on the hand and being told not to do it again. Tuition reimbursement program was dropped for all but part time employees. Benefits were downgraded, so they are only give to new hires after one year.

job_title: Package Handler and Part Time Supervisor in Chelmsford, MA
pros: Great workout. Fast paced. The union takes care of you. I worked for a year and a half in a supervisory role and it worked out well for me -  better pay and less monotonous. It got me through the first year of college, which is what I was there for. If you're in it for a career, going the management route is a gamble. You could rise up the ranks and make great pay with great benefits, but by losing the backing of the strong union you really take a gamble because the company can screw you. If you get hurt they put up roadblocks to acknowledging it. If you stay union you can stay their for life and eventually earn a decent pay, enough to raise a family and it's a very secure job. Your pick.
cons: Hard work. Crappy pay the first couple of years.

pros:
- Industry leading solutions and knowledgeable individuals
- Positive long term growth outlook: eCommerce, international trade 
- Relatively stable work environment
- Learning environment
- Great corporate values
cons:
- Very limited resources for assigned areas of responsibility 
- Multiple hats to wear
- Very little formalized training other than that required for legal compliance (e.g. sexual harassment)
- Below par compensation when compared to peers with similar scopes of responsibility
- Labor contracts exert very strong pressure on company financials, resources made available to non operations personnel

review_title: Hidebound mgmt, low pay for software developers, mgmt distrusts employees
pros: The work is steady, UPS has virtually no competition, and the steady growth of online retail means steady growth for the company.
cons:
Mgmt refuses to pay market-competitive salaries for software developers and is therefore forced to hire contractors to do most of the work. Upper mgmt believes that most software development and support can be off-shored.

A fundamental aspect of company culture is a deep distrust of its own employees. Distribution hub employees are searched as they leave the building after every shift. All employees have to use a productivity-sapping authenticated proxy server just to Google something even if it's job-related.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Horsham, PA
pros: Hey I work for the holiday season as a driver helper for United Parcel Service. Even though I was only a part-time temporary employee I was treated with respect I was asked whether I liked what I was doing where I was working who I was working with. I was taught that position even though I was only a temporary seasonal employee. And the play was great
cons: The only downside working for UPS for me is that I truly love the idea being a UPS driver but you have to wait through seniority for quite a few years and I'm not that young Comet order to obtain the positions

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Tukwila, WA
pros: You will most likely have to meet at a location near where you live. You work with one other person working as a team. This can be a pro or con. Personally the less people the better. IF you're stuck with a strict driver it will make the job stressful. There is a promotion, since it's a seasonal position you get a $200 bonus every week and at the end of December when the job ends you get a $500 dollar bonus. This is only for 2017.  It's probably too late to get a seasonal position with all the bonsues this late
cons: You work until all the packages have been unloaded. It will most likely be over 8 hours everyday especially during the season. You have to be outside in the cold lifting heavy packages. You never know what time you are going to start working or where. They will call you a few hours before.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Earth City, MO
pros: Been working here since October of this year, so not long enough to really get a gist of the whole operation but so far no complaints.  Besides beginning with physical growing pains working a Package loader, my body got used to things and so far so good.  Work week has been Monday through Friday with weekends off, so get plenty of family time.  Very accommodating if you are unhappy with your job.
cons: Late hours of the night, if you are working the night shift from 10pm to 3am.  I wish these hours were a little earlier but I will take what I can get.  Too many men yelling and screaming throughout the building.  Can't bring cellphones in unless you are higher up.  I would like to listen to my own music while I load the packages onto the trucks.

review_title: Great Company, Less Than Desirable Facility
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in New Stanton, PA
pros: Job Security, Pay Rate, Tuition Reimbursement
cons: Under Qualified Management, Hostile Work Environment, Mainly Affirmative Action Hiring

review_title: Good for college kids who need to make money on Christmas Break
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Somerset, PA
pros: I worked part-time as a seasonal helper over Christmas. It's not hard work but is very physically taxing, as well as having to adapt to changing weather conditions. Its nice that you normally don't have to travel very far to meet the driver, and they will drop you off where you want (as long as it isn't out of the way. ) Pay is really good for a part-time job, but be willing to deal with everything. It's also nice if local business owners feel bad and layout free stuff for you to take (snacks, water, etc)
cons: Helpers are paid so well, that their time is dictated by management. You may only work 3-4 hours a day in the first week. More packages = more work.  Also, it can get very hard if your driver isn't very nice/hates what they do.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Hilliard, OH
pros: Workout is the only pro
cons: They do not pay you for the time you work. Call it “human error” even though you have a time card that you swipe in with. They will manually enter employee times at the end of the work day even though you have already swiped with a time card. The managers on the floor are encouraged to change times to make their numbers look good and meet company quotas. Company wide pressure and clock in policy(not using swipe card time) influence the floor managers to willingly and openly rob people of their hard earned hourly pay. Unions pretend to protect you but allow the company to take advantage of new hires, who are unaware of the conditions of pay. You must keep track of all your time on your own and report all discrepancies promptly. It is unbelievable how hard employees work and how often the company steals time and money from its employees. This is the most unjust and corrupt place I have ever had the displeasure of working for. They all should be criminally prosecuted !

review_title: Good job security and environment, Salary not competitive enough
pros: This company has tremendous respect for individuals who are hard-working.  Employees are treated with respect and upper management are fairly competent within their positions.  Job security was not  as much of a concern when I worked there as other companies were going through a series of layoffs during the economic downfall.
cons: Career advancement is very slow to progress with positions taking months to interview for.  However, feedback from upper management makes it seem that patience is key as they are in comfortable positions now even though it took a long time to get there.  Salary is on the low end of the scale for comparable positions elsewhere.  Educational assistance is minimal for employees seeking to obtain advanced degrees.

review_title: UPS has truly helped me mature as a adult, and it has been a very humbling experience.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Grapevine, TX
pros: Great people, good for college, friendly managers and a competitive atmosphere, free insurance and decent pay.
cons: Only part-time no real ability to advance within the company, not really a long term career place their is a little favoritism, and the hours are always changing.

pros:
This was a seasonal position I did for additional side cash. I was able to talk to my managers and supervisors a lot while working. After my manager got to know me and my future plans, was very encouraging of me taking a position with UPS while earning my degree. That it could take me places there and sticking it out while I went to grad school.
-Management and Safety showed concern
-Consistent hours
-Wear anything, however, steel toe is required
cons:

-Was informed workers don't get medical until they've worked for 1 1/2 years and dental and vision after 1 year. (Working seasonal is not included in that)
-When I asked what number do I call if I had an emergency and need to call that I would be running late or to call off, I was told, "Let me give you a tip. Don't call off."

job_title: Driver Helper/Package Handler in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Like a big family


Pacific Coast Benefits Trust (401k)

Medical

Good People

Nice workout

Cosco Pizza

Opportunity to advance quickly to;

Sorter

Floor manager

UPS Driver
cons:

Its an adventure...

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Spokane Valley, Optional[WA]
pros: Good job, with benefits after a year. and tuition assistance. Employees are very friendly in my hub, contributing to an overall positive atmosphere.
cons:
Hard work, when they say stay hydrated, they mean it. 

I have hardly had any hours, only working three days out of two months of employment. 

Work is an as needed basis for new employees for a while until you receive a permanent schedule. So, you may not work frequently in seasons with little demand like Summer. So, don't expect a regular paycheck.

Because I chose the Twilight shift, I have to wait until around 3:50 pm every day to see if I am working on any particular day. This really cuts into time I can do things during the week, especially during my summer vacation time. And, most of the time I call in, I am off work.

pros: Great benefits, weekends off, paid holidays, tons of vacation time, Union for hourly employees, college tuition paid 100%, tons of room for advancement
cons: Long days, Christmas is intense, can be a high stressful work environment, must be in good physical condition, the weight limits on packages can and will be over 150 pounds (people lie about pkg weight on a daily)

pros: Hourly rate, flexible schedule (four shifts), free benefits after a year,  tuition reimbursement while in school, paid classroom training. They're pretty straightforward, during the interview and hiring process, about to cons of this job so you can back out before getting hired
cons: I expected to be working a 5 hr shift, but have only been working a little over 4 hrs per shift, hours are supposed to increase during peak season. Can be dangerous, must be absolutely aware of surroundings. not allowed to have cell phones in the facility. very physical, fast paced work, a con if you don't like manual labor. It can take years to get a full time position, takes a year to get free benefits

pros: Great introduction into leadership from an operations standpoint.
cons:
There really isn't any training, you are essentially asked to babysit but achieve results. I didn't feel like they prepare you to improve those who work under you but merely enough training to try and make it through another day.  
The union vs. non union thing was pretty shocking, and it really highlighted the issues that go along with union type work.  In my opinion that issue prevented a lot of teamwork from happening because it created a selfish grab for a few minutes more pay over developing a team mentality. The management and unions had an us vs them mentality but somehow UPS makes this dysfunctional relationship work.

review_title: Been working at this company for two years and all for them to stab me in the back.
pros: Health benefits are good. I can’t really say much pros but an okay part-time job if you need extra work.
cons: Can be unsafe working conditions, the compensation is horrible for the type and amount of work you do. I was a skilled employee for 1 1/2 years (small sort) then all of a sudden they stripped away my position without a heads up, docked me a dollar from my pay and stuck me in the unload with all the other new hires only to be treated like one. All without warning or notice.

pros: It’s a BIG BIG company
cons: The lack of relevant leadership is an amazing short fall. Managers and senior leaders are Boomers till death. Work is good, you are not. Seasoned boomers ignoring their duty to make the work place better for the workers. You want hot water in the bathroom? Quit being a sissy. You want a beard? No way hippie. You want reasonable and competitive pay? No. You get stock so you own the company. Because as we all know the way to get rich is not to get an honest paycheck but to invest IN ONE STOCK ONLY! Of course every Wall Street billionaire only invests in one stock. Duh. The choice to work here was likely a mistake and there is little future for managers. Union drivers have it made. Great full time benefits, great pay, work can suck a bit but there are good and bad. Supervisors and managers- look elsewhere.

pros:
If you are union:

Pay is decent compared to other entry level jobs
Benefits are amazing (takes 1 yr to earn)
Hub I work at, hard work is appreciated
Job security
Opportunity for advancement if you are a hard worker, punctual, and don't talk back. I moved up from pkg handler to p/t sup. F/T jobs are rare but out there if you are willing to move.
cons:
Union dues (about $40 a month for package handlers) but the medical, dental, vision benefits are amazing and included for free. Non-union benefits suck compared to union but are better than nothing!
Other union employees are lazy, especially tenured employees.
Only big hubs have tuition reimbursement
Low hours (pkg handlers work about 15-18 hrs a week)

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Memphis, TN
pros: If your in college this a great way to go. Insurance is always nice to have when you are young and sometimes dumb. All the other benefits here really provide some nice options when you finish with school. And in the summer you can pickup an extra job if needed for extra cash. A lot of the older guys run there own bushiness in my hub and don't mind extra hands in the summer. There could also be opportunities to drive package cars also.
cons: Its hard work to most people, but if do your stretches and preserve your body you can turn it in a workout.

job_title: Plant Engineering Specialist in Louisville, KY
pros: People I work with are great. You get pay well for what you do. They do a tuition reimbursement program for bachelor's degree.
cons: The job I have was misleading in its representation. I was lead to believe this was more of engineering job when it wasn't. You are an alarm caller who sits behind a computer all day. Mechanics have more power to change the area then you do. There isn't very many opportunities for promotion. Because there isn't a lot of promotions or upward movement there is a lot of veterans workers doing the same work making 20 or 30,000 more then you. Raises aren't based on performance they are based on years.

pros: Great benefits... Health, dental, vision.  Paid holidays.  Tuition reimbursement.  Raises every 6 months or year, depending on union contract.  Great job if you were hired in the 70's and have high seniority.
cons: Starting pay is low.  One year of employment before benefits and holiday pay kick in.  Typically takes years and years before having opportunity for full time.  Since it is Union, it is all about senority.  For the most part, it is a job for younger people.  The job really takes its toll on the body.  sink or swim mentality when it comes to package driving training.  If you can't perform under pressure right off the bat, they will weed you out fast.  Very stressful on mind and body.

job_title: Part Time Operations Management Supervisor in Columbus, OH
pros:
Job security - the business is still growing so job security is a big plus
Fast paced - day to day tasks may be the same but there is always something different happening
Benefits - Health insurance plans are fairly good however the best part is the retirement plan as well as the paid education
cons: Constant and unrealistic changes in the metrics used to determine how a center is doing. Corporate seems to be out of touch with what actually works and what its employees need to do their job well. There is also a big disconnect between management and union members, its a constant battle and in this position there is a lot of middle man mentality.

job_title: Sunrise Package Handler in Rapid City, SD
pros: No more wearing the customer service face. Burn a TON of calories. Paid workout if you're inclined to keep a positive outlook. Hours usually end by 9 to 9:30 so they leave the rest of my day till 8pm open for second job, school, whatever.
cons: You'll always be up in the dark. Everyday.  I've been worked to death before. The pace around these hubs is insane. Most normal people cannot hack it. Big and strong doesn't mean you'll be able to get the job done better. It's all about speed, efficiency, and being willing to  work your butt off for what will definitely seem like not enough pay. You'll have to have your own reasons, like the b benefits or the workout factor to want to do that job beyond your 30 days. New hires drop like flies.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Roswell, GA
pros:
The website is easy to use and there are many resources for employees
Training is easy and painless
cons:
The interview was a joke- only asked me if I was legal to work in the US. 
No one contacted me after the interview even though I filled out all of the paperwork and gave them my availability. 
I had to call 7-8 other people before I could even speak to my own manager.
My manager was super condescending and rude.
I have yet to get a shift and I was hired a week ago. 
No one ever knows what is going on and the place is completely disorganized.

pros: The culture within the company is big on ownership and internal promotion, which is how it should be in any large corporation.  The benefits are very generous, 401k match is good too.  Management is trained on how to handle many situations.  There is no limit to sick time off and short term disability is 6 months at 100%.  Open door policy is real (not just words on a page).
cons: Pay seems to be below industry rates within IT.  Many of the workers within the company are contract, even though they aren't brought on for any specific contract but moreso for employee style work. Changing this over would likely save the company money and greatly improve morale.

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Earth City, MO
pros: Bad to mediocre employees are rewarded better than hard workers, if you don't plan on getting a college degree this is the ideal place to earn more than those with college degrees
cons: Everything, treats employees as if they don't matter.  6 years with more than one bachelors' degree but yet can't get a full-time position because of internal politics.  HR hiring personnel plays favoritism on hiring process.  They call you for interview as a formality but already hired someone for the position your interviewing for.  Upper management gives you false hopes of promotion, positions open up within your department, but they hire someone with no qualifications, and they pretend as if they don't see you for a few weeks then start approaching you again.  Opportunity to advance depends on who likes you or who you hang out with outside, educational background or qualifications don't matter.  They are extremely political especially in MO.

pros: Competitive pay, free health, vision and dental insurance, pension plans, 401K plans. The people are fun to work with and it is a decent environment for the most part.
cons: Some of the challenges of working at UPS include the physical stress it puts on your body over the years. You can be a hero for the first few years if you start out young, but it will eventually catch up to you. And management can be hard to deal with when they decide that they want to cut people early in order to save a few bucks; which, in turn, causes more stress on the pre-loaders left to do the work.

pros: 100 % Healthcare, 70% Dental, vision, Hard work keeps you strong so it usually isn't necessary but nice benefit to have.
cons: Offer you all this great lies, get you to quit your job and work for them,  then don't pay you.

review_title: At Lo get last,  I am blessed to be not only an honored employee of such a ideal company,  I really love my job!
pros: It is hard work,  no,  it is a blessing to get paid (earn wages)  just to do what I do and I totally have had previous customer service jobs.  Those times of a dreadful longest 8hours are in the past.  To God be the glory, Great things he hath done.
cons:
None come to mind.  Truly a blessing.  To work for UPS!  
MY dreams and aspirations are to advance in the company and I will definitely be a great driver some day,  that is,  if it is my Heavenly Father's will. 🙌🤲🙏

review_title: UPS  is sacrificing its soul for a stock price that's going nowhere quickly.
pros: There is good job security. The insurance is pretty good but may be getting worse for management people.
cons: What other company has its management employees making less money than the employees? This is comparing yearly salaries versus hourly wages for the year and not by the hour. If comparing by the hour the difference is far worse yet. The insurance benefits are relatively good for management but not as good as for the employees. It's great to promote minorities, but the company will overlook very qualified white males in order to promote someone who isn't necessarily qualified.

pros: high pay... positive accounts of work environment
cons: seasonal work is erratic at best, some employees show up at hiring sessions raving about cleaning up w/ 3k in the one month after hiring, in reality however only a few employees get full time after black friday, they make jokes about how sick you will be of delivering packages etc, they're lying if you get a position as a seasonal worker at UPS get another job while you're waiting for that beloved NEVER COMING call they inferred you would but not legally would get.

review_title: Great place to work for job experience and training, don't work if you want to make a career.
pros: Great Benefits, Pay is higher than most, oppotunites to move up to a certain point, education reimbursement, meet a lot of people.
cons: Non-flexible schedule, managers treat supervisors poorly sometimes and like to blame them for their own mistakes. Once you reach a certain point, it is extremely hard to move up in the company. Seniority rules all in this company, if your an hourly worker you have to wait YEARS before you can go full time or be a driver. The Union is a little excessive in this company, its Union workers against managment all the time.

pros: The job is good if you love hard work and a work out. They pay is ok to begin with. And if you get to stay the benifits are one of kind and best from any company.
cons: The supervisor have a total lack of care for thier employees. They can bearly keep track of who works for them or not. And they all will treat you like crap if you are not apart of the union. Never distrub a manager towards the end of thier shift. You have to put your self out there and ask the supervisor everyday about your progress in the company if you want to stay full time. If you don't watch they will mess up you're pay check.

pros: The raises and benefits are great, although they about to change this year. UPS and the state is currently paying for just about all of the costs of my bachelor's degree! The company usually shows a decent concern for its employees, and the union helps when you know your supervisor is overstepping their boundaries.
cons: It's way too difficult to get anything fixed and when it does get fixed it may take a very long time for it to get fixed. The union will not allow anyone to be judged on the quality of their work or their attendance so you have some people who are extremely lazy doing nothing while someone else picks up their slack. I feel like that makes you really frustrated.

review_title: UPS has demonstrated great value and vision towards the future.
pros: Each day is challenging and different. I actually look forward to coming to work and happily arrive early or stay late. Management above me gives me goals to meet that are attainable and rewarding. This company looks to promote from within and rarely hires outside. There is huge room for growth in this company and in coming years there will be a lot, I mean A LOT of positions opening up in upper management.
cons: If you are looking for a job that gives you the same task without variables everyday this isn't for you. Also, though there are different shifts to work throughout the day, some people burnout on the nights as supervisors because they cannot cope with the scheduling.

review_title: Opportunity to form the building blocks for your career
pros: Tuition Reimbursement and the entry level experience to management that you gain. This is a commodity that you can add to your resume and take to any company.
cons: There is rampant culture of disrespect that festers with hub managers. Hub managers and full-time supervisors believe that instilling fear within the employees, Union and Non-Union, is the only way to accomplish their production goals. This is why so many part-time supervisors that obtain bachelors degrees from accredited universities choose to leave the company once their tuition reimbursement has expired or the graduate from college.

review_title: UPS Inside Sales - San Antonio, TX
pros:
The application is a multi-step process but really nothing difficult.

I'm very pleased with my new opportunity with UPS. 

Currently I am half way through my training and have nothing but positive things to say about UPS. 
The training process is 6 weeks and very well organized with a lot of interaction between your colleagues.
The training coaches are really awesome people who are wiling to help you learn and answer any doubts you have.

Oh the benefits are great and very affordable.
The work schedule is perfect 8-5 or 9-6 for inside sales.
cons:
1. PARKING - I hike a mile to get to and from the building.
BUT lets stay positive, I will eventually shed some lbs.

2. ATTIRE - Attire is not business casual its professional attire.
No boat shoes, No Jeans, etc.

3. PARKING - Did I mention that there is limited parking?

review_title: Great place to work through school.
pros:
You can work a set schedule so there's no guessing.  A variety of shifts available to fit your school schedule.  Lots of opportunity for overtime around the holiday season.  I enjoyed my time with this company and will consider going back to work for them again.
Also, UPS provides some of the best health insurance you can get.
cons: This is supposed to be a tobacco free workplace, but there are a lot of people who use chewing tobacco and they spit it all over the place with no regard to other people.  Also, it is a warehouse so it is very dirty, but that is to be expected.

review_title: UPS 1st, Customers 2nd, Employees 3rd:  Bureaucratic, Big Business, and Bad Communication
job_title: Operations Management Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Good pay for part time, decent benefits, and fast paced work (if you like that type of atmosphere).
cons: Bad communication, no one knows what is going on from the top to bottom.  Numbers, numbers, numbers, numbers....the most important thing at UPS.  UPS can do no wrong, customers are generally wrong, and employees don't care.  That's the the UPS way.  Training is laughable, the term that comes to mind is "thrown in the fire".  If you are full time, they own you.  Left on own terms.

pros: Part time (union) employees make out like bandits with great pay and full benefits for only the cost of union dues.  Short hours allow you to have another job or attend school without too much conflicting and usually one or both will work with your prior obligations.
cons: Dealing with new hires that are improperly trained and having to go back through their work and fix it.  Having supervisors constantly breathing down your neck and accusing you of sabotaging the company and work being done.

pros: The benefits are still very good, although they seem to get a little less good every year.
cons: Management is apathetic and no one seems to care about the company, let alone employees. In fact, management actively provokes adversarial relations with the union. Working conditions are terrible. Picture 98 degrees, 95%k humidity and they don't even care if the water fountains work for the laborers. In addition, they give safety lip service but don't do anything to actually make the place safe. If you just want a pay check and don't care at all about other people or making a quality contribution to your company, then UPS is the perfect place for you. I kept hoping it would get better, but it did not.

pros: Amazing health insurance that you don't have to pay for. Discounts from various stores. Get a raise every year. It being really early in the morning makes it a good job if you are going to college. Dress how you want and can to some extent say what you want when you are talking with other coworkers as there are no customers around.
cons: Really hard on your body. Need to go to the gym to stay fit or all your joints will be busted up. You work at a warehouse where when its cold outside its cold inside and when its hot outside its hotter inside. They don't give new part time supervisors enough training. There can sometimes be a large disconnect between supervisors and workers.

job_title: Operations Management/Safety Supervisor/Trainer in Reno, NV
pros: Health care benefits better than most, tuition paid up front for management, generally stable company with decent wages
cons: Being a member of management makes you a scapegoat. You can't hold the union employees accountable for anything so you are yelled at to fix an unfixable situations. Benefits are good, but keep getting worse. The  bargaining unit employees get better benefits and ultimately better wages, not really the best way to treat members of management who have put company first,  not the union. Union stewards act like they run the place and fight to keep the worst scum employed. If you are worthless, unemployable, and generally lack ethics, you can find a place at ups, as long as you pay your union dues

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in San Antonio, TX
pros:
As of 2015, the pay for the seasonal position has gone up, so the pay is good.
Flexible hours. If you have a part time job, let them know, and they'll work with your schedule.
Weekly paycheck.
cons:
Promised at orientation that they'll place you in your zip code, but usually don't.
Hours are never constant.
Sometimes ask you to meet drivers at far away/hard to get to places.

review_title: Its an awesome place to work....i am seasonal now, but boss has made it clear ill get permanent pos. Inside hub.
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Rockford, IL
pros: I was hired at a great starting wage plus plenty of overtime everyday over 8hrs I worked. The supervisors are great.you get foot in foot for permanent spot.
cons: Just that I wish I didn't have to start a job and get to know most of the drivers as a driver helper seasonal and be great at it and love my job and then it has to stop and you start over for a permanent spot.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Earth City, MO
pros: Most the people are cool and work hard, even the managers help when they are needed, which is a rare site to see.
cons: The pay is just horrible for the amount of work you have to do, even with them paying for some of my schooling.  If you can't go to school because of a second job, your just completely screwed.  It's no wonder the turn over rate is so high, I feel like I headed towards quitting, just not worth the headache and you have to wait a year and a half to get medical insurance for your family, that's crazy.

pros: Good pay after 4-5 years, good benefits after 1 year, unionized
cons: High stress, high workload. Work overtime every day regardless of any other factors. Takes months of practice to get up to an acceptable pace. Constantly pushed to maximize productivity which means, no breaks, and no lunch. If you take breaks you fall behind. If you don't move as fast as humanly possible every minute of the day, you fall behind. Customers are slow to answer the door or shipping docks are slow, you fall behind. If you finish early you have to help others who are too far behind. If it is a slow day, you don't work a short day, they cut shifts and overload those working. Have to fight for dollies even though every truck has large, oversized, over-weight, or multiple package deliveries.

job_title: Seasonal Package Handler in Dulles, VA
pros: Very understanding management, even though the work is demanding. Oh! And that's another thing! The workload is physically labor intensive, meaning you're getting a heck of a workout throughout the day! Also, the work is relatively simple, albeit repetitive, which is remedied by your interactions with your coworkers.
cons: Management puts the newbies with the pros, which can really clutter everything unnecessarily sometimes. Not only that, but the hours are absolutely horrific during peak season if you have any other jobs or school. DO NOT enter this job in peak season if you're also in school! That said, the work can get a bit demanding if anyone has to leave the shift early.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in East Petersburg, PA
pros: Hard to think of
cons: UPS management lacks basic communication between staff and thinks it is okay to tell every single driver helper to show up to the office only to have absolutely zero course of action on where to distribute them. On several occasions, the driver helpers show up only to have more than 75% of them be sent home due to the lack of drivers available to help. Do not work here and waste your time, find another job where you can actually work

review_title: Pensioned employee mentality but no more pension
job_title: Community Manager II in Atlanta, GA
pros: UPS is a strong, stable company that isn’t going anywhere. You get the opportunity to learn a broad array of positions of your career and many of the people are great to work with.
cons: They seem to think no one will leave and treat you that way. No flexibility in my work group for work-from-home, many directors micromanage but also only care about developing their own careers rather than their people.

pros: Customers, weekly pay, driving around
cons: Management, lack of work, purposeful misleading of applicants, unsupportive atmosphere.

review_title: Best Transportation Company in the world sucks to sell at
job_title: Senior Account Executive in Parsippany, NJ
pros: No lack of work. Check will always clear.  You will have a secure retirement.
cons:
Sales people are managed like the union drivers without the benefits of the union.  Real money made on stock which has been struggling since they went public in 1999.

No lack of work; As an Account Executive you will be responsible for winning new business, retaining current volume and revenue (by product), ALL CUSTOMER SERVICE (as support is inadiquate), holding the drivers hands for leads, get the operation to pick-up the accounts on time, deliver late air, shovel out letter centers and documents everything but how many times you went to the bathroom in their CRM.

job_title: Instructional Designer Supervisor in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Nice Corporate Building
Clean Bathrooms
Decent food
cons: I work in the HR Training Department. I have never worked with so many insecure, incompetent men in my life. This place is all about rank. Supervisors are not allowed to eat with Specialist or Admin. The cafeteria is like a high school lunch room. You literally see people eating with their clicks. They have a policy book which no one adheres to. Pay is HORRIBLE...you get to keep half of your bonus in cash and the other half goes into stock. Micro Managing to the max...the minimum work hour is 55 hours...and the pay is not competitive. SAD, SAD, SAD!!!

pros: Good pay, dollar raise every three months, a lot of advancement opportunity, great benefits, and good hours depending on who you are.
cons: Starting pay is not high enough to keep people, management constantly contradicts themselves, a lot of stress because you are expected to perform flawlessly no matter the amount of work you are given, and you are expected to be able to perform any job on your shift even if it is not your job title or you have not received any training in that area.

job_title: Preload Supervisor in Commerce City, CO
pros: You can learn a lot here, lots of technology and brilliant solutions to difficult problems if you know where to look. Unique company culture that is difficult to understand but can be very effective
cons: Not much recognition. Too much hypocrisy.  Not much support for professional growth. VERY POOR TURNOVER!

review_title: Great company to work for, especially if you're pursuing further education.
job_title: Part Time Operations Supervisor in Chicago, IL
pros: Steady Part-time hours with an excellent tuition benefits program was what sold me on UPS. Great for recent high school grad. students looking to work and attend college. Because of their tuition assistance program, I was able to earn a four-year business degree without having to be in the hole $70,000. Opportunity, opportunity, opportunity. Majority of promotions for management or driver positions are done in house. Work hard, get noticed, and you'll be taken care of. Was promoted to pt/ supervisor within a year of working there hourly as a sorter. Other benefits for part-time and full-time employees include 401-k match, stock options, bonuses, PTO, health, vision, dental, and many,many  more.
cons: Physically demanding. Mediocre pay but still good college students. Highly advise seeking promotion to management or driving ASAP, depending on your own objectives.

review_title: everything you've heard about it being an old boys network is true
pros: good benefits, some departments are flexible with schedules
cons: pay is pretty low for the industry; I've known several people to leave my group and nearly double their salaries. It can be impossible to get things accomplished with the level of reviews, and don't even think about trying to make a change. Decisions are often made on a whim, with a "because I said so" mentality by upper management, which doesn't work in a company this large. If you can't drink the kool aid and play the game, you will not be happy here.

pros: UPS is a great place to be employed, but it is a miserable place to work. They have really good benefits and a schedule that is very well suited to college students. One great thing is, when I left work, i didn't think about work until it went in the next day. I never got a call on my day off. Holidays are pretty generous.
cons: Management is very aggressive. There is dissonance between the union and management. Management can make or break the experience. I worked there over five years both in the morning and for a time on the evening shift. Evening was much better. The stress just wasn't as high.

pros: Once you hit top rate it is very generous with great benefits. Pension,  401k,  medical, dental, vision, prescription. Earn descent paid time off.
cons: Work long hours. Less than 10 hours a day is rare. Constantly being monitored. Must be on A game at all times. So many rules you feel like if you fart the wrong way you'll get terminated. Where waged are a pro it is also a con. Currently making $34/hr with some change and you will be expected to bust your rear earning every cent of that. This job is not for the weak and you can expect to not gave a family life. This is why I'm leaving. Family is way more important to me.

pros: The main reason people start working, and stay working at UPS is generally because they have an amazing healthcare benefits package, but part-time employees must wait a year for eligibility.
cons:
It feels like military boot camp all-over again...
Culture and environment within the hub (Greensboro) is full of yelling, swearing, and general negativity. 
You could work your tail off and hit 1200 packages an hour, but it still won't be good enough. 
You are constantly told you are not doing good enough, no matter what your production number are.  I know, because I called my trainer out on it, and he laughed and admitted it. 
They give you all kinds of great rules regarding safety and work methods, but go ahead and throw them all out the window once you start working, because all they care about is speed.

pros: UPS was a really great place to work as I was able to accumulate experience in a leadership role and learn valuable leadership skills on hours that fit my busy graduate school schedule.
cons: Although I was able to work at this job during my academic career at Colorado State University, working during the night shift eventually took a toll on my academic performance and I decided to step down as supervisor to focus on graduate school.

pros:
-Strong skills improvement focus from direct manager
-Fast paced work environment
-Semi-Salary + OT chances (esp. around winter holidays)
-2 Weeks of Vacation with 5 more PTO days that can be set at request
cons:
-Insulting annual raises don't cover inflation (<1% ($0.18) on average over 3 years
-Large paperwork load combined with average of 8 miles of walking per day (via fitbit) as well as large amount of expected grunt work

pros:
Tuition Assistance for local schools
Above average wages
Excellent "stepping stone"
Variable hours with extensive hours during holiday season (around November through January)
Overtime after 8 hours a day or 40 hours a week (1.5X)
Double  time on most holidays with paid time off option (2X)
cons:
Moderately stressful
Long hours during holiday season listed above (12-16 hours most days during this period)
Tight time schedules for daily production.
Limited employee input to upper management.

review_title: Logistics Company That's Behind the Times
pros: The people I got to work with kept me there longer than the company actually did. The benefits are OK - on par with other employers in the space. Getting to see the logistics business from the "inside" was pretty cool.
cons: Because the company was built on internal hiring and promoting, there are lots of people there who stifle growth and innovation. As a young professional who joined the company with hopes of learning from the seasoned professionals already there, I left having learned very little because those people were so dedicated to maintaining status quo.

review_title: Logistics Company That's Behind the Times
