review_title: the realism of a  ups driver
pros: the salary and the health benifits
cons: it is a vrry physically demanding labor intenion job , with very long hours for ups package car and feeder divers like myself which takes very valueble and important time away from the family life. also we never shut down due to weather of any extreme . also trying to get permission to get time off is often denied . when package car drivers need help on a route we rarely receive any or none at all. often times working during our1 hour of lunch time, which time we are required to take each day by our collective bargining contract agreement

review_title: I enjoy the physical demands and opportunities to do more than expected.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Earth City, MO
pros: The work is physically demanding, the hours are adequate, and the tuition reimbursement is ideal for students. I get paid to exercise and go to school!
cons: The work can be extremely challenging in the summer and winter; very few employees enjoy their work, which shows in their performance; and many supervisors could develop their people skills to improve their interactions with subordinates and other supervisors.

review_title: Good compensation for a young person, behind the times thinking by upper management
job_title: Senior Account Manager in Parsippany, NJ
pros: Earned six figures as a young professional, excellent benefits, and significant room for growth.
cons: Wall Street likes FedEx's stock better than UPS's for a reason.  UPS has been around over 100 years and is the 500lb guerilla in the room.  They're a great company but are so large that they are either resistant to change because they either 1) can't change or 2) don't feel the need to change.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Portland, OR
pros: The characters, the union, the good exercise, the optional competition, the relaxed work environment. One of my co-workers pulled a prank on the supervisor and everyone just laughed. It was very down to earth and friendly.
cons: Getting moved from belt to belt. I personally like knowing who I'm working with and what I'm doing before I go into work. Most of the time, UPS offered this predictability. However, because of the unpredictable nature of the shipping industry, UPS will often shuffle people from belt to belt, changing the work environment. Some belts are just miserable to work on as well. Doesn't seem like there's any solution, just a part of the job. Working nights is pretty lame as well tho.

review_title: Very diverse company that will allow you the opportunity if you train yourself!
pros: Very fast atmosphere. Company moves you into different positions to allow you to never get bored. Also allows you to figure out what you enjoy and to groom you to understand all sectors of the business. Job stability, company has been around for years and continuously growing in untapped markets.
cons: You have little to no training. Literally there is no one there once you start that new position that they place you in. You will have to fish for information or have a trial and error. In which if you don't perform you will not receive a raise from what they consider your "QPR" (Quality Performance Rating). Average pay rate is for someone fresh out of college and looking to stay with a company for a very long time.

review_title: Overall it was a good experience. Dispatchers, while overworked and sometimes stressed, were always helpful.
pros: Great hourly rate. Very easy to apply. Very quick interview. If you have a clean record you're pretty much hired on the spot.
cons: On call and expect to work only one or 2 nights (if you're lucky) a week until after thanksgiving. After thanksgiving you can really bank in some money with lots of overtime(not a con). Trainers were a nightmare. Horrible first 2 weeks! I was borderline harassed by very unprofessional trainers. On a separate note, Indy 81st is completely congested and very intimidating for new drivers. Too much variety of work, including yard mule.

pros: Everyone I worked with was happy and a joy to work with.  The management at UPS is helpful and  easy to work with.  Overall, the job tasks are fairly easy.  For the most part, you will correct shipping addresses, handle damaged packages, and deal with will-call packages.
cons: The Long hours during the busy season in November and December. You have a set number of packages to get through every day and you are pushed to complete it in as fast a manner as possible. At times, the job can become monotonous.

review_title: Longest part time job you'll have
job_title: Frontline Supervisor in Baldwin Park, CA
pros:
-Great pay
-Have to start from bottom to move up
-Community and fellow loaders turn into family if not great friends
-Great atmosphere and union somewhat takes care of you
cons:
-Threat type work force 
-No life work hours again great pay
-MASS amount of brown nosing to move up in management
-Union only fights for you because of money most of them are just snobs and dont deserve their place they save the people that should be without a doubt be fired 75% of the time
-No management union

job_title: P/T Management; Driver; Pre-loader in Paris
pros: Decent benefits if you have an opportunity to use them.   Company on firm financial footing.  Focus on safety.
cons: Few full-time positions.   Many part-time positions where one is ground up and exhausted beyond a typical full-time position elsewhere.  Safety tends to go out the window in pursuit of  performance metrics - esp. during peak season.  Time off unavailable during peak season.  strict appearance guidelines.  antiquated training videos.  union positions pushed excessively by management.  management pushed excessively by upper management.  Decent as a delivery driver if you are young with limited alternatives for non-college-degree positions, and you plan on making it a career.  Ok for management , though you will be moved from location to location often, if you can secure a full-time position.  Don't even think of taking a job as minimum wage p/t preloader.  See YouTube videos on that position.  They are accurate.  You've been warned.

review_title: Fair compensation but very mundane work with a tough path for promotion
pros: Compensation was very competitive for the area and industry. First 6 months were spent on an educational team that included travelling and workshops. Was given a lot of responsibility very quickly. A great company if you are willing to stick it out for the first 4-5 years. You will never lose your job here.
cons: Very political and bureaucratic. Hard to get exposure and have your ideas heard. Tons of competition for promotion since there are about 20 people fighting for the same promotion every year. Teams are spread far away. Hardly every meet your boss if you arent in the same building as them. Work became repetitive and mundane very quickly. The 3 month leading up to New years are hell. Expect 70- 80 hour work weeks during this time.

review_title: Used to be a great company to work for...
pros:
job security
growth
compensation
partnership within management
great training
opportunity to travel
cons:
Management is old school and doesn't seem too see the need to change
Sales compensation is difficult to understand and even harder to hit
There used to be a reason to put up with long hours, hard work, and impossible expectations but with the new structure (no pension, benefit cut backs, changes  in management incentive plan), the new young people don't have the same reason to make it a career.

review_title: High level Sales/Consulting role in Fortune 50 company
job_title: Senior Account Executive in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-Access to C-Level Executives at major companies
-Incredible work flexibility
-Very adequate compensation with a stong base
-Rewarded for having unique strategies
-The ability to truely affect positively the outcome of someones business
-Job Security - People will always need to move packages and we're the worlds largest logistics company
cons:
-Work hours slightly above average
-Luck plays a role in success
-Very rigid structure for procedurs
-The company is so large you dont feel like you can make an impact
-Internal systems are scattered and not fully integrated which causes disorganization
-For record profits occuring frequently, the company can be extremely frugal

review_title: I was expected to meet dangerous and unreasonable standards incentivized only by competition.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Portland, OR
pros: Decent benefits, after a few decades you might be a driver making decent money
cons: Dealing with unreasonable volume per period of time.  I moved about 30,000 pounds per night five nights a week, and often boxes would pile up.  Co-workers drank energy drinks or did coke and let their definition of manliness influence them to break their bodies in the name of competitive labor productivity.  I was trying to go at a rate that I felt was less threatening to my body, tried to be aware of my posture and physical procedure, but after two months I got shooting pains in my shoulders and wrists.

review_title: Hard work, but great for college students.
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Dallas, TX
pros: I've never had a job that allowed as much flexibility as UPS. The benefits are the best out there! There is plenty of room for promotion and experience. You get paid to workout. They don't drug test. Hours during peak season are practically unlimited. There are various shift options depending on the location.
cons: There is heavy workload daily. Compensation could be better for the amount of work you do. It is a union job, so you have issues with fellow employees showing up to work. The promotion process could use some more organization. Upper management can be very rude and inconsiderate towards their workforce.

pros: There are many positives to working at UPS such as good benefits, 80 hours of PTO/year, shift selection based on performance, and we don't work any weekends or Federal holidays.
cons: Current management does not care about agents as individuals, everyone is just a number. As such, we are not allowed to express our individuality. We follow their dress code, have to hide our tattoos, body jewelry, and your hair color has to be UPS approved. Management is a good ole boys club and they protect their own.

pros: Great benefits and a great pay rate, also a lot of different things offered when acquiring Union status. You also get a raise every 3 months
cons: Crappy hours, their method in thier preloading department is horrible they implement a better system and I have a good couple million ideas that will help. The supervisors treat you like slaves. They try to fill your head with lies that if you work hard you become a supervisor but it never happens ever

pros: Great company if you're part time and going to school, Paid tuition and steady hours.  The company offers competitive pay and good benefits for their full time positions.  Great place to start a career.
cons: Very specific skill set required for most operations related jobs.  The hours are very demanding both the amount and at what times of day.  There is a lot of circumstances that you have very little control of and getting other operations to work with you seems to fall on deaf ears.

pros: A lot of potential for teaching you a management skillet at a big league employer.   You are in the belly of the beast and other employers will see this and pick you.
cons:
• Cut-throat management (treated like garbage for not hitting impossible numbers)
• You are not allowed to move back to union positions such as Brown-Truck Driver due to your nonunion position (I was denied for 3 years and my friend had less time(reg package handler union employee) at UPS- he was given the position I was trying to get)

pros: Still have really good benefits, dental, vision, and health only cost monthly union dues which is twice the pay rate deducted first paycheck of each month.
cons: Must gain seniority to be called in frequently. Without consistently working can not get benefits. Must be able to constantly lift packages with varying weights up to 150 pounds. The pay is no longer competitive, they haven’t adjusted to new wage increases so they have fallen behind on appropriate pay rates. Expect a lot for minimum wage and hard work usually goes unnoticed. They have been coasting off their name and reputation, use to be great company to work for but now have fallen behind.

pros: Short hours, occasional overtime pay, an extra dollar per hour for loading position, good workout, stable job that is unionized and can lead to great benefits and pay if you stay for several years.
cons: Very early in the morning (Started at apprx. 4am), management tends to push workers harder than average (even for a warehouse position), just like with many warehouse jobs injury can come easily if you´re not always alert and cautious. Hard on the body in general in the long run.

review_title: UPS stole over 20 thousand dollars  from me
pros: If you want just a job with UPS, always get a UNION job, never a non-union job. The UNION people make more money than the people that supervise them.
cons: Last minute change for employees about to retire.  All vacations and discretionary days were paid out on retirement year only.  After 33 years of service, all the time off with pay was denied.  The 20 thousand came from roughly two months of pay times two.  They took the time and the money.  This has affected hundreds of employees that have given blood, sweat and tears for this ruthless company.  How am I supposed to continue going into work with a smile on my face?

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: UPS is a great company to work for. Job security is not even an issue. You know the senior management team in Atlanta is solid and knows how to steer the company through a resession. The company is over 100 years old so they have weathered many storms. The benefits are among the top in the industry, and there are plenty of advancement opportunities if you commit yourself to the company.
cons: They demand a lot of your time. You often work overtime and don't get paid. You are expected to work hard no matter what. You must deliver results. Anything less than plan is unacceptable.

review_title: Great job, but takes a really long time to get where you want to be.
pros: Health benefits even for part time employees.  Also paid vacations and a great retirement package.  Keeps you energetic and in shape because you are always moving.  Driving days go by fast because you are working against the clock at all times, not staring at it.  Also you are in the union.
cons: The main thing is you really have to be committed if you want to get full time.  At my center, it takes right around ten years just to get full time!  Every thing is by seniority due to the union, so sometimes the wrong people win the job that you surely are more qualified to do.  So, a pro and a con-you're in the union.

pros: It sounds as if you can move up in the organization quickly after your 30 day testing period. Good people who are working very hard to see that you get your packages.
cons: Everyone has to start as a loader or unloader. The work is brutal on your body. You think doing reps at the gym is tough, this is 4lb-100lb packages loaded every 8 seconds for 4-5 hours with a 10 minute break for $10 an hour. The equipment that you use is poorly designed and worn out.

pros: Friendly people, short workdays, benefits are great if you stick around a year.  Promotes from within, If you can stand the BS youll move up fast.
cons: Very fast paced, hard physical labor, low pay, and on top of that you have to pay the union 20 bucks a month.  Muscle soreness is a regular thing for me now.  Not a good job for people with anxiety, I have seen two people have anxiety attacks at work and one lash out at a supervisor and quit, all in 3 months.  Sometimes it can really feel like slave labor.

review_title: Great Company of you're willing to be in it for the long run
job_title: Part Time Package Center Supervisor in Jackson, MS
pros: Great company with yearly raises, reasonable insurance, education assistance and, great work life balance.
cons: Very hard to transfer or apply for different jobs. Immediate managers have the last say so in promotions and transfers. Managers will expect you to work off the clock with no paid overtime.

pros: One of the best benefits, paid vacations including optional weeks that you can work and get two checks for, disabilities and other perks.
cons: It can be very hectic. Boxes are everywhere and many loaders who pulls the boxes off the conveyor belt get really backed up. Supervisors would see and not do anything about it most of the time. It can get really hot inside a trailer that has been sitting in the sun all day. The sorters would mess up on the sorting, stack the belt when it's off, and place box's labels upside down.

pros: Some supervisors were friendly and organized. Provides good experience in safe loading/lifting methods and hazmat safety routines.
cons: Job was for "holiday help," (as calling anything "seasonal" violated their contract with the union). Work, as expected, was grueling physical labor that could put anyone not physically "cut out" for the job out of commission from the pain and exhaustion introduced to their body. Package handlers were set to on-call, but they were required to call into the company themselves every morning instead of visa versa.  Manager wanted package handlers to keep calling in long after the holidays ended, only to give them no work and never tell them they were laid off. Work opportunities are offered from within the company, often taking 7-9 years to work up from a package handler to a truck driver.

pros: Excellent health insurance, but must wait a year and a half to add dependents.
cons:
Pre-Loader is a misnomer.  You are actually loading the delivery trucks

Not even a place to hang your coat

Very dangerous work environment, employees constantly getting hurt.  We got doughnuts during break if we went a week without an injury - during my time there we only got doughnuts twice.  That's how bad it was.

Supervisors constantly in your face asking safety questions which distract you and causing misloads.

One break, most of which taken by supervisor telling employees how bad they are doing.

Verbally abused by manager, union rep didn't help at all.  Very worst company I have ever work for.

Extremely high turnover rate.  Only hope is to wait for a driver position, which hundreds are waiting for.

pros: Great benefits package, union resolved all problems. Getting paid to work out.
cons: Management is mostly young kids who advanced the ranks. Stress and rapid environment leads Management on edge and at times berate employees. I was forced into a new position when I requested not to by a manager, and once I started on the new position, I wasn't given the updated pay scale until I had union fight to give me my money. Experience is limited to the managers at the Saddle Brook branch, but I did enjoy the work.

review_title: A disappointment to say the least
pros: Global Company with deep pockets to invest
cons: Poor management in Ireland. Mostly dragged in from abroad made up of individuals who dont understand the Irish market. There is a real arrogance and are in love with their own Hype. UPS Europe is the poor cousin of UPS America and UPS Ireland is the poor cousin of UPS Europe.  Yet they think are big players when really they are not. UPS Ireland will ruin what was good about Nightline if they have not already. They believe they can do as they see fit with customers. Its Links Pt2 - death by politics. DPD, TNT, DHL, Fastway must all be laughing at prospects for 2018.

job_title: Delivery Driver in League City, TX
pros: Great company to work for
cons: Hot outside no A/C

review_title: Decent pay and benefits however things can get stagnant
pros:

- Good work-life balance

review_title: Great jobs & amazing people to work with! But won't stay there too long.
job_title: Part Time Building and Systems Engineer Supervisor in Lathrop, CA
pros: My department was really kind, not only that but they were a group of people a few years fresh outta college & they understood my school schedule. They were really flexible considering I had multiple activities on my plate. Leaving the company was difficult for me since I gained a lot from my managers and coworkers.
cons: It's intimidating to be the only engineer in a room full of operations team. It takes a lot of professionalism, patience, and communication between the engineering department and operations. However, you do gain a lot of skills you never would have thought to get from this company.

review_title: Better get used to it quick, or quit!
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Norwalk, CT
pros: Good benefits if you stay a while, nice people to work with at times.Always fun to load the truck that delivers to your own neighborhood!
cons: The distribution center manager is so nice! So are some of the shift supervisors, but they are very pushy! Every misload (getting a package in the wrong truck) which is bound to happen with 2000+ packages a day, they take personally and you seriously end up not caring. Early hours, alot of pay taken out of the paycheck, and it is hot and sweaty!!! ... If you tell them it's just for the summer, they wont hire you.. theyre looking for full time permanent part time loaders, but I can't do it during school!

review_title: Company getting worse as the years go on.
job_title: Designated Responder in East Petersburg, PA
pros: Decent pay after being there several years, good benefits after being there for a year.
cons: Poor starting wage, you get treated like an animal.  Poor contract between the union and company.

review_title: Safe place to go before retirement,
pros: Working for UPS Information Services is as close as you can get to working for the government while in the private sector - it's very difficult to get fired so if you're looking for a place to work before you retire, you might consider here
cons: Pay not competitive with market, no room for advancement, company hasn't moved with the times and seems to look back on its history to its detriment, employees seem bored, not kept busy enough. A lot of middle managers who are going through the motions to wait for retirement, causing a higher turnover of lower level staff

review_title: UPS is OK if you like a big company
pros: UPS is a large stable company.  There are a lot of areas to work in within your career and there are a lot of good people to work with.
cons: UPS is bureaucratic and can be stagnant.  The culture can be static and very old fashioned in many ways.  Since the IPO and the recession UPS has been struggling to find itself.  A lot of the good things it was known for have disappeared- good pay and benefits included.

pros: Good pay, benefits, vacation, job security
cons: Long hours, physically demanding and hard on your body. many guys near retirement age have had multiple hip, elbow, knee, and shoulder surgeries. package weight and stop count continues to rise. Not sure if this is a 30 year career type job anymore. Many of the guys who are near retirement age came through the system with less stops and much lighter packages. I can't imagine how this generation will look in 20+ years.

review_title: Good Temporary Work If You're Agile
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Nashville, TN
pros: As long as you can climb in and out of the van quickly and be on your feet almost constantly for a few hours its easy work. You're just taking packages to the door and getting back in.  Decent pay to ride around chatting with a delivery driver. Also this can be a way into full time work.
cons: You do have to be pretty nimble to do this job.  Also you're in the elements, so if its snowing or whatever...

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Bakersfield, CA
pros:
*Great Benefits after probation period ends
*Finished by 10am
cons:
*Work flow not consistent
*start time not consistent 
*Poor management 
*Have to be with the company for years to move up to driver.
* Management does help when short staffed
*Company divided: workers looking after themselves and management look after themselves.

review_title: Fast delivery, safe delivery, and reliable!
pros: Work more than one job, I’m moving into a house and could definitely use an extra source of income. I’m sociable but I know when things need to be done. Very friendly attitude, Im always willing to stay to help. I hope to climb up the ladder! I know when someone is in need of help. I have worked packaging and shipping before!
cons: The hours, but I can over come it. It’s a little far from where I’m located but everything is, I live in the middle of no where. Other than that I have a cheery bright smile and attitude to offer.

review_title: Great Longterm investment, need to have a lot of patience working here...
pros: Job Stability, benefits are great (pension, medical, 401k, stock bonuses). You get personal days (min 5 days) in addition to your vacation days. Sick days are unlimited. The new pension plans gives the younger and new employees more flexibility.
cons: Not young or dynamic, very conservative and older staff. Tuition reimbursement is pathetic. The IT staff is so old you don't get any new innovation, IT works on old technologies and does not create an environment for innovation. College degrees are not valued much as most of the older generation were part-time workers. Upper Management gets rewarded on a different scale than regular Manager and supervisors.

pros: You love being involved in a very fast-pace moving company, you like doing multiple tasks at one time and are passionate about making difference through the work that you are doing. Also, if you like to get your hands dirty and being involved in the operational side of the company, this company is a place you want to be
cons: Not much of an opportunity for advancement and if you are doing the management side of the company, the chance is that you might get bored doing your job because you don't have enough stimulation that can energize your hard-working spirit. Last but not least, not enough team project that would create a stronger bonding between the employees.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: off at the same time each day, good AC in the building, nice equipment at work station.
cons: they will tell you in the interview that this job is so great when in reality you are sitting at a cubicle making sales calls all day. Plus,  if  you are not meeting "magical" sales goals you will be put in the fire. Most irritating thing is the "commission".  No one knows how to calculate it not even upper management! Making sales at UPS doesn't directly equate to dollars in your pocket!  The one employee at the site that was making the most commission, actually didn't make the sale at all.  She dishonestly put her name down as the direct contact and she was rewarded for this! Don't work here if you are used to the typical sales atmosphere you will be highly disappointed.

review_title: Not for everyone, excellent pay/benefits for the job
pros:
Excellent benefits
the warehouse culture
Excellent pay for the hours you work 
Incredibly flexible (except for holidays)
Excellent way of picking up quick management experience (quick promotion)
cons:
The warehouse culture (It can get rowdy)
You WILL work holidays. Sure, you'll get christmas off, but you work the day before and after. Only exception is the new year. They basically give you a hangover day. 
Quick promotion=high turnover. But it's a pain advancing past part time supervision, where it's very seniority based .

review_title: Repetitive; great for elderly or first job fresh out of college with debt.
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: 8-5 hours. No weekends.
cons:
No facial hair. You do not get paid enough for what you are doing. DO NOT MOVE FOR THE JOB!! I personally sit next to a gentleman who was working at a cellphone provider and moved to SA for the job. He hates the decision he made. You make more money at the cellphone provider, times 2!
UPS pumps this job up to be great but if you have ever made over $50K you will hate yourself for taking this job.

review_title: From driver demoted to Preload because of seniority
pros: As a driver you get paid well, don't get checked like a criminal at the guard shack, and you don't have Satan breathing down your neck. As a driver you get to explore the world and you will never work nearly as hard as a preloader.
cons: As a preloader, the start time always changes. Always. 230, 430...very inconsistent. They will keep you busy doing things you aren't being paid to do. Unload at a steady and expedient manor. Why you may ask? To get the managers who are starring you down will get a bonus if you come out of there sooner. Its a lot of bs on a whole new scale. Let's not get on the topic of seniority and how its broken down. Join the union with this job!

review_title: Great company stuck in the past
pros: Great benefits, great people, global brand, lots of opportunities for growth
cons: The company tends to rest on its laurels despite its attempts to be seen as progressive. With a history built on cutting-edge operations, company leaders have forgotten to invest in its most valuable asset - its people. Lots of value lies in the minds of the people who keep the company running, but leaders seldom listen to the feedback of those working the front lines. The faux culture of "open door policy" and collaboration can be demoralizing. Also, strict company rules can be a stumbling block if you're a member of Gen X or a Millennial.

pros: Excellent benefits (best you're gonna get at any part-time employer), educational aid, steady work hours, good job security, regular raises with a high caps on potential hourly earnings, five day works week with plenty of opportunities for picking up extra hours when you need a little overtime.  Lastly, advancement opportunities are abundant, as well as specialized training.
cons: Most of the management team will seem out of touch, and base their decisions solely on the bottom line.  Upper management holds all the power here and they often make off site decisions that force their subordinates into tough situations.  On site management was generally very keen on the needs of their workforce, but seeing as these individuals hold very little real authority it was often impossible for them to influence positive change.

review_title: Company culture starts at the top
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Louisville, KY
pros: Time off is fairly reasonable. At the beginning of your tenure, at least in an Administrative capacity, job flexibility is common. Plenty of entry level career paths to choose from.
cons: Management attitude is divisive, abrasive and contentious. HR is complacent. The type that will cuss out employees they feel "comfortable" with, swear and scream to the point that you can hear them through walls on company calls, and threaten you with your job when you call them out on their unprofessional behavior.

pros: The company is a strong leader in logistics and larger than most people realize. There are a number of opportunites and if you are willing to learn and move you can grow and expand your experience within the company.
cons: They are slow to react to change as much as they say they are innovative at times they appear to be more reactionary in certian areas of our business. It sometimes seems slow but you are turning in a new direction, it is a very large ship to move. In the past the core values meant something and I do not believe that to be as evident any longer.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Commerce City, CO
pros: Really good benefits.  The health insurance (after one year) cannot be beat anywhere.  If you stay five years, you are vested in a retirement that pays $60 per month for each year you've been there (starts at retirement age).  Full time retirement is $140 per month per year there.  Great college assist programs too.
cons: Really hard work - expectations beyond what is often possible.  Work fast.  Work hard.  Work accurately.  The management culture can be very negative, even abusive and condescending.  But it is not always this way.

pros: In this position your not micromanaged and are left alone to do your job. You can listen to music, audiobooks or whatever on your headphones.
cons: Taxing on your joints, ligaments and muscles (shoulder & neck). Routinely expected to pick up 50-70 ib over your shoulder (maybe over your head depending on how tall you are). The company has never seemed to cope with increase in work-load so you are constantly understaffed. Unberably hot during the summer since you are located near the top of the building and there are no windows &  no a/c. After a little while, the job becomes unbearable due to how excruciatingly unfulfilling it is.

pros: Good benefits,  but long hours.  Good job security and a fixed pension plan
cons: Long hours expected regularly.  Very difficult to balance work with a personal life.  Difficult to schedule time off or get off early for personal events.  This is a complaint one seems to hear in most departments.  And forget about doing just about anything outside of work during December.  Every job has "peak" work hours,  but 16 hours/day for 6 weeks is especially long.  Of course, you wont' have the opportunity to visit relatives this time of year either.  Some of this is to be expected, but no effort is really made to mitigate the excess hours either.

review_title: Appalled at corporate employee expense account spending, booze, good 'ole boy system, excessive franchisee royalty fees.
pros: The benefits are great and if you want an expense account, you've got it. (I am speaking of The UPS Store corporate organization.)
cons: UPS Store Franchise double charges their franchisees and even competes against them. The franchise corporate structure is way, way over staffed for what they do; they could cut their staff in half and give the franchisees a break. The UPS Store Franchise Corporate employees spend way too much money on frivolous expenditures, silly training sessions all for an excuse to party on the backs of the franchisees.

review_title: Operations Supervisor. No longer a good job.
pros: One of last employees to still get a pension, 6 weeks vacation, this is no longer available to new supervisors
cons: Minimum 11 hour days, more often 12 to 14 hours or more at a salary that equates to less than the hourly Teamsters make..  Benefits reduced significantly over the years while the union folks still have their medical, dental, vision, etc provided for them with a better retirement.  No protections for management.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Phoenix, AZ
pros: you get out early in the morning to do other things like school, hangout with friends... very hard to get fired from the job once you pass the trial period, only if you don't show up on time to work many days.
cons: the work is hard and a lot of employees are not motivated, new hires tend to pick up the work of others. Depending of the shift you may have to get up at 2 am

review_title: You will be working for a Typical Corporation
pros:
Steady work for a long standing company.
OK benefits, nothing to write home about.
cons: UPS is a publicly traded corporation, however old-time management expects employees to act as partners did back in the 30's. The attitude when it comes to work-life is to hit the street if you are not prepared to give up your personal life, and frankly, the nature of the work done does not require such extremes.

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Louisville, KY
pros: Job security. 401k match up to 3.5 percent. Healthcare. Pension.
cons: No competitive salaries for business professionals. You will not earn "your worth" here. Takes forever to get anything changed on a medium to big scale. Seems to be stuck in the past and unwilling to match competitive compensation with other bigger companies. Unless something changes I do not see UPS having a solid/long future.

pros: It is a great company to work for, with around the clock shifts
cons: However it is very difficult to get in/on with UPS in the position you were actually hired for. Like me for instance, I was trained (very well, through their defensive driving course, a great course too!), yet once the Christmas season is over, to my understanding I would have to prayerfully come back as a part time package handler, and then work my way up through the seniority process before I could actually be hired full time permanent as a driver, the position I was originally hired for!?!?

review_title: Great pay, job security. Zero work/life balance
job_title: On Road Supervisor in Paducah, KY
pros: Great pay, benefits, 401K match, pension if you were hired before 2008, job security, industry is growing, can have some flexibility to take care of errands during the day in you are not on car, usually one or two days a week.
cons: No work/life balance. 12 hour day, taking phone calls before and after the time you are physically there. Have to go back to work for major issues. Goals are usually not attainable. Upper management even admits you can't get every single task done in one work day they want you to.

review_title: There is a constant struggle between management and union workers.
pros: Benefits are the only thing that keeps me there. But the benefits get worse every time the contract changes.
cons: The stuggle between management and union workers is awful. Management wants you all to break the rules to get stuff done but they don't want to held responsible. It is kind of a disaster.

review_title: Warehouse specialist I record all inventory that comes in our warehouse at Usaa submit it into FIMS system.
pros: They work really well with your schedule and also the benefits and vacation paid time off. Great work environment, overtime pay is great.
cons: Not too many challenges only project managing don't have there plans together so sometimes we get stuck having to double work.

review_title: Be prepared to put in about 10 years before it's worth it.
pros:
- Solid benefits
- Lots of part time opportunities
- Lots of different shifts available for entry level positions
cons:
- Minimal training, if any
- Difficult to get a full time position unless willing to be a driver
- Package Handlers are severely underpaid for the physicality of the work
- Extremely negative culture

pros: Free parking space, people are friendly. You can play table tennis at your break. The salary is not bad for a part qualified accountant.
cons: No job security. The company has been making people redundant since beginning of 2019 and it will continue in 2020. We have to deal with weak management all the time. Management has a bad attitude and not honest to employees. We are working in a toxic environment. There is no career path in foreseeable future. They are pretending like the performance review must be high to get promotion but mostly managers pick out certain team members as their favourite and promoting their work over others. Talented people with high quality of work goes unnoticed. Stress level is high and there is no appreciation for your hard work.

review_title: It was pretty ok if you can stomach some of the annoying people
pros:
1. Quick Pace Environment
2. Active Job keeps you in shape
3. Benefits are incredible
4. Pretty Good Pay
5. Some Pretty Good People
cons:
1. A lot of employees don't work very hard and complain a lot about a job in which they are overpaid due to a very good union. They are lucky and entitled and don't know it.
2. At the same time, good employees can be overworked due to the lack of commitment and effort from other employees and due to supervisors wanting to report better numbers to their bosses.
3. Upper management doesn't know how to keep their cool during high stress times
4. It gets incredibly hot during the summer leading to dehydration and then everyone gets cranky and yells at each other.

review_title: Get excellent work experience, but work for peanuts.
pros: Challenging work environment, days and hours fly by, everyday is unique. Autonomy for management decisions not a lot of red tape to get daily tasks done, health benefits are excellent, Company has a good reputation for work experience in the industry, 100+ year legacy,
cons: very long hours 50+per week, oncall 7/24, high demands on management, limited promotion oportunities, lack of recognition. compensation not linked to hours worked, performance or level of responsibility, employees often earn more than the supervisor/manager, stock retirement plan not worth what it was in the 1990's, upper management uses fear and intimidation to get results. Limited vacation time for new employees.

review_title: No Respect, Illegal work hours, Unfair Promotion practices
pros: THe two biggests pros are pay and benefits. UPS has excellent benefits (including health, vision, dental, disability, life). They are also know for promotion from within, but latey they have been hiring outside to fill certain 'quota' requirements.
cons: Specialist should be paid for any time worked over 40 hours, but they are not! SSRs are epected to work until the job is done even though it usually takes 50-70 hours a week. Management advises to self develop (work more than 40 hours and claim it is development). Upper management does not keep confidential items in confidence. BD is often expected to "eat" our mileage.

pros:
Decent pay salary, so if work less than guarantee, you still get full pay
Excellent benefits for a part-time employee, even in management
Locations all throughout US for easy commutes
cons:
No respect from upper management, meaning operations manager and division manager
Do not receive proper recognition for safety, attendance and overall work habits
Pay raises suck compared to competitors and other part-time management positions
Not all divisions of the operation follow same procedures

review_title: Work lots for little pay and recognition!
job_title: Business Development Unit in Toronto, ON
pros: It depends on the people you work with. In some departments you get lucky and in others you get cranky supervisors. Overall people are respected, and do managers attrend to your questions. It's really good the company has an open door policy!
cons: Overtime not paid, although often it was needed. Expect to work lots and in return you get paid so little for it. Fedex pays a lot better for the exact same job. Consider this job like working for the government of the private world. Job safety, but low pay.

review_title: UPS is very stable, but don't expect to advance quickly if at all
pros: UPS will invest in your training; for someone fresh out of school, it is a good place to develop solid Excel and Access skills that will help you throughout your career.  UPS is also good in terms of work/life balance.  There is a gym onsite at the Atlanta corporate campus that offers an excellent variety of classes for $25/month.  It is also acceptable for people to come in later or leave early occasionally due to family commitments.  I experienced a death in the family while at UPS, and my boss encouraged me to take as much time as I needed to grieve.  If you are happy with where you are in life or ok with making very slow progress, it is an excellent place to work.    UPS also extends health benefits to domestic partners which is pretty progressive.
cons: It is hard to advance at UPS.  If you are ambitious, you are probably better served working at a company that is experiencing rapid growth.  UPS is very stable, very slow to change, and painfully slow to recognize top-performing employees, if at all.  People are treated fairly - too fairly if you are a top performer.   3% cost of living increase in a decent economy is pretty standard.  If you go the extra mile all the time, the best you'll see is 4-5%.  UPS also likes to advertise its benefits, but look at the fine print.  While it offers tuition reimbursement, it is capped at $5,250 a year (if you take a full courseload).  UPS no longer does 401k matching for employees under the defined benefits plan (not sure if they do 401k matching for new hires).  Every year, the health benefits get more expensive and less comprehensive.  That is hardly unique to UPS, but UPS has a reputation for providing excellent health benefits, but if you are not extremely careful about what you let doctors do, you will still get ridiculous bills.  The culture is rather stodgy.  The company does not get the mindset of young people.  There are not a lot of women in powerful positions.    This is purely a guess, but I'd say that 90% of the people in the corporate headquarters are white men over 40.

pros: As a service provider you get to work alone on the road you supervise yourself in so many ways to get your job done and meet lots of people throughout your day and learn to be efficient with everything you do
cons: Management treats you like you always late and always lying. You feel everyday you come to with that you may be fired for dinner miscellaneous reason. People see the UPS guy running and think it's bc we want to,NO it's the pressure coming from management.

review_title: Stable and Financially Rewarding; but UPS is not for everyone
pros: Life long career opportunities where your skills will be stretched and strengthened.  Financially rewarding as long as you realize that wealth is generated by building equity into the partnership.  Can retire 10 years early (age 55) and find roles/position in the industry where you can handle with ease.  UPS will stretch you further than any other company I have interacted with.
cons: UPS is not a place for everyone.  You are either a UPSer or your not.  It is a very tough place to work; yet rewarding if your attitude is right.

pros: It is decent pay @ 18.50 an hour. If you're looking to get on full-time, working as a "seasonal" is good way to get foot in the door. Wknds off.
cons: It is extremely rigorous work, oftentimes you will work 10-12 hour days, M-F. This is picking up heavy packages all day long, and you will sweat off at least 10 pounds. You are always in a rush and never have any time to chill. No breaks. This is not an easy, temporary way to make extra cash but a very difficult and time consuming job that will work you to your limits.

pros: Early morning shifts get the work day out of the way, freeing up your schedule for the rest of the day. Constant amount of hours each week make budgeting much easier. Makes you think twice before going out with your friends on week nights.
cons: Working at UPS the past few months, I have had to change up my daily schedule completely to accommodate the unusual hours. Talking with drivers and other employees about the pay and benefits, I have really been thinking hard about becoming a package delivery driver and saying screw college! Why waste time when I could be making almost 6 figures without a degree?

pros: UPS has a fantastic reputation in the transportation industry and when all resources are applied appropriately is the best option for a company.  You never have to worry about the paycheck cashing.  Sales training is fantastic and will prepare you for any industry.
cons: As a salesperson, you are dependent on the drivers and package sorters (operations) doing their job in order to keep your customers.  As union employees many of them do not care.  Senior sales leadership is not focused on your career or helping you.  Also if the upper management has control over your career--not your direct manager.  Commission as a sales rep is terrible for what all you do as an account executive.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Greensboro, NC
pros: The only Pro is leaving.
cons:
They tell you to go your own pace, but at the same time shame you for going slow. Its not like you need energy anyways!
Oh and if you are even one second late they'll send you home.
The pay is crap since you work 4 days a week in a comparison to a place like walmart.
The supervisors are complete bullies, they talk down to you, as if you were a small child throwing a tantrum.
and did i mention that the workers don't get breaks? yeah that's right they wont even let you go to the bathroom! 
I mean is the a work place or a prison? 
They then hold the infamous $100,000 dollar position of driver as if a normal person is willing to work in those conditions for a decade! 
if this is your dream job i won't hold it against you but if its not please consider something better!

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Romoland, CA
pros: Amazing benefits. Medical, dental, vision. No extra cost. Paid vacation and sick time. Benefits cover spouse and up to 4 children.
cons: Laughable pay. You will make less than $200 a week. Expect to wake up at 3am 5 days a week to unload/load trucks for 3 hours a day. No real career advancement. Expect to wait more than 5 years to be offered a full time job. Back breaking labor at less than 20 hours per week. Aggressive and deplorable management tactics. Rampant drug use/alcoholism within the part time ranks.

review_title: Bad place to work; slave labor; good for losing weight; health benefits went mostly to treat work related injuries
job_title: Package Loader (Part Time Union) in Saddle Brook, NJ
pros: to lose weight, health benefits for part time work
cons: lack of manpower, extremely demanding physical work for low hourly pay, give lazy, less hard working, undeserving employees more desireable positions and keep hard working deserving employess in non desireable positions, poor tools and equipment, outdated facilities, poor management unable to properly run there sections resulting in poor performance and delayed delivery, extremely high turnover, too many employees leave due to back injuries and other work related injuries.

pros: Job security, strong brand, community image.
cons: Operators run the company, who have no knowledge of sales/growth. Very old school policies and personnel that work at UPS from 18 yrs until retirement. Usually old, bitter, and just looking forward to retirement. Operators, who drove UPS vehicles for a number of years tell the sales people what to do and how to do it. Then expect to then receive reports as to status of business growth. Sales people are on the bottom of the food chain and have a very steep, slippy slope to climb up the company ranks. Do not trust that future advancement will be available in the near future even for someone with exceptional sales results and MBA.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Austin, TX
pros: the company offers a lot. the benefits are awesome and your guaranteed a decent  amount raises every 6 months as long as you don't go into management .once your a full time driver your going to make between 75k-90k.free benefits 5 personal days and a couple weeks of vacation and off on weekends.so if your not book smart but still want a comfortable life style then ups is the way to go oh and its also unionized =job security
cons: its takes ad least 7 to 10 years to become a full time driver . hard labor and getting up mon-fri from 3ish to 9 for the next 7 years...yeah doesn't sound too great. but if you stick it out your set.... Ive been there for 3 years now

pros: Benefits were excellent when I made it on the old contract before everyone else had to wait a year for them. Some supervisors say they wish they stayed as a loader. Tuiton reimbursement of $1500 per semester, $15000 for lifetime... hope you can handle doing $3000 worth of credits to finish your 2 year degree in 5.
cons: Management was a joke... you get scowled more than praised doing your job and agree that safety bbqs were a joke.  Pay sucks the first year and really just are worn down quickly from the job. Watched my co workers I started with drop down from 12 to 2 in a year. Not a job for anyone who has never done face paced heavy lifting

review_title: Decent pay for part time job.  Solid environment
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Boston, MA
pros:
Co-workers
Pay for part time and no experience
Great physical workout

I enjoy the work a lot.  Having to unload trailers is challenging and I find it fun trying to beat my co-workers times.  However, once you prove that you can go hard and are capable of doing so, they expect that all of the time.  This can definitely wear a person down that is not prepared togoghard
cons:
Work conditions can be rough depending on weather
Chance for advancement
Demanding work
Lack of hours

Found myself and a lot of other co-workers getting sent home if workload is light.  Since everything is predicated on seniority, this can be difficult for people without other jobs.  This is definitely a solid second job to have.

review_title: Working at UPS is "eternal Army boot camp".  They continually beat you down, psychologically and physically.
pros: Job security and benefits (medical, dental, pharmaceutical, pension, education) are excellent.
cons: The supervisors are sadistic.  The package-handling jobs are physically demanding and definitely NOT for the faint-hearted.  UPS expects and demands 100% effort every single second.  Furthermore, they treat all workers as if they have no brain whatsoever.  The work environment is extremely demeaniing.

job_title: Temporary Cover Driver in Stafford, TX
pros: The money is outstanding for blue collar work and the benefits are the best in the business. Plenty of opportunities to move into management and progress through the company ranks.
cons: The work is hard. The trucks don't have A/C and reach extreme temps in the summer. Many of the trucks have worn out clutches, gearbox, steering system, suspension, etc making them very difficult to drive. The managers are callous and are relentless about micromanaging the drivers.

pros: Job stability, consistent raises, if you stick with it, pay can increase significantly; health benefits (and benefits in general) are absurdly good--it's almost unheard of these days for an employer to offer health benefits like theirs, especially for a part time job.  Burns lots of calories.
cons: Can be stressful due to the fast-paced nature of the job; can be hard on the body, especially if you're not careful (they're sticklers for working safely, but for good reason).  Pay starts relatively low.  Hours start fairly low, as well.  Tension between the union and UPS is really obvious, and the company seems bent on trying to reduce benefits as much as they can (despite continually rising profits).

pros:
The way the management team came together. UPS has a real dig in and get it done culture that sets tough expectations there is a real feeling of success when you overcome. 

Clear expectations
Clear direction
Company support of policy
cons:
Management blaming eachother culture. Even when there is no directly responsible party. They need someone to blame.
Work life balance is abismal 
Management is tolerant of a culture of jnternal abuse to supervisory team. Yelling, accusing forcing unreasonable hours. We all understand there is a job that needs to get done. 

90% of your management teams time is invested in fighting operational fires and talking about yesterday.

review_title: Easy to get hired, crappy job
pros: Super easy to get hired, they did mass interviews and hired anyone with a pulse. Good opportunity to move up to other positions if you're willing to put the work in on memorizing things and you get your work done.
cons:
Got sexually harassed frequently (I'm a female, it was a 97% male hub), when one worker wouldn't stop pushing up against me and grabbing me I went to management. They told me the man harassing me has had many complaints made before and the union protected him every time so all they could do was move me back to loading (a lower position) so I wasn't working near that guy.

Also the union/supervisor battle got really old.

review_title: Not a great place for developers
pros: Job security - UPS has a lot of money
cons:
The pay is ridiculously low and they cannot offer you better (pay caps)
Managers make up dates for you to complete a project without even asking you
Management limits your framework use 
They have a dress code for developers and you will NEVER see a customer 
Offices are super dingy, computers are sub-par, lighting sucks, people are rude, in times of high stress (aka before peak, management is up your butt but before peak you can go up to a month with no project to do or a useless project they will not use)
almost everyone below the age of 30 is constantly applying to other jobs
your input does not matter, even new projects are antiquated
The benefits get worse every year (high deductables)

review_title: UPS is a great place to work if you are motivated and can handle very difficult work for seemingly low pay.
pros: It is very easy to get promoted if you are competent.  Additionally, the pay is fairly competitive with other corporations.  For many, the lack of a need for a college degree for some of the upper level supervisor jobs is a plus.
cons: The work is probably the hardest in the field.  There is little recognition unless you actively push yourself forward.  Most people see UPS as a dead end in their professional growth.

review_title: If you do your job and don't Misload you get treated decently
pros:
The UPS Small Package division's benefit package is great you get company sponsored benefits.
They treat you well if your fast enough and you don't missload. they leave you alone when you have been there for a while.
cons: The Managers are of poor Quality.  They get angry about petty things and make you look bad for small things. Then they  treat you like crap if you misload when they should hold a Pickoff accountable as well as a loader and then they also should add a Missload prevention system.

pros: Solid Company, many different oppertunities in different Subs, or within small package.  Benifits and stock are great. The people (co-workers) are great some of the best most honest people I know
cons: Ever since we went Public the company has changed, Our People were always #1, now our people are only the engine to make the stockholders money.  From the Part timers to the Middle Managers the atmoshpere has changed, and it going to be hard to re-visit the days of a UPS Family

pros: Good company to work for, they are definitely leaders a what they do
cons:
A lot of changes in the past few years, the company just changed salary structure and most likely will continue to change, the retirement plan sounds good but it will change for sure, opportunities are always there but there is always the idea that you have to work around 12 hours a day to get to the next level.
The IE department is increasingly downsizing and that is not good, that equals more work for you. the company is operational driven with that being said there are a lot of poor educated individuals running the business (no saying they are not competent on what they do) at the end of the day education is not prized as it should be.

review_title: UPS is a cut throat operation to work for, They do not care about thier employees welfare.
pros: The Pay is the only pro at UPS. They pay well so they can treat the employess with no professionalism.
cons: Very Hostile work environment. UPS in Memphis doesn't care about the customers packages. They care about what corners can be cut to make more profit. UPS is a very poor managed company that is only successful because of thier wealth and large infrastruture.

pros: Good Pay, Interesting work with a wide variety of responsibilities. An opportunity to build a team with a "Go Get Em!" attitude.  The fast paced environment will insure you are never bored.
cons: Excessive hours.  UPS has out-sourced many support staff functions in recent years, forcing remaining management to take on new responsibilities.  These responsibilities have increased hours from an average of 60 to an average of 70.

pros: You can gain experience designing internal work at a very large company. Everything is very spread out so you can lose weight if you want just by going to see co workers.
cons: If you're a designer, you don't want to work here. The projects are bad and the managers are untalented with no industry experience. They constantly request outdated designs and bury you in job-justification notes and actually fear talent. The worst thing you can do is show your skill here because your manager will most likely interpret that as a threat to their job and they will quickly show you the door. The office is bland and has no perks. The company itself is quite old and it is awkwardly old school. The headquarters has unofficial sexist policies like 'women first on the elevator.' I've actually seen people get yelled at for not allowing women on first.

pros: Hours can be somewhat flexible. Fairly clean work environment. Permanent employees seem to have good benefits. Stable company for logistics.
cons: I worked in the department that develops training for customer service representatives.  Lack of integrity in management/supervisor team. Managers/supervisors are gossipy, openly make fun of those who are different, and routinely blame their own mistakes on contract employees.  To survive, it is best to avoid any talking to co-workers and to protect your work as best you can as there are no checks and balances on firing contractors.  High turnover. Realize you are seen as easily disposable and take it one day at a time!

review_title: Sooner or later one of us must know
pros: The people who make up the rank and file of UPS employees are outstanding. There are also plenty of challenges and opportunities for personal growth
cons: The further one advances up the corporate ladder, the less in touch that person becomes with reality. The company also faces an upcoming crisis, as it cannot recruit and retain quality people in underappreciated roles. Introductory pay rates are low, and the advantage of full benefits for part-time employees doesn't appeal to young people any more.

pros: It’s a job, they give you money to work. No pros
cons: When you interview they basically say you’re not going to get off on time. How does that work when they’re saying you’re going to get 20 hrs and a lot of people complain it’s not enough time. So if the hours are 330 am -9 am 5 days a week how does that equal 20 hrs. They say a lot of people quit because of the labor or because it’s not enough hours. They warn you that you can’t keep another job with this job because they will conflict. It takes a year to get benefits from the time you’re actually an employee. It takes 5-10 years on a waiting list to become a driver. It’s just confusing as to how this is a good job.

pros: The benefits and job security seem good.
cons: Training program needs to be better supervised and organized, and driver training should not be conducted overnight, nor be like a boot camp.

review_title: What Brown Has and Hasn't Done For Me...
pros: The best reasons to work for UPS are the pay and benefits. I'm curious as to whether they would be so generous if the Teamsters didn't give them a little nudge.  As a driver, I also like the fact that I go take care of business without someone breathing down my neck all day.
cons: The downsides to working at UPS would be the irregularity of (full time) hours worked...overtime is not an option (only excessive overtime can be fought).  Also,  management always seems to be looking to pass the buck to hourly employees for their problems and shortcomings.

review_title: 40 hours a week is not what you will get at UPS
pros: UPS is proud that it has been around for so long and the people that work there are proud to be employees.  It is a great brand and a company that is HUGE on community service and helping others.
cons: If I work 45 hours in a week its because I had a day off.  The demands being placed on the management team are out of control.  Anyone that is a salaried employee can expect to work at least 10 hours a day, usually closer to 12, and sometimes up to 15 or 16.

pros: Great benefits and a company with huge growth potential. They promote from within and offer numerous training opportunities for those willing to seek them out. There is also tuition assistance for full time management.
cons: Your work life balance will be skewed to the work side in most positions. A career in operations is very time demanding and is high stress. Part time management positions are not as financially rewarding as the hourly part time or full time positions.

review_title: Very Professional Onboarding for New Hires
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in New York, NY
pros: Management and HR truly take the time to find out specifically what will help an employee to succeed in their current position and move forward. Opportunities to advance are non-biased and are always clearly communicated, so that everyone knows what is required to move forward.
cons: Look into more innovative logistic practices on Inbound to minimize the large and unnecessary added workload to employees and supervisors. This will save time and allow all special skill employees to focus on their designated assignment for the shift. This will come in time through better technology. No complaints at present.

review_title: Excuse me, there's a chip on your shoulder
pros: Good benefits after being employed for one year. Free healthcare to part time employees. $1.00 raise after one year if performance requirements were met. Advancement available.
cons: Supervisors are based on seniority. A lot of the supervisors do not have the qualifications, experience, knowledge or class to be a supervisor. ZERO communication. No training. No information given on employment advancement, extra hours, switching shifts, policies or procedures. Not all, but most of the woman have such horrible chips on their shoulders. Especially the woman supervisors.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in New York, NY
pros: Work outside (if you like being out in the cold!), meet new people, development rapport with your customers and the satisfaction they get from receiving a package.
cons:
Fellow workers (drivers) will try to intimidate you about the job -- they will trash talk the job and make it seem not worth it. I'm a trained actor so I could tell when someone is trying to act in a certain way to garner a response -- don't let it phase you. These guys that have been there for 15-20 years act like it's a club house and will "test" you to see if you're up to it and will be "one of the guys." 

Level of employee IQ is low -- expect locker room talk most of the time.

pros: Good benefits and resume builder.  Old school management style that does not value their employees . Bullying is tolerated and depending on the department, it can be an unprofessional work environment.  You will gain experience in large scale operations if you can tolerate the culture and negative work experience. Fear driven environment.
cons: Employees are not valued or seen as assets   They are often disrespected, yelled at and bullied publicly.  Very hierarchical environment with old school managers who have not evolved to a better way of leading others.  Those with outside professional experience will find this environment difficult to accept.

pros: Good benefits. Health insurance is very inexpensive once you get it, and tuition reimbursement is nice. Promotes from within, if you stand out you can become a supervisor or driver.
cons:
Very rushed. You will be worked hard, especially during peak season. Warehouses and equipment are minimally maintained, it's likely you will end up with equipment that barely works. Supervisors and management make excuses when asked about fixing the equipment. Lots of unsafe work due to being so rushed, work culture only cares about moving the packages. It's no wonder so many people's packages get damaged and so many injuries happen. Oh, and don't believe the 70lb max weight on the job description: you can and will get packages that are up to 150lb.

Basically, new employees are churned through like they're disposable.

review_title: No one knows the answer to anything
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Odenton, MD
pros: The hiring process is quick and they swear that females with degrees can get promoted quickly.
cons: UPS doesn't like to give their corporate HR phone number.  Good luck on your goose chase through their many voice recordings the take you from one message to another, without any human contact for up to an hour at a time.  The parking lot is a pedestrian death waiting to happen, and when it does, I'll be sure to write a police report about the overcrowding and unsafe parking of cars on grass and hills.

pros:
The company is changing their views on tech
They are respecting the IT employees more
The CIEO is dedicated to changing the old corporate business structure
They are currently getting rid of the older tenured employees so they can continue to modernize and get the most technologically driven and minded indivduals the keys to the company
cons:
The pay is lower than the industry standard by a good amount
You are expected to work additional hours when on support with no compensation
For people new to the company the culture shift may seem slow

pros:
Good little workout of about 4 hrs. a day and you get paid...  not much
Full health ins. and a pension and some nice tuition assistance.
cons:
Since the turnover is so high, they won't even pretend to care about you.  Safety training is by rote, not real world.
While we broke all records last Christmas.  Our Christmas celebration consisted of a cup of coffee and a donut.  Keep it classy U.P.S.
This in no way should be a career.  just a chance to get a little work experience, maybe part time supervisor (looks good on a resume) or advance to a well paying driver career.

review_title: Company is okay overall- could be better with job opportunities
pros: Good health benefits. salary is competitive. Stable company with few (if any) layoffs. People typically stay for a long time if not for their whole career (this is actually both good and bad)
cons: Because people don't typically leave, sometimes opportunities are tough to find because if you want to apply, it's for someone who is already there in the position but it's a promotion.

review_title: Not a bad job while in highschool
pros: It was a good part time job. Never had to go to the gym since working at UPS was basically your gym helps you build muscle.
cons: The only con was the 10 minute lunch break but I quickly realized that's understandable because we usually worked 3-4 hour days. I wish it was full time

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in San Antonio, TX
pros: Potential for growth, devopment and advancement.  Employee benefits, compensation and rewards.  Reputation for minority employee satisfaction.  Variety of positions with which to work in.  Part time employees have the opportunity to go to school full time or work another job. Ownership in the company.  Safety is paramount!
cons: Must start at entry level position and pay regardless of experience and education.  This means that talented leaders may not be able to afford to start a career with UPS with a starting pay of $8.50 for the first 90 days.  A lot of the equipment in the hub is in poor condition.  Supplies needed to work with are in short supply.

review_title: The best days are long gone...
job_title: Plant Engineering Supervisor in Columbus, OH
pros: Relatively Good benfits, Strong corporate culture, Clear communications of objectives and expectations, no nonsense approach in dealing with problems.  High level of technical competence demonstrated by most management members.
cons: Junior mgmt members are thrown under the bus to keep labor peace with the unions, especially the Teamsters.  Many sort (operations) managers are simply ignorant, and refuse to accept, the necessity of tasks other than those directly related to delivering pkgs.  Expectations of younger managers higher than those of previous generations without any education or technical skills.

review_title: UPS is an excellent career option.
pros: Excellent opportunities to advance and make good money. Reward and recognition for going above and beyond.  Great team environment.  Excellent name recognition when trying to gain new customers.
cons: If you don't want to work and work hard this is not the place for you.  Sometiimes operations and sales don't have mutual respect for one another but mostly is due to fragmented communication.  Drivers are slightly becoming less professional and less customer focused.

review_title: Hit or Miss...Could be nice, Could be a living hell
job_title: Driver Helper in San Francisco, CA
pros: Weekly pay, Ability to maintain a personal life, post-season opportunities, and lots of exercise (if you want it)
cons: Minimum wage does not add up to work load.
