review_title: Information Services : Great for entry level positions, but then boredom sets in
pros: Like my title says, working for UPS I.S. is great if you're fresh out of college and you want to add experience to your resume. They have a leadership program that you can take advantage of, although you need to be chosen to do so and it's really if you're thinking of staying with the company. If you're looking for slow paced with little probability of being fired, then this is the place for you, it's as close to working for the government as you can get while still in private industry.
cons: Top heavy middle management, making it difficult for career advancement. Lots of people in it to draw a pay check and wait for their retirement rather than do anything innovative. Slow paced and unexciting. Too much corporate structure of a bygone era and office politics.

review_title: They hired me as a felon (grand theft) and gave me full time benefits and everything I could ever ask for. Amazing....
pros: After a year, part time workers receive FULL TIME BENEFITS!!!! The best medical, dental, and eye coverage in the WORLD!!!
cons: It really is hard work, but its do-able, and the employee environment is incredible conducive to personal growth. This was more like a pro, But you do have to work hard, understand that.

review_title: Seasonal Drivers, they need them when they need them
pros: Once the season gets going you can be assured of work everyday.  For UPS that is 6 days per week as long as you don't go over hours of driving
cons: Working at a port city their operations are in several locations and they often don't know where you're needed until you arrive and that may not be the location you'll work from that day.

review_title: Big Brown was a great company to work for
pros: Benefits were outstanding, Salary was better than most.  Bonus Program in stock MIP was an outstanding way to build your wealth.  There was a great retirement package and the ability to retire at 55. Challenging and rewarding work.
cons: Time management and balancing family life.  UPS Upper Management often was very tight with praise.  They seemed to ride you hard and put you up wet and money /!benefits was the lone carrot.

pros:
Worked as a driver helper one year when I had been laid off from my job. Worked my tail off for $10 an hour with 3 different drivers. 2 of them were very cranky long term employees who constantly complained about the company, the work conditions and their salary. Got tired of all the complaining especially since I know they were making a lot more than $10 and hour and quite honestly I was doing the majority of the work during their peak season. One driver I worked with had a positive attitude and that was quite refreshing. 
Had heard from other drivers, driver helpers and former driver helpers that I would get a nice bonus from the drive I worked with.........yeah, not so much.
It's an ok job if you need money badly but be prepared to be used and abused for very little pay.
cons: Hard work, tough conditions, little pay.

pros: The package handler position is good for full-time students with a big workload. Typical shifts were usually about four hours. And the union benefits are great. But they take one year to kick in. A positive experience overall.
cons: Unless you intend to stay with the company for the long run, the money you make as a package handler may not justify the work you have to put in to get it. I put up with the work for a couple of years as I was finishing up school, but I wouldn't recommend it to others unless they are good workers who are open to intensive manual labor.

review_title: Be warned...UPS Stores are small businesses
pros: UPS Stores are all privately franchised, meaning that they are essentially small businesses. If you end up working for someone who handles this well, it can be a very good thing.
cons: Be warned...UPS stores are all privately franchised. That's a double-edged sword. That means that if you end up working for an abusive manager, there's not much recourse for you. Your two options are to quit or deal with it. Learn from my mistakes: ask open questions in the interview, feel out anyone you might be working under, pay attention to how the staff are treated/what kind of mood they seem to be in, etc.

review_title: It Isn't Terrible, It isn't Great
pros:
No dealing with customers, third shift (if you enjoy it), can keep to yourself most of the time/little social interaction.
Good insurance if you work there for 6 months or a year, can't remember which.
cons: Hours would sometimes vary to be much longer than the regular shift, managers don't seem to understand the work load required to do the job, people call in a lot or no show, and upper management does not stick to their word if you need to speak with them.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros:
The coworkers 
You can pick your hours depending what territory you get...(if you ever get one)
Hour lunch 
$18.55 base pay
cons: So basically you’re in training for 4 weeks then wait to get placed in a territory if you’re not placed right away. I’ve been in “growth group” after 3 months....have yet to get a territory and we were told the longest people stay in growth group is a month...WRONG. All we’re doing while we’re waiting to get placed is making calls on dead account...all...day...long....with no commission since we’re not placed yet. Very overstaffed so idk why they hired so many people.  There’s so many people for no reason that people are even having to share a cubicle.

review_title: Great company to work for with lots of great changes on the horizon!
job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros: Work/life balance, managers that care, work from home, constant learning/opportunities to learn and grow, ability to rotate around/get exposed to new parts of the organization
cons: Vacation policy is old, not many holidays, still have an issue with appearance, still has an "old corporate" feel (super old cubes/old environment/old standards still lingering around), hard to retain younger employees/MBAs, hard to move up and get a promotion

review_title: An okay, but very physically demanding job
pros:
Getting to learn the ins and outs of warehouse operations was interesting.
Fellow leadership was understanding and helpful to a certain extent. 
Bonding with employees and accomplishing a successful operation was always rewarding, as it was VERY challenging.
cons: This hub (and maybe most hubs, but I only worked at one in particular) was a mess. A toxic-environment filled with self-entitled union employees who ran their "own" show. review_title: Not too bad of a gig
pros:
-The schedule is constant, so you'll never have to worry about your hours changing and you get weekends off

- Union protection... nearly impossible to get fired
- The medical coverage is GREAT. I got wisdom teeth surgery and head surgery, and they only costed $5 for every doctors visit

Lots of red tape, which usually leads to no resolution at all. Long story short, I was supposed to transfer to another hub. End of the story, I never heard from them or worked for them again.

- Warehouse weather... intense heat in the Summer and freezing cold in the Winter
- The union protection can sometimes be a bad thing. There are people who will work there who really shouldn't have jobs there... and you'll probably find yourself having to carry their dead weight
- Heavy initial pay-in for union dues, and you have to pay them every month. Also, the more you get paid, the higher your union dues become

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros:
- Great training and great learning opportunity
- Good benefits, decent wages
-Weekly pay
- Opportunity for promotion*
- Work/life balance

The training program at UPS is world class. The company invests a ton of money into the training (your benefits start pretty much immediately, you're paid well during training, 4-7 weeks of actual training depending on the flavor at the time). The Sales Academy is mostly a classroom setting, and the much of the training is highly applicable to sales in general (i.e. Situational Sales Negotiations, CRM technology, etc). This is a great place to grow your business acumen very quickly.

The health insurance is fantastic and the base pay is decent (see below for comments on commission). At the specialist level, you are paid weekly, which is nice. 

Think of this as a sales job with training wheels. If you're new to sales or the corporate environment, it's really hard to get fired due to lack of performance. If you ask for help, you will usually get help. 

Right now, there is a lot of room for advancement. It's probably not going to be in less than a year (like I was told), but after 1-2+ years there is room for advancement.

Depending on the team you are put on (which is totally luck of the draw) there is great mentorship available. I have personally been able to develop my own leadership and public speaking skills because my coach has made it a point to find out how I want to develop as a professional. I am directly surrounded by strong leaders that give me the room and guidance for growth. SO MUCH of your experience at UPS has to do with your manager.

Finally, there is a lot of stability in UPS. It is an S & P 100 company that has been around for over 110 years and in a world where B2C commerce is expected to grow 50% by 2020, you can feel confident that UPS is going to continue to be solid for the foreseeable future.
cons:
- Misleading on commission and PTO in the job offer
- Difficult commission structure
- Constantly moving target goals 
-  The environment feels like a call center
- Stagnant corporate culture
- That other person wasn't joking, you really do sit in a cubicle and get fat

I was made a lot of promises that weren't completely true when offering me the job. I was told I would have the opportunity to be promoted within 3-6 months of starting the job, which was not even remotely accurate. I was also told there were two weeks of paid vacation in the first year, but vacation time is actually pro-rated after your 6-month probationary period.  Finally, I was told my target commission would be $12k - $15k per year, which is wildly inaccurate. This is a good opportunity, but it's not everything they promise it will be. This is my biggest issue with UPS - I feel it is at best unethical and at worst potentially illegal to be so misleading in a job offer. 

Don't let HR fool you into thinking they are hiring because there is so much promotion. There is high turnover for many reasons:  culture, feeling underappreciated, higher paying equivalent positions elsewhere).

The commission pay structure changes every year making it difficult to understand and achieve. As I write this I know that my SIP (commission) will change in January, so the next sentence may not even be true in a month. The commission is currently based off of the performance of your territory compared to last year. This structure means that you have to reel in a whale to affect your pay.  Additionally, commission is only paid out quarterly. 

The environment can be very high-stress. There are high expectations and the target is constantly moving, making it difficult to achieve. 

***Management gets commission based on your performance and management gets a $$$ bonus when you are promoted within business development***. Because of this, management is very resistant to people entering into other divisions (such as operations or finance).

 The culture in Inside Sales is beyond out-dated. From the dress code to the way people interact, a lot of policies would be better suited at a sock hop than a modern place of business. 

Finally: this is corporate America. There is a hierarchy. Sometimes your boss yells at you simply because they got yelled at. A lot of initiatives don't make sense. A lot of things, in general, don't make sense. You are 1 out of 450,000 employees.  Being mediocre and doing things their way is the key to success. 

Overall, this is a decent job, especially for new graduates. I would not suggest staying in this position long-term, but I personally feel that I have learned a lot.  UPS is a solid company and there is room for growth. Modulate your expectations, learn how to speak corporate UPSese and move on to bigger and better things.

Decent pay/Overtime - over 5 hours in a day is considered overtime (Union Workers i think)
Flexible shifts - lots of shifts that work with working two jobs. I worked midnight (1030-0330[varies]) [varies because your shift is over when the work is done]
cons:
Management Contact outside of warehouse is non-exisitent
--I had to leave for a family crisis last minute, on my way to moving to a new state I didn't have a number for the supervisor and couldn't find it anywhere to tell them that i quit. 
(Keep contact info updated if you work here)

pros:
Friendly co-workers and supervisors
  Many people said they were promoted inside one year.
cons:
Non-existent breaks (breaks were called, but there was no way to physically leave the truck area do to mountains of packages on the floor and conveyor belt.)
  Turns out, the only people to be promoted were 20-something men.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Palm Harbor, FL
pros: I enjoyed the actual job
cons: Poor pay for what is expected of you

review_title: Great place to start to gain work experience , and an opportunity to move up with a great company over time.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Roswell, GA
pros: I like the feeling that working for this company can help open a lot of doors for me within, and outside the company. Ups Also has tons of benefits they offer such as health, dental, retirement, and even in some locations help out with education. My job now is not the easiest job, but I can do to help pay off in the future seeing that I am still very young.
cons: Not much time to really get to know your co workers

review_title: A of HEAVY lifting and grueling hard work and if u work here seasonal most likely they won't keep you around .
job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Springfield Gardens, NY
pros: They put you to work there is always work to done the pay is average ( no where near to live off of ). Solid work experience met friendly co-workers here. Work-life balance is hard to balance but impossible.
cons: I always felt that make you work so hard for so little because the work could be very intense especially around the holidays . You'll be lie and promise a raise or better position and sometime they try to mess around with your hours .

pros: Benefits - originally for worker and dependants after 30 days.  When I left, 6 months to qualify for employee 18 months for dependants
cons: Career Growith very challenging.  Poor union/managment dynamics.  Not as safe as it used to be - not encouraged to work in power zone when sorting.   The equipment for sorting required holding packages away from body to be scanned and then sorted.  The expectation was to pick up packages with one hand, hold away body under scanner & sort while picking up a package sort and scan with other hand,  creating many shoulder, neck, injuries.  Shortly before implementing this program they discontinued Physical Therapist visits and check-ins on site.

pros: Supervisors are guaranteed time, full benefits follow after being promoted.
cons: No work-life balance, expected to be at work no matter what's going on in your personal life, no time to finish all paperwork that's required throughout sort, days off can only be used at full timer's discretion.  takes forever to fire horrible employees while good employees are expected to be taken advantage of, overtime is a no-go unless approved by upper management,  compliments are far and few between, but when things are rough you'll be the first one "up under the bus". Happy UPSing!

pros: Being a part of a company that is so recognizable is a rewarding experience.  Being able to learn a route and the people on them is a challenge, but a lot of fun when you can get on a first name basis with your customers.
cons: Interviews were mass events that wasted a lot of time.  Required only to show the recruiter two forms of ID and for them to make sure you didn't look like a thug or drug addict to get the job.  Also, for being such a well-known LOGISTICS company, UPS has the worst communication I have ever seen in a professional setting.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Dallas, TX
pros:
Loved my driver. He is one of the coolest guys I've ever met. We got along so great. 
Also, PR was readily available when I needed to reach them.
Also, $75 bonus at the end of the week if I showed up to work Monday-Friday
cons: The last day I worked was Christmas Eve and yet they said they would have work for me until January 15th. They didn't "lay me off" officially. But they never had a day's work for me afterward. So be aware. If they tell you they will employ you through Mid-January, they aren't being entirely truthful. 10.10 an hour. Bonus helps. But still not that much.

job_title: Seasonal Package Delivery Driver in Middleton, NH
pros: Being a seasonal delivery driver was an eye-opening experience. It was impressive to be part in the holidays for so many people. It was a rigorous process, but the seasoned drivers are nothing less than professional and dedicated. Nonetheless it is rewarding.
cons: It is an immense learning curve where new drivers must be focused and able to master key skills to safely and efficiently transport, deliver and accept packages, especially during the long, dark days of the winter season.

pros: Some of the people ate decent.
cons: They have scaled back and now have the  worst benefits ever.  we are merely a driver and package handler company.  The employees are the most unhapoy group of people I've ever encountered.  Management are bullies.  Absolutely horrible environment!

job_title: Major Account Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good Benefits. Stock Options. Good opportunity for advancement for minorities. Opportunity to work and live in other cities and countries. There is not many terminations. Opportunity to be promoted from within the company.
cons: Aggressive Work Environment. Because of high volume and high demands there is often management by intimidation. High volume of work over the holidays and nobody is allowed to take vacation during the months of November or December.

review_title: Great company to work for. Environment is friendly and supportive. Training and support from coworkers is awesome.
job_title: Deiver Helper in New York, NY
pros: Great experience and environment. Training is valuable and is practiced daily. Benefits are great. Plenty of opportunity to grow within the company.
cons: Poor job of keeping hours worked accurate. Vehicles need to be updated to automatic. Driving a stick shift delivery truck in New York City is very time consuming and physical demanding.

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Rocklin, CA
pros:
- Good hours if you have open availability
- Great pay for college students especially - Base pay varies however I received $12.50 hourly and then after 5 it bumped up to $18.75
- Work can be rewarding and enjoyable if you get a good driver (most of them are great)
cons:
- Unorganized management (you will have to remind them constantly of your availability)
- On Call...
- The time schedule is very unpredictable because your shift is done whenever you deliver all of the packages in your truck
- Can be physically straining

pros: They picked me up for work every day
cons: They lost one of my paychecks and after having so much safe work place stuff how much they care about their employees well I was never given a rain coat in the peak holiday season I got one shirt that was far too small and was made by the driver to carry heavy 70 and 80 pound packages up very dangerous driveways and up 40 plus stairs then was let go after being unhappy they lost a paycheck of mine and telling one of their big wigs how I felt about it..

job_title: Maintenance Associate in Castle Rock, CO
pros: ups offers more than others it is convenient for a part time job with a place for advancement for a future , i like the fast pace work at UPS, a really good future.
cons: in order to  work at United Parcel Service you have to work as a part timer for at least one year ,in which i know from  experience you have to go threw employees just to find ones that fit into a fast paced work environment.

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in London, England
pros:
Promotion from within 
A company with a mission - the service itself is great
cons:
A very old school way of thinking. People often have +20 years old seniority - they breath UPS and talk about UPS all the time. Sometimes it feels like living in a sect because people can't imagine there is anything else in the world apart from UPS. There are not many young  people. 
The staff lacks training and the job gets mundane very quickly. Promotion from within is available, but only if you are lucky. Not much room for progression within HR. You can only see how bad it is when you leave and compare to other companies.

review_title: Not like it used to be
pros: If you have been an employee for at least 10 or more years , the benefits are good the pension is good and the accumulation of holidays is good.
cons: The turnaround in staff is  out of control and it seems as though nobody knows what they are doing.  Those who do know what is going on are expected to do more than they can handle .  The non union employees are  underpaid for the work they are expected to do.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Northbrook, IL
pros: Convenient location; flexible hours; get a workout while you work; can listen to music while moving boxes
cons: truck drivers openly insult package handlers with how they pack the trucks

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Columbus, OH
pros: For college students it is a great place to work. Union employees get 3000 dollars in tuition reimbursment each year. If you decide to make a jump into management you can get 4000 dollars in tuition reimbursment. PT supervisors make between 13-15 per hour while union employees start out between 8-10 per hour. Great chance for advancement into higher paying jobs as long as you are willing to work at the low end for a couple of years.
cons: Some shifts require crazy hours to be worked, for example 4am-10am is the most important shift operations worked wise. Horrible relationship between management and union, they do not work well together and can create a stressful environment at times.

review_title: Only if you want to relocate or change shifts
pros:
Used to have better than average pay
Used to have great benefits (price went up 130% this year)
cons: You must be willing to change your work shift at the companys will.  Over and over again.  (Tough if you have kids).  And to get promoted you must take the next promotion offered and relocate.  They don't pay moving expenses if your a part time sup being promoted to full time.  If you don't accept the first offer, it's rare to get another.  Now they are forcing full time supervisors to relocate/lateral moves without moving expenses.  If you don't take it, you are removed from the promotion list.  Raises are very low.  Bonuses stopped.  401k Match stopped.

review_title: Unless you want to be a driver or a cashier, do not work for UPS.
pros: Pay is decent, you can start to receive benefits after 6 months.  Good exercise.  The people you work with every day can be very pleasant.
cons: They extremely overwork their employees and expect far too much.  Often leading to injuries or employees taking risks in order to do what is expected.  Management does very little during the morning load.  No matter how good your performance you are constantly reminded that the smallest slip up can lead to your termination.  You get approximately 3 and a half hours to load 4 full sized UPS trucks with packages coming in a steady unrelenting stream.  Very stressful.

pros: Short shift allows employees to better manage work/life/school balance. School tuition assistance helpful to supplement overall cost. Steady, fast paced work.
cons: Very skilled and competent employees continue to leave for better jobs. Full time positions are being filled by temporary workers instead of hiring within to reduce cost of paying benefits. Insurance benefits continue to decline with monthly rates and co-pays increasing. Women are routinely passed over for higher positions. Level of communication is less than desirable.

review_title: Its a busy fast pace job, that ask a lot from its employees and have great benefits.
pros: The company benefits and professional growth is very good. The company has opportunities for anyone who wants to advance themselves into a better situation financially and professionally.
cons: Very little feedback from management in the preload area. They demand high performance at a fast pace and  offer very little support. Which is fine but some praise would be nice as well as a little help from time to time.

pros: Short shift allows employees to better manage work/life/school balance. School tuition assistance helpful to supplement overall cost. Steady, fast paced work.
cons: Very skilled and competent employees continue to leave for better jobs. Full time positions are being filled by temporary workers instead of hiring within to reduce cost of paying benefits. Insurance benefits continue to decline with monthly rates and co-pays increasing. Women are routinely passed over for higher positions. Level of communication is less than desirable.

review_title: Its a busy fast pace job, that ask a lot from its employees and have great benefits.
job_title: Pre Loader in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: The company benefits and professional growth is very good. The company has opportunities for anyone who wants to advance themselves into a better situation financially and professionally.
cons: Very little feedback from management in the preload area. They demand high performance at a fast pace and  offer very little support. Which is fine but some praise would be nice as well as a little help from time to time.

review_title: Pretty brutal and tough but with the benefits and good pay it's worth it.
pros: great benefits and retirement plan. that kicks in after your first year.. raises every year for part timers, twice a year for full time drivers, paid vacation, a tuition program that helps pay up to 3,000 a year for school, sick days, keeps you feeling fit etc..
cons: it's extremely hard for the first few months but you get used to it. it can get really hot during the summer time so you got to drink plenty of water.

pros: The company pays management well compared to other transportation industries, although that's probably due to the wages the union drivers earn.  Time off usually isn't an issue and most employees at the front line get along well.
cons: The company is controlled by industrial engineers that can't function at the front line or manage people.  Generally when the engineers are placed in operations they fail miserably, yet these people control how the business is run.  Also, promotions are curious.  It seems unclear how some higher ups got to that level.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Ceres, CA
pros: The best thing about working at UPS was the weekly pay, early morning hours, and 9.45 hr starting wage.
cons: Constantly overworked and always told never doing job good enough. Dangerous working environments with old machinery that was either broken or didn't work right. Bossy supervisors who care little about your overall safety and more about the rate at which you work. Probationary period is a joke they just hire you then fire you once your close to making your probationary period so benefits are not given to you and pay is not raised. Basically they believe in keeping company worker costs down at all costs they work there new hires unsafely and could careless about your safety.

review_title: An alright job for the money, but incentives have been completely eliminated. Poor management and workplace culture.
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Columbus, OH
pros: part-time salary, tuition reimbursement, healthcare benefits, no weekends, set schedule
cons: extreme conditions due to no climate control, poor work conditions and environment, physically demanding, intense production standards with no incentives, no appreciation for employees, poor culture and anger and intensity is always high, constant threat of being fired to intimidate.

job_title: Package Car Driver in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: The most important reason to work at UPS is that most positions pay better than competitors in the industry.  The only other positive thing that i liked was that you are self directed while out on the route.
cons: Absolutely ridiculous micro-management from middle managers.  Military style over regulation of every aspect of the job.  Management only concerned with quarterly numbers and not long term well being of company or customer relations.  Advesarial relationship between hourly union labor, and management.

review_title: Can be a good career, but it is not for everyone
pros: Benefits are still among the best for the price  Pay can be good, depending on position. Respected company that has been in business for over 10o years. Opportunity for advancement.  Most positions are filled from within.
cons: Many jobs/positions have NO work/life balance.  No time off from Thanksgiving to Christmas. Meeting/conference call intensive. Company is old, so many systems get "band-aided" instead of fixed.  The Corporate office seems too far removed from the reality of what's going on in the rest of the company locations.

pros: The average pay wage is much higher than most starter jobs, and the raises are consistent. There is plenty of head room, and seniority counts within every portion of the company. The job is incredibly challenging and superiors constantly push you. Most package handling jobs are vigorous and challenging for the body.
cons: The company expects the best from you and often seems unforgivably strict. I have yet to experience this behavior, but have often witnessed it, which is solely due to my strict work ethic. Thus, if you are a casual/lazy worker, prepare to not last long in this company.

review_title: Hard work in dirty environment for good pay.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: No previous knowledge necessary. Good pay, especially compared to amount of hours worked. Lots of locations. 3 different shifts. Pretty flexible with being late and family emergencies. Always desperate for workers near holidays and hire just about anyone without a record.
cons: Driver positions are highly coveted and very rarely available. Very dirty environment, used to cough up black phlegm. Most hours are inconvenient and little advancement unless  you've been there years+. Union dues seem steep when you're making just over minimum wage part time. Benefits take over a year to kick in but environment means you're likely to get sick quite often.

review_title: Hard work in dirty environment for good pay.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Addison, IL
pros: No previous knowledge necessary. Good pay, especially compared to amount of hours worked. Lots of locations. 3 different shifts. Pretty flexible with being late and family emergencies. Always desperate for workers near holidays and hire just about anyone without a record.
cons: Driver positions are highly coveted and very rarely available. Very dirty environment, used to cough up black phlegm. Most hours are inconvenient and little advancement unless  you've been there years+. Union dues seem steep when you're making just over minimum wage part time. Benefits take over a year to kick in but environment means you're likely to get sick quite often.

review_title: easy job made stressful by management
pros: Decent pay, coworkers were great, getting off work at 9:00 am gave the remainder of the day to do as you please.
cons: Varried start times, management was almost always condescending to employees, threats of loosing your job was the only motivation management used on daily basis, some supervisors seemed to enjoy "calling" people out in front of everyone for the mistakes they made even laughing about it and talking about them to other employees.

review_title: Physically hazardous work at 4 am for low pay.
pros: After 1 year employees and their families have access to good insurance for free. After several years employees will have opportunities in driving or management even. Also employees gain vacation time based on years of employment. The union protects employees jobs and rights to some degree.
cons: Jobs at UPS are always stressful because of politics and pushy people. There is a high expectation to perform excellently that can be smothering to some people. There is a strong use of fear to motivate employees.  If you have low seniority you might be laid off for a few months after the Christmas season.

pros: Extremely stable job. Great work life balance if you do not aspire to reach higher levels and are content with lower level Technical jobs. Your manager decides your destiny. Also matters in which departments you work. Some departments are better than others. You are in luck if you end up working for a powerful manager (very very few of them btw ) . Pay is reasonably good.
cons:
Politics
Bureaucracy and red tape.
Extremely  top down management structure. 
Very few growth opportunities for the Technically minded. Absolutely cannot move to pay grades equivalent to mid level management positions without giving up Technical skills and becoming a pure hands-off manager.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Louisville, KY
pros: Great benefits and pay, especially for a part time job. Guaranteed 15 hours per week.Regular pay raises every year according to the contract that was in effect when you were hired. Union could come in handy at times as well. Lots of opportunities to advance if desired
cons:
Most of the part time supervisors were late teens/early 20s with no management experience or skills. They could be quite immature at times and were hard to respect (I was in my 30s when I worked there). If you are a hard worker, you will be expected to pick up other's slack. They will not be told to do their job. 
Hard work!
Mandatory union membership, joining fee and monthly fee

pros: The company had really great benefits, especially for a part time position. They offer tuition reimbursement, 401K, medical, dental, vision. You get a chance to work around some of the greatest aircraft in the world.
cons: Head to head with union. Very difficult to manage upper level management tasks. Very bad disconnect between upper management and lower management. Worst part was the union walks all over management and gets away with it. As a part time supervisor your hands are tied and the union employees walk all over you while full time and upper management treat you with the utmost disrespect.

pros: Great salary, benefits and bonus (if the company and you do well). You will learn a wide range of skills you can take anywhere. With the right leadership you can go far and make a great career. This place will toughen you up, there are very few who stay for the long haul. Looks great on a resume.
cons: Extended hours, no work-life balance. You are expected to go above and beyond everyday without question. Most of the numbers from IE are out of reach and out dated. Expectation is 110% from every worker 100% of the time to reach your goal. Union environment will slow that down. Management can be cut-throat once you get involved in the district or division.

pros: UPS was my first job when I graduated high school back in 2012. I started off as an Unloader. It was hard but I grew into liking it. They offer a great benefit package, tuition assistance so they can pay for your classes, and ample overtime during peak season months(November-January). However I resigned 3 weeks from the company, having to start everything over. The only good part about it is I was placed into an area I would feel more comfortable in. Still trying to get my benefits back but other than that, great company and I will never leave again!
cons: Working in the heat is horrible so you have to stay hydrated.

job_title: Air Driver 22 III in Franklin, TN
pros: Good benefits and compensation overall. A world recognized brand. Consistent workload throughout the year with the exception of "peak season" Christmas season. For hourly,best for seasonal and or someone looking for part time work...for the wait to fulltime can take years.
cons: Noisy non air conditioned environment in buildings, unrealistic pace, long wait from part time to full time positions, vehicles not air conditioned with the exception of tractors. Too much pressure on all employees including management. Hourly worker starting off must now wait a year before benefits kick in.

review_title: helps you to get experience and money but leave when you can
pros: Your alone in a truck all day seeing different types of people making really good money with benefits and a union, also if you help out management, you'll get a day or two off. Keeps you in shape.
cons: Extreme overload days due to cutting routes, rarely take breaks, they want you to hustle and get done early to help others but if you get hurt or into an accident they blame you for rushing. Also pee in water bottles so you don't break off your route.

pros: The things I have learned from UPS in the Pro's, I have learned so much from them. The momentum needed to get through a hard day. Being able to motivate a person to stellar highs and learning a can-do attitude.
cons: Management here will say one thing and do another and will leave you in the dark about it. You will constantly be tested on company knowledge. The pay does not equal the amount of work you do. And people messing with time-cards is not uncommon.

pros: The HR professional was very helpful and kind. She tried to get a suitable place and also made the whole process very easy. My colleagues (the drivers I worked with) were awesome people and always eager to help. Great relationship with those guys.
cons:
A bit of dissonance between back office and front line staff.
it will also be helpful to know what the week would look like rather than taking it a day at a time. it can be frustrating not been able to plan ahead

job_title: Plant Engineering Supervisor in Overland Park, KS
pros: Lots of employees stay with UPS because it is a big company and has solid benefits for our union members. Lots of experience walking around so it’s easy to find someone who may know the answer yo are looking for.
cons: Management is overworked and under compensated. I know that it sounds cliche but I am on call 24/7 unless I’m on vacation. This, in addition to the massive amount of items/tasks I am responsible for without much help from upper management.

review_title: The company always expects more with less.
job_title: Local Sort Supervisor in Medford, OR
pros: Free health insurance. That's about where the pros end.
cons: UPS is always expecting you to increase your production with seemingly fewer employees every single year. The company recently did away with management getting similar retirement benefits that the full time drivers get. Very easy to get promoted to part time manager and very, very difficult to become full time. There is no upward mobility but lots and lots of nepotism. Their "culture of safety" is a total joke. You cannot physically perform the tasks safely and also achieve your production targets. This encourages workers to get injured.

review_title: I worked for them for 9 years
pros: Benefits are some of the best in the country as long as to work on the west coast. I herd everywhere else doesn't even compare.
cons: All of the upper management is fake they just act like your friend they won't blink an eye if they find a reason to fire someone its a game to them they get excited to fire people. Safety is just paperwork to UPS. they talk about safety a lot but don't actually care. If you do get injured UPS management will do everything in their power to make you feel like it is your fault or even try and make you feel bad for getting injured.

review_title: If you want a career at UPS stay in the union.
job_title: Part-Time Supervisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good pay and excellent benefits for part-time work. If you want to live a life of repetitive work stay in the union for several years and become a full time package car driver I think that they start out at 45K +.
cons: If you decide to go to management realize that loading and unloading trailers is physically demanding and requires a moderate degree of athleticism. Unfortunately, UPS will hire anyone regardless of physical shape to perform the job. If you manage people be prepared to have 1 or 2 athletic employees and the rest who are out of shape (that you are responsible for "developing" into faster workers)

pros:
Great Pay
Hard, but rewarding work
Good Benefits
Strong sense of family
cons:
Poor communication with management
Termination without cause
Hours somewhat erratic
Lack of training

pros: Good benefits package. Potential to move up the ladder or into management if you want to. Easy to get started at. Without a high school education you could potentially make $60K as a driver.
cons: Very strenuous manual labor. More difficult than many other labor jobs. You start as a Loader/Unloader at fairly low pay (but okay if you live in a small town where the COL is low). It's basically an us versus them attitude towards full-time management. Part-time managers are alright.

review_title: Strong company but not a good company to work for as a supervisor
pros: Your job is secure in that it is a long standing fortune 500 Company. You have the ability to work in several fields within the company of you are willing to relocate.
cons: Management are expected to accomplish there jobs in an unrealistic amount of time with no overtime allowed. You are made to feel like you are shorting the company if you leave in your paid 5.5 hours a day however you are not allowed overtime if you decide to stay to complete your tasks.

review_title: Good short-term, then either move up or out.
pros: Well-run business. Good benefits and pay. Great short term work for those moving on to a career elsewhere, or long-term work for those capable of advancing to management.
cons: Most positions are suitable for younger people. The line jobs are physical work, and workers are expected to perform like machines, which takes a toll on your body over the long-term. If you work there long-term and don't advance to management, your performance will decline with age, but you will be pressured to maintain time standards. So long term, best plan to move to a career elsewhere, unless you can advance to management or can successfully keep defending yourself from management pressure about time standards.

review_title: Nice looking shield. What's behind the shield.. You can find out for yourself
pros: Stability since you can be working for 10 years in the same role doing an excellent job. They will keep you there . there are a handful of nice ppl but majority ..
cons: The politics = disgusting. If you are good at politics, don't worry about working. Suck up to director level above (don't have to efforts with manager level below). Interns get promoted to supervisors instantly with limited knowledge of work compared to potential candidates that work for 5 years (maybe cause he/she didn't suck up or is an introvert)

review_title: Good company, easy to get lost in a sea of fellow employees
pros: I enjoyed UPS. The people are great, the pay is fair, and the benefits were good. Most managers really cared about their staff.
cons: Sometimes there is office drama. It is difficult to progress in one's career because there are just so many employees. It is easy to get stuck.

job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits-Health Insurance for a part time job. Excellent for single parents. Job Security-UPS isn't going to lay you off or go out of business.
cons: Some jobs are night shift and are physically demanding. If you are patient, you can move quickly into less physically demanding positions and better work hours.

review_title: UPS should check their management system
pros: Not many pros found during my three years working for the company.  I made some good friends and learned about the bad side of corporate America
cons:
Low pay, want employees to finish tons of work without working overtime. Managers will make you take two hours lunch or leave early even if there is pending work to avoid paying overtime. Managers belittle employees and will take advantage of their skills having them work  on excel sheets or power point presentations to then present them as theirs.
Their MAPP program is supposed to help employees to advance but in reality only those who have connections with managers get ahead. 
HR is not there to help employees but to spy on them  

Managers and supervisors will use other employees to find information about other coworkers

job_title: Package Dispatch Supervisor in Visalia, CA
pros: Great reputation. Everyone knows UPS and respects it's employees.  Looks GREAT on a resume.
cons: Very hostile work environment. Everyone's quotas are so tough that there's littke time for personal development. Upper management views lower managers as disposable resources. You get yelled at and have your job threatened daily, rarely praised. The union has bled the company dry and now everyone is struggling to compete with other shipping companies with more freedom to run their businesses the way the know will please customers.

review_title: Good First Job for the Experience
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-excellent sales and negotiation training
-great experience dealing with businesses spanning multiple industries
-no overtime ever 8-5 M-F
-promotions are handed out as long as you will relocate
-job security
cons:
-commission bonus metrics and targets constantly in flux
-old timer corporate culture, employees treated like children sometimes
-lack of direction from corporate on actual job duties
-management always metric chasing something new every week 
-outdated internal technology and processes could definitely be streamilined

pros:
Pay for your school
Decent wages for basic labor
Work 5 days a week guaranteed
Get paid holidays and vacations
Free healthcare
cons:
It gets really hot in the summer
Most of the management is dumb, unorganized, and rude. Most of your part-time supervisors are 18-19 year olds who have never held a position of power before. They have no experience managing others and like to hold their power over the workers. 
You rarely get appreciated for a hard day's work

job_title: Front Line Supervisor in Dallas, TX
pros: Known for its benefits, a UPS career is a long-term game. Package handlers may benefit from being paid to work out. Parents and those with dependents will benefit greatly from staying with the union. When it comes your turn to drive a package car, you can make quite a living with out any former education.
cons: Management career is even better than hourly, but you had better be ready to defer gratification. Most front line supervisors work two jobs or are self-employed for the better part of a decade before full time opportunities come available.

pros: Great benefits...if you work here long enough and decide to search for a new job, you'll be prepared  to work anywhere.
cons: Poor work environment,  hardly any recognition,  no company parties, moral sucks, always feel like your on the chopping block. Upper management's way of trying to motivate you is by threatening your job instead of providing advice and tools to improve. review_title: Excellent Pay - BUT you'll EARN every penny
pros: As I've said, the pay is excellent - $35 hr straight time and $52 hr for overtime, of which you can expect about 2 hours per day...whether you want it or not. This puts most of us well over $90k per year and many a bit above $100k. But you will earn every penny - we are actively working 100% of the day. This is a stark contrast to most professions where employers expect to get about 40-60% of productive time out of their workers in a given shift, 75% from an outstanding employee. There is no downtime - no internet surfing or chatting with co-workers. In addition to the pay, you receive free benefits - health, dental, vision. All paid for by the company with no payroll deductions. There's a 401k and full pension in retirement. There's also a discounted class A stock program - preferred stock that's unavailable to the general public. That stock program has made multi-millionaires out of many an old-timer. We receive between 2-6 weeks paid vacation depending on years of service, in addition to the 5 personal days and 5 sick days that everyone gets regardless of seniority. That means that many of us end up with 8 paid weeks off yearly. We are afforded union protection that makes it nearly impossible to be fired unless you break one of the cardinal rules - theft or dishonesty. If you're doing your job well and/or consistently doing your best you can go weeks with little to no contact with management outside the dispatcher. You're working for the industry leader in a growing field with management and union brothers who have tremendous pride in the company and service we provide. You're treated as extended family by many of your customers and will develop many lasting relationships that transcend the job. As such, many drivers do very well with tips around the holidays, adding tax-free income to an already lucrative endeavor. The job security is nearly unmatched - UPS is one of the oldest continuously operating companies in the US with 100+ years of service. Being on the Fortune 100 list and consistently named one of the best companies to work is just par for the course for UPS.
cons: The stress level in this job is fairly high, and much of it is unavoidable. Outstanding performance is both expected and demanded. Everyday. Without exception. The physical demands of the job are extremely strenuous as well. The work/life balance leaves something to be desired - you can expect to work from 8 or 9am to around 8pm every single day. There's no leaving early because you're not feeling well or having a rough day - you are out until you finish with VERY few exceptions. Which means if you're having a bad day, as opposed to cutting out early and heading home to regroup, you will be out longer and later. If you're having a good day and you think you're gonna get out early, think again. Since they can now see your whole day in real-time, the minute you finish your work they'll message you telling you to go help in a different area with deliveries or covering pickups for them. Don't expect to EVER get out "early" or eat your dinner before 7pm. It will only set you up for disappointments. You will need to be prepared to drive and deliver no matter what the temperature or conditions. 100° and 100% humidity, torrential rain and flooding,  -20° with 40mph winds, blizzards and ice storms - doesnt matter - we're out and delivering people's stuff. And you're not just worried about yourself and your skills - you've got to worry about grandma who's 90 and Jr. who's 16 and they're out driving in conditions they aren't equipped for. Let's not forget about Johnny the road rager who is trying to get nowhere in a hurry, and well, you get the picture. We are expected, as highly trained professional drivers to control the situation on the road around us - no exceptions.  The management is obsessed with numbers...stops per hour, mileage, time-allowance, and on and on - these numbers are both unrealistic and/or unattainable, and none of them will be able to explain to you how they arrive at these figures. As an example, oftentimes you will have 1 minute allowed for a pickup that usually ships 20-50 packages that weigh 25+ lbs - an impossible feat if ever there was one...or you'll punch out at 7pm when your last bulk pickup requires you to stay until 630pm no matter what and its a 20 minute drive from there to the center - the next morning they'll tell you that you were 2 hrs over your allowed time, meaning that you should've been off the clock by 5pm...how could that ever be possible when you're required to stay at the pickup until 630pm? If you ask them how they expect that to be possible or how they could even arrive at that asinine figure considering the circumstances - they will NOT have an answer that makes any sense, if they even attempt to give you one. If you park under a tree and a branch breaks off in the wind and cracks your mirror or windshield, you're charged with an accident. If the girl texting her boyfriend backs into your truck while you're not even in it, you're charged with an accident. A deer runs out in front of you and you hit it and crack a headlight, you're charged with an accident. These are all considered AVOIDABLE. There are 2 kinds of accidents at UPS, avoidable or unavoidable, so they say...but it's probably less than 1 of 100 that their investigation will find to be unavoidable (you wouldn't believe the stuff they tell you could've been avoided and how) - so it's basically always your fault. Even if as I said, you're not even in the vehicle at the time. They can now track EVERYTHING about the vehicle(it's called telematics), right down to whether or not the doors are open or you hit the brakes hard to stop quickly. How often and how far you back the truck in reverse. How fast you're driving at any minute of the day. Etc etc etc. This is under the guise of vehicle maintenance/fuel economy and improving the efficiency of the route, but it's really a tracking system to monitor the drivers and micro-manage every aspect of their day if they feel the need, and they WILL at some point. Even if you're doing your job well there's something that you will have to answer for in regard to telematics, like pulling from a stop with the bulkhead door open or the seat belt fully engaged. You will also have to deal with customers who are dishonest - they'll keep a package and say it wasn't received, or call in and say you were speeding or the truck damaged something on their property even though you walked the stop off from the road(this is where telematics is your friend). Sometimes it seems like everyone is trying to get some $$$ outta Big Brown, whether it be a new driveway or suing them for fake injuries - you always need to be cognizant of this...they don't think about the middle class guy they're potentially hurting - it's just a faceless mega-corporation to them and they want that unearned money. This job is literally fraught with hazards - dogs, irate customers, poorly maintained propery, and more. Avoiding them all is the name of the game, and the major key to a long and successful career with UPS.

pros: Benefits are truly unbeatable, honestly. After 1 year of working there you receive full benefits: dental, vision, prescription, and no deductible. I have mine through Anthem Blue Cross/Blue Shield. After 1 year you get 2 weeks paid vacation and paid holidays. After 2 years you get 3 weeks paid vacation and it keeps going up after a certain amount of years are worked. I work with a guy who's been there for 23 years and gets 7 weeks paid vacation every year! It's awesome. It's also honest hard work and if you're not a sissy it provides a certain amount of satisfaction when the job is done for the day. You'll start out as a loader or unloader (unloading is easier). I was an unloader for a month before they promoted me to a sorter. You'll start out at $10.15 as a loader or an unloader and a sorter makes a dollar more. You also get 2 raises a year. One in February and one in August. I went from $10.15 to $12.00 in just a year and a half. If you're looking to make GOOD money, then you'll have to become a driver or work in full time management. Driver's are full time and start out at $18.75 an hour and I think full time management starts out at $60k a year but they're both seniority based jobs. Staying with the company for many years is crucial to making the big bucks. If you go into management though then you'll lose Union benefits which I hear are better than management benefits. I worked in the Cincinnati Hub by the way. Different locations might pay slightly differently, obviously. As far as management to worker relationships goes it depends on location. If you work hard then management shows a high amount of respect and will most likely give you a little bit more hours a week and also could help you climb the ladder of promotion a bit easier (even though it's mainly seniority based). You'll be working around 20-25 hours a week on average. During peak season (November 25th-January 1st), however, you can work as much as you want because they'll be needing help during the holidays. I worked 71 hours in one week and around 60 the other 4 weeks so definitely take advantage of those peak hours. The time and a half and double time rack up big time during peak. My personal advice would be to WORK HARD and IT WILL pay off. Another helpful tip to the "out of shape people like me" when I started is that you will definitely lose weight. I went from 225 at 6'1 to 195 in 3 months. No kidding! It's labor work. What do you expect? Oh and they also offer in-school tuition help. I think it's $2,750 in help every semester! Not too shabby! You'll work for a good company and also get free money to help aid in getting a degree wherever you go! My advice would be to take advantage of that. Go to work, go to college, graduate, become a driver and make $60k+ a year or go into full time management with that degree you received and make $60k+ a year. Win win.
cons: I really only have 2 cons for this company. Super hard work and if you don't want to be a driver or work in management then it takes forever to make decent money. It is hard work but like I said if you're not a wuss ball then you'll be fine. Also, try not to shoot for working on IC's/Irregs/Gold belt if you can help it. That's the easiest place to throw out your back or pull/tear something bc of obvious huge weight increases in packages. If you never become a driver or go into full time management then it'll take at LEAST 15 years of employment before you make decent money. You'll mainly need to work a second job until the 15 years is reached to afford a decent living. No complaints on the benefits, however. Loading, unloading, and sorting do get really boring after 1 year and you'll start to feel a decrease in work desire. I mean your pushing mainly heavy cardboard boxes for hours every day so you'll see what I mean.

I left because I transferred to a university and working 5 nights a week with a commute while being a full-time student was making my grades suffer.
cons:
This place is great if you are willing to work HARD. This means that you're (literally) sweating buckets off every night and show the in-building management that you're a hard worker. This isn't necessarily a con, but from my point of view, the high turnover rate is because most people aren't willing to really bust their backs for a job that only starts you at $10/hour, which is fair. If you stick with it for a little while, you'll go far. If you're trying to make a career out of it, that's another story.

To move from hourly employee to part-time supervisor is generally a pretty quick process if you're a good worker. To make the next step and become full-time, you have to work as a part-time supervisor with pretty small raises for years. Most of my full-time supervisors worked at UPS for at least 10 years before they got the promotion. When you become full-time, you work crazy hours, but make ~$65,000 a year with no college education. The majority of part-time supervisors are competing against one another to try to get promoted to full-time, which rarely happens.

The other route to go as a long-term career is to go driver. Given, I don't know a whole lot about this process, but I do know that it's the same story as trying to move full-time. It takes years. Then when you do get the promotion, you only work part-time through peak season and they put you back to your original position. Deal with that for a couple years and you can have a pretty good, secure job to make a career out of.

The last con that I've mentioned many times: this is HARD WORK. Especially during the dreaded peak season. You're expected to meet pretty high production standards for 8 hours a day during peak. Given, the pay is awesome because Union employees make time and a half after five hours. Part-time supervisors get paid for all the hours they work too. But man, this is a ball-busting place. Easily the most stressful job I could imagine. If you can handle it, awesome. If not, don't bother. You won't last long.

Another minor thing: you have to really commit to the Monday-Friday work schedule every day. They do not give a lot of days off and if you can't work every day every week then they won't hire you.

pros:

cons:
- During peak season, hours doubled or tripled to full time+
- Pay was apparently a bit lower than competing warehouse jobs (not including seasonal bonuses)
- Supervisors never really seemed to know what was going on, who was where, etc
- High turnover rate means many people are inexperienced, and anyone who is good at the job will be endlessly frustrated by their incompetence

cons: Because the company is so large, there are a ton of processes (or lack thereof) in place that really hinder your ability to do work. Very top heavy company; slim opportunity for advancement in your current role, will likely have to move to other positions within the company (often a lateral move vs. promotion); culture not suited to keep new, millennial talent. Limited budgets to do any real events and comms initiatives.

review_title: Ira not your dream job but the good thing is that it pays weekly and times goes by fast.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Harrisburg, PA
pros: There is room for promotion according to seniority and at times opportunities to change positions such as a package handler to become a cover driver to full time driver, once again according to seniority.
cons: Same routine every day.  No economic insensible unless you are working over time.  At times if you are a good worker they tend to explode you in other areas.

pros: Very good starting pay, good training which was payed.  I was a seasonal delivery driver for the holiday season.  If you want a career with UPS making excellent $$, arrive EARLY..at least 30 to 20 mins.  Work your butt of & don't joke around.  It may take 3-5 years to make it as a full-time delivery driver...everyone must work their way up.
cons: None to speak of.  Be a YES man & do what they tell you.  It's in your hands if you want to do well & have a good experience.  You get what you put into it!

pros: Great benefits, 401k, medical, dental, and vision. Coworkers are good people. You do the same thing over and over so you don't have to think much. They have water and ice available. (You'll need it.) The union will save your job. Join the union.
cons: The warehouse is the dirtiest work environment I've ever seen. The management treat you horribly because they know you're replaceable. The work conditions in a trailer are tragic, ranging from blistering heat in the summer and frigidly cold in the winter.

pros: The greatest pros of being a service provider, aka driver, are the pay and benefit package. I have been at UPS over 25 years and I have a college degree, but never found a job that paid well in my small city. I can honestly say my pay was over  $99,000 in 2015. It is nice to be in charge of your daily delivery area. Serving some great people in your delivery area.
cons: The pace is fast and furious. An environment where you are constantly monitored via telematics. Long hours in all weather conditions. The job can take a toll on your family life and general health, such as back, hip and knee problems.

review_title: Not a place for motivated or ambitious individuals
pros:
-Older employees with almost all life spent at UPS provide good learning
-blue collar employees can rise up the ladder
cons:
-ambitious, motivated and highly educated employees will struggle in the company as opportunities are limited and growth very slow
-right people are not rewarded, and it all revolves around who is personally liked by higher mgmt
-old school thought process of managing the company
-conservative and slow to make changes and keep up with the times. still stuck a few decades behind
-lot of talk within the company about culture, but unfortunately that conservative culture doesnt appeal to new age employees in their 20's or 30's
-salary and benefits nothing much to speak about
-tight with the budget

job_title: Production Line Worker in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great experience working at UPS. It was hard work but fulfilling. This is a team environment with great processes to get the job. Coworkers were great to work with.
cons: The shift I was working on started late night and went well into the early morning. This was a tough schedule, but one that I chose to accommodate my school schedule. I wish they had better schedules that would have been more flexible.

pros: I am fortunate to have supervisors that are able to be flexible with my schedule needs. The better you are as an employee, the better you will get treated.  While they expect you to move fast and work with precision, their is more to being  a good employee.  Supervisors value a respectful attitude and a willingness to do any task they ask you to complete.  Tuition reimbursement is a great perk!
cons: The hourly rate is on the low side, but when taken in consideration of the entire compensation package, its not too bad.  The job can be very stressful at times.

review_title: A great place, not much to do.
job_title: Senior Account Manager in Blanchard, OK
pros: Stability, great company, great retirement options.  It is difficult to get let go, unless you commit an integrity violation.  I respect that immensely.  It is also easy to skate by, as long as you give the impression that you are doing what the company asks. And that’s not much.
cons: Zero excitement, all the things that come with being a small fish in a very large pond.  The corporate ladder is all about what your impression on management is, and not necessarily your skill set.  This is reflected in most upper management appointments.

pros: fast paced, always something to do and mentally very simple
cons: very harsh weather conditions.  Trailers are frosted on the inside during winter turning it into a giant fridge and during the summer the 53 foot metal trailers turn into 53 foot ovens.  Constant lifting of heavy shipment items like 6 foot tall construction drills to trailers full of everlast punching bags weighing 60 to 70 pounds each.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Fairfax, VA
pros: Early morning hours allow you to go to school or have a second full time job. They pay up to $5250 a year for you to go to school and that starts they day you are hired. Great medical benefits and as a part time worker who else gets a health insurance plan with a zero dollar premium.
cons: It gets to be hard waking up at 3am to move boxes.

review_title: If you have a college degree and other options, this is not a good company to work for.
pros: You learn to be ruthless, which when coupled with positive experience elsewhere can be useful.
cons: Long hours, management pay cuts, zero positive recognition, micro-managing by higher levels of management, no opportunities for advancement based on merit, no networking opportunities, zero work/life balance, extended off-shift assignments are expected, no opportunity to use vacation, management by intimidation.

review_title: Lack of appreciation for skilled employees
job_title: Lead Technical Specialist in Paramus, NJ
pros: Many really great and smart  people and managers. Philanthropic organization that truly cares about the community and its customers.
cons: Very strong corporate culture which still promotes old-school management style that was born out of the unionized labor force which limits innovation and creativity. Very little opportunity for career growth unless someone higher up retires. No technology experiments, just routine implementation of requirements based on customer demands.

review_title: 36 years at company, 24 years in management-a great company on the decline.
pros:
Challenging work
Dedicated co-workers and subordinates
cons:
No work/life balance,  your family is expected to take 2nd priority behind the job in management.  Very strong "silos" protect division and district managers from responsibilities and consequences. "Club-like" structure in place to isolate upper mgt.from hourly and front line management. 
Long hours and the only way you will know you are doing a good job if you don't hear from your boss.

pros: Got hired 15 an hr for helper was called two Monday's ago asked if I had a uniform she told me they would send me one with my driver. Told me I would get a call everyday through Christmas . I never got a call and my uniform never came and I've seen driver three times since then. I called back and emailed and have not gotten any response. Thanks for making me drive two hours for nothing! Kind of irritated I was on my last dollar and couldn't afford to waste anything! I needed a job not for someone to play games
cons: They are just hiring you and never calling so what's the point?

pros: UPS is a great company to work for. The company provides great opportunities within this company. They also provide their part time employees with full time benefits such as retirement, health insurance, dental and vision insurance.
cons: UPS employees work very hard! There are a lot of lifting heavy boxes, fast paced work, bending and pushing/pulling. Therefore leaves a lot of stressing your body.

pros:
- Graduate college with very little to no student loan debt
- Great benefits package for part time employees
- Opportunities for promotion
cons:
- The hours are extremely difficult to get used to, especially if youre still in school

review_title: Great company; but needs to join 21century when it comes to equality n the work place

job_title: Delivery Driver Helper in Seneca, PA
