job_title: Package Car Driver in Oakland, CA
pros: They have a strong fully funded pension program BECAUSE of the UNION. They have strong health care benefits. The work is consistent and you have a set schedul
cons: We had to work forced overtime. Requests for vacation are only accepted in the month of March and you are awarded vacation based on seniority. They set unrealistic expectations for work loads and they follow you around secretly with a movie camera if they have concerns about your performance.

pros: 15.00/hour, union, benefits, college scholarship program.
cons: Stay away from preload; it says 5-9AM, but in reality it's 1 or 2-7 or 8:30. You should know what to expect from your interview should you choose to pursue after they warn you: You lose sleep when your body needs it (night shift will shorten your life in some way over an extended amount of time), working very hard, getting beat up by the packages (wear boots with protection and gloves), getting placed on-call indefinitely after holiday season, and thus getting texted or called in at godforsaken hours. In other words, there aren't too many perks with working for UPS. Depends on whether you work in the hub, or delivery drivers. Nothing is special or inspiring here.

pros: Good salary, good benefits. Good job if you can handle the stress, take criticism, handle pressure  and don't have young kids.
cons: Expect to work 12+ hrs daily. Sink or swim environment. Very stressful, fast pace environment. Lots of yelling,  screaming and being talked down to. No time for having a life outside of work. Don't recommend if you have kids. You'll rarely get to to see them and when you do you'll be mentally and physically exhausted.

pros: Certain jobs at the corporate office have good work hours, mine does. I don't have to work over 45+ hours many weeks.
cons: Benefits aren't what they used to be; no more pension, nothing exciting at the workplace (not even TVs in cafeteria), they charge you for gym membership at the small on site gym, getting promoted is more of a "who do you know" type system, training is not widely available aside from the dated online "University" system, pay is not at industry level, annual bonus is 50% deferred stock (stock that is NOT a growth stock), hard to advance if you don't have "field" experience (so not great for college grads)

pros:
Benefits beyond the company, which include discounts on a large variety of items and services
Decent Pay
Off by 9-10 AM
Many active programs for helping the local community
cons:
Starting time isn't 5:30 AM as HR will tell you, it can actually range from 3:30 to as early as 11:00 PM the previous day. 
Have to filter out many mistakes from other sections, typically items needing to go elsewhere in your area or labeled for the wrong destination altogether.

pros: This is the only company that offers over night delivery of your order.  Friendly people, well trained leaders which in turn makes well trained employees.  Your day starts at 3:00 am - 11:00 am.  That can be a good thing for some but not for all.  I like it.  Many opportunities within the company to grow.   Your attire is "dress to get dirty".
cons: Pay scale too low for the work that is put into the job each day.  Early hours start from 3:00 am - 11:00 am.  Not for everyone.

review_title: Not a bad job and you will learn a lot. Pay is not competitive for expected workload
pros: The benefit are good as they have always been at UPS. There are a lot of really good teammates that work together. The work is not overly difficult.
cons: Although the work is not difficult, workloads tend to be heavy especially when short staffed. High turnover in department, due to advancement or better opportunities elsewhere. Job expectations are somewhat unrealistic due to the amount of responsibilities and work given.

review_title: A decent place to work if one is not looking for an active career growth. Provides a stable job.
pros: UPS provides some great benifits in terms of health care and post retirement (not for new employees though). This motivates lot of the existing employes to stay with the company. Also, this company is very strong on ethics and moral values.
cons: Lack of growth and opportunities. This is a company with reactive efforts primarily. Not much change is seen in general. Not a great choice for fresh college grads (strictly speaking of the IS department). The IS department is managed as a cost center. Hence there are hardly any budget and opportunities for trying new products/process.

job_title: Part-time Package Handler in Louisville, KY
pros: Good Benefits, Decent Pay depending on the job you acquire within the company. Work environment can be great depending on management and coworkers, however there is little done to improve worker morale.
cons: Complete luck of the draw on placement with coworkers/management who can be awesome or completely incompetent. There is no incentive to work hard as you are paid the same regardless of amount of work done or type of employee you are. Abysmal company spirit among most employees encountered as they are only there because there are no other options. A great deal of time is spent on silly information that doesn't even pertain to the task you are performing.

review_title: This is a fast pace environment. Good people.
pros: Everyone is helpful from the drivers to the supervisors. If you work hard, they are there to support you. If you are a slacker, you will not last.
cons: It is difficult to get in. you have to do your time. Unfortunately that means working part time for half the money for 6 months out of the year, until (hopefully) something opens up for you.

pros: If you are a union employee you receive free benefits after a year (medical, dental, eye). The package car drivers (union) get payed decent money (50,000 up to over 90,000 a year or more depending on seniority.) Feeder truck drivers (union) get payed well. Every union employee gets a guaranteed raise every year. Part time union employees have no limit on pay rate. Feeders cap out at a certain pay rate. Mechanics (union) get payed well once they acquire seniority. Their pay also caps out after a number of years. Part-time supervisors get the benefit of having most of their college payed for. Union employees also receive compensation for school, but not all centers offer this for union employees. You can acquire your CDL through UPS, and if you go the supervisor career path (non union) you gain good experience. UPS looks good on your resume. You do not have to have a college degree to become a package car, or feeder driver. UPS is a good company to work for if you have patience and are willing to work.
cons: Non union employees (supervisors, management) have to pay for their health benefits. UPS will try to get every ounce of work out of you that they can no matter what position you work. Especially out of part-time supervisors, package drivers, and part-time union employees working in the warehouse. If you go the package car driver route and you do not have a college degree many drivers start making money, and end up buying a house, a car, having kids exd. Then after a few years or more they end up hating their position, and become "trapped" at the company because they have bills, and no other experience to get another job without taking a pay cut.  At the center I work at they have outdated equipment and won't fix broken equipment unless it is absolutely necessary. Because of the union everything is seniority based, so sometimes people who deserve the more skilled positions that pay more can get bumped from that job by someone who does not deserve the position but has more seniority. Some union employees will try to "play" the system, and use the union to get out of trouble. Once they get away with doing this a few times they think that they are invincible because the union will always protect them. As a result supervisors sometimes have trouble getting employees to follow instruction. Supervisors don't get payed enough money, and don't receive proper training. UPS does not offer full time employment for any entry level position. Starting pay rate for entry level positions is low. Upper management is greedy, and does not do whats best for the center.

job_title: Handler of the Package in Middletown, NJ
pros: Outstanding benefits, Union, decent regular pay bumps in wharehouse, great pay for those who can make it behind the wheel, and a great opportunity to make a life career out of moving cardboard for someone who can't count past D
cons: loading boxes in a cold/hot trailer every weekend for 3+ hours until you go driver (then long days on the road), no place else to take your skills once you're in the door, you're there til retirement (with pension and benefits, not a bad deal at all), you'll have your hands on more box than degeneres

job_title: Air Ramp Supervisor in Billings, MT
pros: The benefits are great.  I've only been there 3 months so far, but they seem to be a company who really cares about those who work for them.  I've also been impressed with the caliber of people who work there.  Great place to work.
cons: I just wish it could be a full-time position.  I really like the job, but the nature of it is part-time because I work at a Gateway.  I also think the wage could be higher considering the amount of responsibility I have.

pros: great  benefits  great people
cons: making changes to  job  duties without properly  training employees  leads to a lot of  mistakes and  frustration. The Brokerage has a Professional  Improvement program  that  does  not  work as  intended.   What is  accomplished is  workers'  feeling  paranoid  and  frustrated.   How errors are applied is also  a problem.   Errors  should be  flagged  by  computer  programs  not  fellow  employees.

job_title: Seasonal Package Handler in Lubbock, TX
pros: Great place to work. Moving up and around is available. Paid education is a possibility. Benefits are great. Many hours available. Supervisors train you to perform your duties as expected.
cons: Many, many applications are submitted. You have to continually keep tabs on applications for current jobs available.  You can not be hired full time unless you have been there a full year. Until a full time, full year employee then no benefits are available.

pros: UPS affords its employees room for growth. They also provide great, affordable medical & dental insurance. They work alongside of strong unions that ensure safe environments for employees.
cons: The labor can be intense at times. Though they do offer less physically demanding positions, the bulk of the job opportunities involve long hours of heavy lifting. It's a great way to stay in shape though!

pros: Most people were really nice and pleasant to work with. The work environment was good, facilities were about what you'd expect. Canteen with vending machines, fridge, microwave, kettle.
cons:
Traffic is a nightmare at night. If you left before 5pm it would take a minute to get out of the estate, but if you left after 5pm it would be 30 minutes to go 100yds to the business estate exit. 

My boss wouldn't be flexible about start and finish times, even though they and others in my department came and went as they pleased. Offered to start later and finish later or start earlier and finish earlier but they wouldn't entertain it. I'd not been there long and this incident set off alarm bells for me because their reaction to being asked a simple request was bizarre. 

As I say most people are really nice but there were a few who had been there for years and years and they were allowed to speak to you like crap and the rules didn't seem to apply to them. My immediate supervisor was one of those. 

The flexibility about times and my request really brought it home to me that we wouldn't get on. They just couldn't find it in themselves to compromise about anything after my initial request and I decided to hand my notice in a few weeks later. 

HR in my exit interview said they would have facilitated some flexibility but I felt that my boss would have taken this as a declaration of some sort of war, I just wanted to leave quietly, at the end of the day I just want to earn a living not go into battle every day.

review_title: Twilight Metro Unloader @ UPS for 3 years now
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Cerritos, CA
pros:
-Great benefits
-Great PTO
-Great Workout to keep in shape (building some muscle always is nice!)
-Great co-workers (at least for me)
-Weekly paychecks (direct deposit is recommended)
-Shipping discounts (only applies if you do it online @ upsers, you can't get the discount by walking into the actual shipping center and showing your ID or anything)
-Great supervisors
-Great managers
cons:
I'm a very honest person, so I'll just tell it like it is what my personal view of cons are at the hub I work at. Keep in mind that my pros outweigh the cons, as these cons are just the little things that nudge me and they are things i've experienced personally, so I just want you to be aware of it if you're looking to work for UPS. It looks like a lot, but it's just me adding detail.

-If you're a college student, read this. UPS doesn't pay for your college (or give you loans or whatever) unless you're in management (supervisor and higher). I believe you need to work at UPS for about 6 months before you can apply for a supervisor position, and then if you get promoted, then the college benefits will apply. This is what i've been told by my supervisor.

-Not a con really, but just be aware, the place is incredibly hot in the summer. Wear tanktops.

-You will work anywhere from 3-5 hours tops per day (unless you're double shifting), with only a 10 minute break which could happen at ANY moment. I've gone on breaks 15-30 minutes into the shift because some people were late to the sort/loading aisle and they couldn't keep up with the flow of operations, and i've had breaks with only 30-45 minutes left in the shift. Whatever the case, just know this.

-People have probably told you for a long time that UPS is a "great company to work for." Yes, it is ... in the long, long run.  It takes a long time to get a full-time position. At my hub, it takes between 6-15 years to get a full time job. Literally. I'm on the list currently to be a delivery driver, and I think there were 600-800 others on that list with me, some of whom have been there for 5-10 years already and are STILL part-time. To add to that bonus, it's seniority-based. They don't choose the most promising people on the list, they choose those who've been there the longest. Yikes. Here's a tip though, I've spoken to at least a dozen drivers and they all recommend that you do saturday delivery while you're on that list to start (even volunteering as a driver helper), as it will help tremendously to transition you into the full-time delivery spot when the time comes. 

-The pay is not very good for the amount of strain and sweat we endure. Prepare to make around $500-$700/mo for a while if you're a part-timer. I'm barely getting by with those paychecks. If you're in college, this job may be suitable for you. If you're trying to find a place to settle in for the next 30 years, get another PT/FT job with UPS to accommodate your wages until you get a full time position.

-They don't care if you're a hard worker. Seniority is supreme at UPS, and working physically harder and quicker than everyone else will not get you a raise or promoted faster. I'm personally tired of people telling me to "charm" my way up at UPS. It just doesn't work like that here. Only time will present you the opportunity, since everything is a "list." I'm not saying you shouldn't work hard and be lazy though.

-College education is deceiving at UPS. They're necessary for some positions obviously, but the management field is a very thin line. I was told by multiple people (mostly supervisors and even great managers) that management will accept any business degree regardless of the field of interest or the position you're trying to apply for. They just want you to "advance yourself" and not become a higher position just for the sake of being that. In other words, don't apply to become a supervisor JUST to be a supervisor, they want you to want more in life than to just settle in that position.

-They say that safety is everything, but the equipment is unsafe. The maintenance crew prolongs the projects for months (or even years). Management tends to spend more time reminding you of the 8 keys of lifting and lowering, hazmat handling, avoiding slips and falls, and yard control than they do fixing your equipment. Also, you WILL get bruises, strains, and scratches, and other things like tendonitis. It's very easy to get hurt even if you are safe.

review_title: Like an Olympic level workout - and you're getting paid!
pros:
This is specifically for working in the warehouse portion of a distribution center.

Staying in good physical shape is NOT an issue when working at UPS inside one of their distribution centers. Even working part time, 3-4 hours each day, the level of physical activity is pretty extreme. Yes, this may sound bad to a lot of people, but if you're interested in staying in shape and getting paid, this is a great way to do it.
Oh, and uh... good team environment, stable pay, and the company is willing to adapt to your physical abilities - if you can't do something crazy (like unload a shipping truck in <10 minutes) you can do something more suitable.

If you want more work, they provide the option to assist the drivers with making deliveries. This extra work, coupled with morning warehouse work, can turn UPS into a (almost) full-time job (with a pretty long lunch break). This is great if you want to travel locally, meet new people, and train to move up within the company to a driving and delivery position. But you have to wear a uniform.
cons:
Again, the physical activity. This work is not for the medically challenged, the elderly, the asthmatic, or the lazy. Speed and strength are essential. Although safety is a prime concern, it is very easy to injure yourself or others through careless mistakes, improper lifting techniques, communication failures, or being over-ambitious when lifting and moving packages. Some of the packages are awkward - stacks of tires, broken boxes of printer ink cartridges being sent for recycling, bags of golf clubs, 12 foot long 2x4 blocks of wood... UPS will ship pretty much anything that's not alive or illegal.

The pay and benefits aren't that great - but they are better than what you might expect from a part-time job.

Great benefits.

The value UPS can have for someone is unreal. It just depends on your situation. I think this is a very good company to work for if you're in college. I don't think it's the greatest long term career opportunity though.
cons:
Not a great company to work for as a college grad. They require a degree for advancement, but don't value your degree. The company doesn't welcome personal ambition. You advance on companies terms. They choose the direction you go. Its a great opportunity for someone that isn't a risk taker. 

UPS creates an environment that makes employees believe they are the only opportunity out there. Also imply their pay is better than any other company, which isn't always true. 

Only promotes within. The management is kind of blinded by the outside world. This I due to no one ever worked for another company. There is a ton to learn from ups' processes, but they don't always welcome innovation.

Working in small package operations is a very specific field of work. The only US competitors are FedEX and USPS. This can hurt your chances to switch markets down the road. UPS doesn't normally allow you to switch between their companies, such as UPS Freight.

Pay raises are really bad. Really really bad. They are based on a qpr. If you hit your numbers your manager's review can cancel out your numbers, which results in a poor raise. If you don't hit your numbers you get a poor raise. You hardly hear about big time raises. Your pay slow increases over the 30 year tenure they expect you to be there.

This isn't a bad company giving my negative reviews. It's more based on working while in college verses after graduating. I'm very lucky to have worked at ups. It helped me be very successful at my new company. 

No time off from thanksgiving through the New Year.

pros:
UPS is always in need of Part-time Supervisors; this gives all package handlers an opportunity to get management experience on their resumes. They offer excellent medical, vision, and dental benefits at a fraction of the actual costs if you are a supervisor (about 30 to 35 a month if you only want them for yourself). Pay is about average for the position of PT Supervisor compared to other similar positions. 

They give part-time supervisors a base salary that is supposedly based on your length of service before promotion, but I found this to be untrue, its who you know above. The base salary is based on a 5.5 hour work day/27.5 hour workweek. After you go over the 5.5 or 27.5 hours you are given an extra 10% on top of your broken down wage. Time and a half is given for going over 8.0 hours and 40 hours.

Also available is 401k matching which was maxed at 6% for part-time supervisors and in addition there is tuition reimbursement at 4,000 per year for approved courses/degrees. Stock can be purchased at a 10% discount.

Part-time package handlers start at 8.50/hr here in Southern California. Benefits are free for the employees after 12 months of employment. Tuition reimbursement is at 3,000 a year.

Women are always looked at first for "diversity" and can expect a quick climb up the career ladder.
cons:
If you are management, then dealing with the union is the biggest downside. The union is allowed to have too much power, often leaving managements' hands tied most of the time. From as little as telling an employee to "hurry up," can cause an employee to file a grievance based on "harassment". Often employees will look for any supervisor moving a box  or breaking a jam and will file a grievance because the suprvisor is "stealing" work from union employees. From what I understand this a little more exclusive to the Ontario Hub, and I understand it is not as bad in most other hubs. 


Upper Management does not seem to care about their part time supervisors to the effect that often times they will not defend against the grievances filed simply because they may have a good relationship with a few of the shop stewarts or because they don't want to deal with arguing. A bad relationship with your lead supervisor or manager can make it worse.

Raises for Part-time supervisors are supposedly based on a combo of the shift manager or full time supervisor and a peer review. Most of the time 2 to 3% is the common raise given once a year. However, this is where either being buddy-buddy with the Manager or Full Time supervisor comes in handy so you can get a 5 or 6% raise. If you are female and somewhat attractive, it works to your advantage as you will often receive larger raises and more opportunities to advance faster without being necessarily qualified. 

Part Time Package Handlers only receive 8.50 an hour to start and need to pay union dues and most importantly their initiation fee. The first 4 months of employment are very difficult because you get a small paycheck after all the dues and fees are taken out AFTER taxes. Checks less than 100 bucks a week are very, very common.
